title: Agriculture and global physicochemical deregulation: planetary boundaries that challenge planetary health
display_name: Agriculture and global physicochemical deregulation: planetary boundaries that challenge planetary health

author.au_affiliation_raw: Complex Systems Institute de Lyon and Plant Reproduction and Development Laboratories, Ecole Normale Supérieure de Lyon, Université de Lyon, Lyon 69342, France
author.institution_display_name: Laboratoire Reproduction et Développement des Plantes
author.institution_lineage: https://openalex.org/I100532134, https://openalex.org/I113428412, https://openalex.org/I1294671590, https://openalex.org/I1326498283, https://openalex.org/I203339264, https://openalex.org/I4210088668, https://openalex.org/I4210096427, https://openalex.org/I4210143888

author.au_affiliation_raw: Complex Systems Institute de Lyon and Plant Reproduction and Development Laboratories, Ecole Normale Supérieure de Lyon, Université de Lyon, Lyon 69342, France

ab: Clear identification and characterisation of social and ecological challenges is crucial to define priorities and allocate limited resources,1Lomborg B The skeptical environmentalist: measuring the real state of the world. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge2001Crossref Google Scholar and to work out solutions and tools for their implementation. Research should serve to increase human understanding of those challenges and the objective interdependencies among them. The resource concept constitutes a unifying theme across disciplines and sectors, such as the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs),2Acunzo D Escher G Ottersen OP et al.Framing planetary health: arguing for research centred science.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e101-e102Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (4) Google Scholar a first point of reference for systemic change. Therefore, the resource approach becomes the most effective tool to address the surrounding issues of planetary health.2Acunzo D Escher G Ottersen OP et al.Framing planetary health: arguing for research centred science.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e101-e102Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (4) Google Scholar The notion of social and planetary boundaries3Steffen W, Richardson K, Rockstrom J, et al. Planetary boundaries: guiding human development on a changing planet. Science 201; 47: 1259855.Google Scholar, 4Raworth K A safe and just space for humanity: can we live within the doughnut?. Oxfam, February 2012https://www.oxfam.org/sites/www.oxfam.org/files/dp-a-safe-and-just-spacefor-humanity-130212-en.pdfDate accessed: April 29, 2018Google Scholar is a complementary conceptual framework that defines safe operating boundaries for its nine dimensions (climate change, ocean acidification, chemical pollution, nitrogen and phosphorus loading, freshwater withdrawals, land conversion, biodiversity loss, air pollution, and ozone layer depletion). The framework's goal is to help achieve a sustainable future for humanity3Steffen W, Richardson K, Rockstrom J, et al. Planetary boundaries: guiding human development on a changing planet. Science 201; 47: 1259855.Google Scholar by suggesting safe limits to the nine dimensions. This framework allows to measure such limits by using a combination of warning sign, threshold, and regime shift indicators. The transgression of the framework's boundaries through the misuse and misallocation of resources has undesired consequences to global functions and cycles of Earth's life-supporting systems and is leading to the disturbance of complex ecological and physicochemical equilibria to a degree beyond their natural resilience. The framework and its use has sparked interest within the scientific, societal, and political communities.3Steffen W, Richardson K, Rockstrom J, et al. Planetary boundaries: guiding human development on a changing planet. Science 201; 47: 1259855.Google Scholar, 4Raworth K A safe and just space for humanity: can we live within the doughnut?. Oxfam, February 2012https://www.oxfam.org/sites/www.oxfam.org/files/dp-a-safe-and-just-spacefor-humanity-130212-en.pdfDate accessed: April 29, 2018Google Scholar, 5Whitmee S Haines A Beyrer C et al.Safeguarding human health in the Anthropocene epoch: report of The Rockefeller Foundation. Lancet Commission on planetary health.Lancet. 2015; 386: 1973-2028Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1122) Google Scholar By showing the interconnectedness of the boundaries, it is possible to clarify planetary health issues and give them meaning in political and societal terms. The framework can be condensed down to a two-component system: agriculture and physicochemical deregulation. Agriculture is both the greatest labour provider and resource consumer (land-use change and biomass appropriation). Agriculture and associated food systems (from fork to farm)6Westhoek H Ingram J Van Berkum S Özay L Hajer M Food systems and natural resources. A report of the working group on food systems of the international resource panel. 2016. UN Environment Programme.file://C:/Users/OCONNOR2/Downloads/food_systems_summary_report_english.pdfDate accessed: September 15, 2018Google Scholar are the biggest contributors to the stressors of planetary boundaries, including changes in land and water systems, ecosystem alterations, fertiliser chemical flows, air and water pollution, and climate change. More specifically, agriculture entangles the key biogeophysical building blocks of the biosphere—biomass, soil, and water—which need protection from environmental and management related risks through policy decision making. This is important because the geopolitics of biomass, water, and land are driving the new resource scarcities,7Mathijs E Brunori G Carus M et al.Sustainable agriculture, forestry and fisheries in the Bioeconomy—a challenge for Europe.https://ec.europa.eu/research/scar/pdf/feg4_final.pdf#view=fit&pagemode=noneDate: 2015Date accessed: April 28, 2018Google Scholar, 8Gabriel-Oyhamburu K Le retour d'une géopolitique des ressources?.L'Espace Politique. 2011; 12: 1-15Google Scholar which are causing conflict between national security and international order mechanisms. Global physicochemical deregulation is a pervasive and hidden global challenge. It is generated through ocean acidification; more general atmospheric, land, and water pollutions; waste accumulation; and climate change. The corresponding chemical intensification affects societies daily on a large scale: 144 000 types of chemicals are manufactured, with a 500-fold increase in volume over the last several decades.9UN Environment ProgrammeGlobal chemicals outlook: synthesis report for decision-makers.http://wedocs.unep.org/handle/20.500.11822/8264Date: 2012Date accessed: September 15, 2018Google Scholar The result is a so-called mega-pollution system consisting of complex chemical cocktails in the environment (eg, pesticides, endocrine disruptors, antibiotics, and microplastics) that interact with the natural chemical world1Lomborg B The skeptical environmentalist: measuring the real state of the world. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge2001Crossref Google Scholar and change over space and time. This makes it hard, and sometimes impossible, to measure, understand, and control the exposure to a mixture of chemicals for which safe limits for polluting factors have to be estimated with regard to exposure to any single chemical.1Lomborg B The skeptical environmentalist: measuring the real state of the world. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge2001Crossref Google Scholar Current standards are based on studies that have been done on one chemical at a time. Mixing different chemicals can result in additive, synergistic, or antagonistic effects. For example, simple chemical mixtures that consist of five pesticides found in food commodities showed additive to synergistic genotoxic effects in cultured cells.10Graillot V Takakura N Le Hegarat L et al.Genotoxicity mixtures present in the diet of the French population.Environ Mol Mutagen. 2012; 53: 173-184Crossref PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar Consequently, a detailed knowledge of the response to all possible combinations of chemical risk factors implies dividing the limit value for an individual factor by the square root of the number of factors under consideration. Although this calculation would be unrealistic in practice, it suggests that the adoption of limit values two or three orders of magnitude smaller than those estimated by single factor impact studies1Lomborg B The skeptical environmentalist: measuring the real state of the world. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge2001Crossref Google Scholar is relevant to legislation. However, this is a problem: prevention protocols, standards, and legislation are not well adapted to the scale of risks operating in constantly evolving environments. Agriculture and physicochemical deregulation act in synergy, are first order systemic risks to planetary health2Acunzo D Escher G Ottersen OP et al.Framing planetary health: arguing for research centred science.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e101-e102Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (4) Google Scholar with long-term effects on the society. For example, the health and economic burden of conventional food systems and global pollution is estimated to cost trillions of US dollars annually and contribute to millions of deaths globally.11International Panel of Experts on Sustainable Food SystemsUnravelling the food-health nexus.http://www.ipesfood.org/images/Reports/Health_FullReport.pdfDate: 2017Date accessed: April 15, 2018Google Scholar, 12Ghebreyesus TA Acting on NCDs: counting the cost.Lancet. 2018; 391: 1973-1974Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar Low-income countries are the most affected. We argue that the health and economic burden constitutes a systemic challenge (so-called health bubble), which government and society will have to address over the next decade. Therefore, we call for, first, coordinated measures that target planetary health through coherent chemical simplification (effectively reduce, redesign, and recycle to make better use of a smaller number of different chemicals) in transitions to societies that decrease their use of resources and are resource efficient.2Acunzo D Escher G Ottersen OP et al.Framing planetary health: arguing for research centred science.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e101-e102Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (4) Google Scholar, 13Haines A Hanson C Ranganathan J Planetary Health Watch: integrated monitoring in the Anthropocene epoch.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e141-e143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar This measure could also help to slow down climate change. Second, we call for the integration of sustainable agriculture practices into food system transitions9UN Environment ProgrammeGlobal chemicals outlook: synthesis report for decision-makers.http://wedocs.unep.org/handle/20.500.11822/8264Date: 2012Date accessed: September 15, 2018Google Scholar with priority on land tenure and value and the food-health nexus. These measures are at the apex of further changes in joint environmental and societal policies that articulate physical and social boundaries4Raworth K A safe and just space for humanity: can we live within the doughnut?. Oxfam, February 2012https://www.oxfam.org/sites/www.oxfam.org/files/dp-a-safe-and-just-spacefor-humanity-130212-en.pdfDate accessed: April 29, 2018Google Scholar in a resource stewardship approach. They are guided by simple, universal, and indivisible principles in support of a civilisation contract.2Acunzo D Escher G Ottersen OP et al.Framing planetary health: arguing for research centred science.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e101-e102Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (4) Google Scholar The goal is to measure the total costs to society of no action versus partial-to-complete phase-out of large sets of chemicals and unsustainable practices. This phase out would help to align equity in health and wealth within the limits of the biosphere. By addressing the health concerns associated with agriculture and physicochemical deregulation it could be possible to devise laws that enable fair access to and allocation of resources, a process for which WHO13Haines A Hanson C Ranganathan J Planetary Health Watch: integrated monitoring in the Anthropocene epoch.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e141-e143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar and the International Resource Panel2Acunzo D Escher G Ottersen OP et al.Framing planetary health: arguing for research centred science.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e101-e102Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (4) Google Scholar could ensure the initial coordination role. We declare no competing interests.

title: Planetary health in Nepal's post-earthquake rebuilding agenda: progress and future directions
display_name: Planetary health in Nepal's post-earthquake rebuilding agenda: progress and future directions

author.au_affiliation_raw: Nepal Development Society, Bharatpur, Nepal
Centre for Tropical Medicine and Global Health, Nuffield Department of Medicine, University of Oxford, Oxford, UK

ab: Planetary health is the health of the human civilizations and of the planet they inhabits; in particular, the health of their physical, political, economic, and social elements, as well as the health of human culture and heritage, which shape humanity.1Horton R Lo S Planetary health: a new science for exceptional action.Lancet. 2015; 386: 1921-1922Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar Disasters affect the health of humans and the planet alike. The earthquakes in Nepal in 2015 had a tectonic origin; however, the huge losses it caused (9000 deaths, 18 000 injuries, and >500 000 households and 1000 health facilities damaged) could have been mitigated if there had been a rapid response.2Adhikari B Mishra SR Babu Marahatta S et al.Earthquakes, fuel crisis, power outages, and health care in Nepal: implications for the future.Disaster Med Public Health Prep. 2017; 11: 625-632Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar Environmental losses from the earthquakes have been overlooked. Ongoing rampant urban development coupled with unsystematic recovery efforts after the earthquake has had the greatest toll on lives. Overlooking the planetary health agendas that arose from these earthquakes will continue to threaten the existence of one of the oldest civilisations of southern Asia. In this Comment, we identify and discuss key challenges that need to be addressed immediately and could be part of local advocacy. The National Reconstruction Authority (NRA)—a legally mandated agency for leading the earthquake recovery and reconstruction efforts in Nepal—estimated that US$7 billion are required for rebuilding, of which $2·9 billion were to be sourced internally.3Adhikari N Nepal's earthquake disaster: two years and $4·1bn later.https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2017/04/nepal-earthquake-disaster-years-41bn-170412110550808.htmlDate: 2017Date accessed: April 1, 2018Google Scholar Still, 3 years after the earthquakes, the NRA has only managed to disburse 16% of the total 4.1 billion USD pledged by donors. The owners of only 544 996 of 900 000 damaged houses have received their first payment, which accounts for only 17% of the total reconstruction grants.3Adhikari N Nepal's earthquake disaster: two years and $4·1bn later.https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2017/04/nepal-earthquake-disaster-years-41bn-170412110550808.htmlDate: 2017Date accessed: April 1, 2018Google Scholar People from impoverished communities, who are at high health risk, are the most heavily affected by this lumbering distribution of funds. The impact of the earthquakes on the economically vulnerable population has been rising steadily, and has caused an increase in the illegal sale of organs (such as kidneys) to pay for costs of living.4Cousins S Nepal: organ trafficking after the earthquake.Lancet. 2016; 387: 833Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar, 5Adhikari B Organ and human trafficking in Nepal.Lancet. 2016; 387: 1907Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar The increase in employment abroad has caused a huge proportion of male labour to migrate to Gulf nations, leaving thousands of families split. As a result, many villages are left without men, which added to the strain of the already substantial male-labour migration trend in Nepal.6Agarwal GRP Rebuilding Nepal: creating good jobs amid reconstruction and migration.https://www.solidaritycenter.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/SC-JJN-Nepal-Project-Report-25042017-webversion-1.pdfDate: 2017Date accessed: April 1, 2018Google Scholar The latest data for out-migration for labour work has shown a steady rise trend since the earthquakes, with almost 500 000 emigrants in 2015.6Agarwal GRP Rebuilding Nepal: creating good jobs amid reconstruction and migration.https://www.solidaritycenter.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/SC-JJN-Nepal-Project-Report-25042017-webversion-1.pdfDate: 2017Date accessed: April 1, 2018Google Scholar Hence, poor families are forced to pay for expensive labour and construction material for rebuilding their homes. The momentum for building back better has dampened, particularly as conventional construction methods without retrofits have been used in rebuilding the houses. The extensive extraction of clay soil for bricks, deforestation to supply wood to kilns and construction, and extraction of sand from quarries are causing concern. In a community-based study in Nepal, more than half of the respondents felt the impacts of climate change, such as a rise in temperature and episodes of droughts.7Mishra SR Bhandari PM Issa R Neupane D Gurung S Khanal V Climate change and adverse health events: community perceptions from the Tanahu district of Nepal.Environl Res Lett. 2015; 10: 034007Crossref Scopus (17) Google Scholar Indiscriminate sand and gravel extraction and deforestation in Nepal's southern plains have failed to draw the government's attention or to prompt it to take action. Increased overexploitation of ecosystem resources causes deepening and widening of river beds, which in turn affect the flow of surface water. Unsurprisingly, the consequences of deepening and widening of river beds have been evident in the flooding patterns in past years. In 2017, 160 people were killed and 26 went missing in a major flood that inundated the southern planes of Nepal, stretching over an area of 1355 km2 that borders India.8Uprety A Ozaki A Senoo Y et al.Flood damage in Nepal exacerbated by underlying conflict with India.Lancet Planet Health. 2017; 1: e351-e352Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3) Google Scholar The unsystematic reconstruction continues to affect air quality in Kathmandu. Roads are further damaged by heavy vehicles, landslides, and unrepaired potholes. Heavy-duty trucks carrying construction materials in the narrow and winding roads of the capital, coupled with high-speed driving practices have increased the number of road-traffic accidents. More than 2385 deaths were attributed to road traffic accidents in 2016–17, a 16% increase compared with the previous year.9Times THRoad accident fatalities continue unabated.https://thehimalayantimes.com/nepal/road-accident-fatalities-continue-unabated/Date: 2017Date accessed: April 2, 2018Google Scholar Air pollution in Kathmandu is worsened by CO2 emissions from vehicles and brick-kilns located in and outside the valley. An ongoing potable-water pipeline project has further added to the amount of dust in Kathmandu. The air quality index in Kathmandu exceeds the threshold established by WHO (the air quality index was reported to be >200, which indicates poor air quality), during all days of the week.10US Embassy K, Nepal Air PollutionUS Embassy, Kathmandu air pollution: real-time air quality index (AQI).http://Aqicn.Org/City/Nepal/Kathmandu/Us-Embassy/Date: 2018Date accessed: April 1, 2018Google Scholar Concern for the situation has been repeatedly raised by WHO, other health agencies, and civil society, but it has yet to be addressed. Uncoordinated and inappropriate construction methods have also put Nepal's cultural heritage at risk. The reconstruction of one of the most iconic sites of Kathmandu, Rani Pokhari, was started with concrete and mortar, but was halted after widespread resistance from the public and environmentalists. Reconstruction of Dharahara, a tower built two centuries ago, is still uncertain. 822 monuments from seven UNESCO heritage sites were either partially or completely destroyed and await reconstruction.11Himalaya E UNESCO World Heritage Sites.https://www.explorehimalaya.com/nepal-information/unesco-world-heritage-sites/Date: 2018Date accessed: April 2, 2018Google Scholar In 2017, UNESCO cautioned against the government's current practice of reconstruction, particularly the practice of selecting the lowest bidder to take the contract even if they do not have proper specifications and craftsmanship, and stated that poor maintenance of these sites could be deadlier than earthquakes themselves.12UNESCOProtecting cultural heritage: lessons from the Gorkha Earthquake.https://en.unesco.org/news/protecting-cultural-heritage-lessons-gorkha-earthquakeDate: 2018Date accessed: April 2, 2018Google Scholar One of the cornerstones of planetary health is sustainability—ie, the ability to sustain our lives and civilization without putting a strain on countries' economies and ecosystems. Nepal's need for sustainable resources to drive the rebuilding process has only been recognised recently, but many donor-funded projects will end soon. The exhaustion of donor funding probably means that in later years Nepal will have to manage the postearthquake recovery process alone, and substantial local resources will need to be mobilised. Quoting a recent media report13Times THForeign aid commitment down nearly 30 percent.https://thehimalayantimes.com/business/foreign-aid-commitment-nearly-30-per-cent/Date: 2016Date accessed: April 2, 2018Google Scholar of a 30% drop in external assistance, we further highlight the need for an economic rebuilding process, such as through community engagement. Since the earthquakes, Nepal has already seen three governments, and political interference with NRA has grown out of proportion. The gaps in the regulatory mechanism and the lack of transparency of progress,14Lee AC Barriers to evidence-based disaster management in Nepal: a qualitative study.Public Health. 2016; 133: 99-106Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar which have left the Government of Nepal alone in rebuilding, can lead to another year of futility. The formation of a task force that combines the NRA, members of the donor agencies, and neutral observers (eg, UN or other independent international authorities) could become an operational tool. Such a task force could enhance the operational management for reconstruction by widely engaging with the stakeholders and the affected communities, the members of which need to be involved, trained, and given responsibilities.15Newnham E Patrick K Balsari S Leaning J Community engagement in disaster planning and response.https://cdn2.sph.harvard.edu/wp-content/uploads/sites/5/2015/11/Community-Preparedness-Policy-Brief-10.28.15.pdfDate: 2015Date accessed: April 1, 2018Google Scholar, 16Adhikari B Mishra SR Raut S Rebuilding Earthquake Struck Nepal through Community Engagement.Front Public Health. 2016; 4: 121Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar Stakeholders and community members with increased awareness of planetary health can themselves become the foundation of a sustainable and environmentally friendly rebuilding movement. We declare no competing interests.

title: Academic health policy debates for local climate change leadership
display_name: Academic health policy debates for local climate change leadership

author.au_affiliation_raw: School of Public Health and Community Medicine, University of New South Wales, Sydney, NSW, Australia
Department of Data Science, Prasanna School of Public Health, Manipal Academy of Higher Education, Manipal 576104, India

Manipal Academy of Higher Education Foundation for Advancement of International Medical Education and Research (MAHE-FAIMER) International Institute for Leadership in Interprofessional Education, Manipal Academy of Higher Education, Manipal 576104, India

ab: Adaptation to the health effects of climate change and mitigation of the associated health risks is a global health policy issue that requires local and regional cooperation along with adequate resource allocation. However, following the withdrawal of the USA from the Paris climate accord, a new model of global climate response needs to be enforced, considering the urgency of these health effects among the low-income and middle-income countries (LMICs) of the global south.1Watts N Adger WN Ayeb-Karlsson S et al.The Lancet Countdown: tracking progress on health and climate change.Lancet. 2017; 389: 1151-1164Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar Regional, national, and local actors need to be involved, thinking globally and acting locally. Although building capacity in local and regional policy leadership necessitates the involvement of educators, the multisectoral nature of the problem demands the use of learning approaches that are interprofessional and inquiry-based. Hence, we propose the use of academic, parliamentary-style health policy debates for building capacity in climate leadership among today's students—ie, the policy leaders of tomorrow. Many such debates in the past have mimicked the World Health Assembly and its global scope. However, simulations of regional and local diplomatic bodies allow for a focused deliberation and the voicing of relevant, evidence-informed arguments. In an example of a regionally focused health policy debate, an interprofessional group of students from both health and non-health professions participated in the Manipal Model WHO 2018 (at the Manipal Academy of Higher Education, Manipal, India), where they debated approaches for adapting to and mitigating against the health effects of climate change in the south Asian region.2The Hindu Students debate climate change, health at Manipal Model WHO.https://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Mangalore/students-debate-climate-change-health-at-manipal-model-who/article22758003.eceDate: Feb 16, 2018Google Scholar By receiving targeted instruction in health research literacy, parliamentary debate procedure, public speaking, and drafting policy documents, students showed key interprofessional and leadership skills to reach mutual consensus on the way forward. By building on existing generic WHO frameworks, they developed and voted on draft resolutions that presented region-specific policy plans to address local health effects. Similar health policy debates in education for health professionals have also been done in other LMICs, such as the Medical Model UN (ie, MedMUN 2014 and MedMUN 2015) in Malaysia involving only issue-appropriate nations.3Godinho MA Murthy S Ali Mohammed C Debating evidence-based health policy in an interprofessional classroom: an exploratory study.J Interprof Care. 2018; (published online Oct 31)DOI:10.1080/13561820.2018.1541873PubMed Google Scholar Likewise the National Health System 2017, a national health assembly simulation in Sudan,4Godinho MA Murthy S Ciraj AM Health policy for health professions students: building capacity for community advocacy in developing nations.Educ Health. 2017; 30: 254-255Crossref PubMed Scopus (3) Google Scholar debated domestic and regional issues specific to the region. These examples show that the local expertise for organising and conducting such debates is available in LMICs. Disseminated efforts and targeted interventions to mobilise this expertise can provide much needed opportunities for building local and regional policy leadership to address the health effects of climate change, specifically in LMICs. We declare no competing interests. The Lancet Countdown: tracking progress on health and climate changeThe Lancet Countdown: tracking progress on health and climate change is an international, multidisciplinary research collaboration between academic institutions and practitioners across the world. It follows on from the work of the 2015 Lancet Commission, which concluded that the response to climate change could be “the greatest global health opportunity of the 21st century”. The Lancet Countdown aims to track the health impacts of climate hazards; health resilience and adaptation; health co-benefits of climate change mitigation; economics and finance; and political and broader engagement. Full-Text PDF

title: Incorporating qualitative methodologies and fieldwork into large scale, quantitative analyses of climate health in low-income countries
display_name: Incorporating qualitative methodologies and fieldwork into large scale, quantitative analyses of climate health in low-income countries

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Geography, Environment & Society, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN, USA
University of Minnesota Health, Minneapolis, MN, USA

ab: Climate can affect individual health through a number of mechanisms, including changes in food access or availability, heat stress, and drought. Each of these mechanisms are mediated by decisions that individuals, households, and communities make, and so associations between climate change and health outcomes that do not account for these pathways can disguise true effects. In a recent study examining the link between climate variables and health in Mali and Kenya, authors found compelling evidence that precipitation, temperature, and vegetation all have an effect on birthweight.1Bakhtsiyarava M Grace K Nawrotzki RJ Climate, birth weight, and agricultural livelihoods in Kenya and Mali.Am J Public Health. 2018; 108: S144-S150Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar A similar study examined how the climatic characteristics of a region affected growth trajectories of children under five years of age, including potentially moderating variables like transportation and health infrastructure.2Shively GE Infrastructure mitigates the sensitivity of child growth to local agriculture and rainfall in Nepal and Uganda.Proc Natl Acad Sci USA. 2017; 114: 903-908Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar Both studies note that although rainfall during key periods is typically associated with positive growth trajectories, quantitative associations are heterogeneous across individuals. Moreover, the associations are not fully explained after controlling for variation due to land use, food availability, infrastructure, or individual-level or household-level characteristics. Climate-health researchers have attributed the unexplained variation to a range of factors, from the adoption of modern agricultural techniques, to transportation and health infrastructure, to nutrition and care practices. The pathways proposed in quantitative climate-health studies generally come from qualitative assessments of context made by the researchers, but the directionality of those pathways is not always clear.3Amegah AK Rezza G Jaakkola JJ Temperature-related morbidity and mortality in sub-Saharan Africa: a systematic review of the empirical evidence.Environ Int. 2016; 91: 133-149Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 4Phalkey RK Aranda-Jan C Marx S Höfle B Sauerborn R Systematic review of current efforts to quantify the impacts of climate change on undernutrition.Proc Natl Acad Sci USA. 2015; 112: e4522-e4529Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar For instance, studies focused on investigating the association between malnutrition and climate propose that the relationship between weather conditions and child health outcomes can be partially explained by the ways a caretaker's workload changes in response to weather. In theory, children are healthier when caretakers have adequate time to care for the children.5Hampshire KR Panter-Brick C Kilpatrick K Casiday RE Saving lives, preserving livelihoods: understanding risk, decision-making and child health in a food crisis.Soc Sci Med. 2009; 68: 758-765Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar In practice, increased rainfall could result in greater crop yields, but create more demand for a caretaker's labor, leaving children to eat less frequently.6Jones AD Cruz Agudo Y Galway L Bentley J Pinstrup-Andersen P Heavy agricultural workloads and low crop diversity are strong barriers to improving child feeding practices in the Bolivian Andes.Soc Sci Med. 2012; 75: 1673-1684Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar, 7Nankumbi J Muliira JK Barriers to infant and child-feeding practices: a qualitative study of primary caregivers in rural Uganda.J Health Popul Nutr. 2015; 33: 106-116PubMed Google Scholar Equally, dry conditions and high temperatures could result in more time on heatwave mitigation efforts and less time focused on childcare. It is also possible that extreme temperatures force individuals to spend more time indoors or close to home, resulting in more time left for caretaking. This example shows how individuals can have different responses to the same extreme weather conditions, resulting in varying health outcomes. Because responses to climate are highly contextual, quantitative analyses that do not explicitly model relevant aspects of the local context can produce misleading results. To advance climate-health research and associated policies, the research community should focus on identifying, isolating, and understanding the different ways that individuals respond to climate events. Strictly quantitative analyses have provided promising insights into climate-health linkages but are limited in their ability to capture experiences relevant to local contexts and cultures.8Nelson DM Who counts? The mathematics of death and life after genocide. Duke University Press, Durham, NC, USA2015Crossref Google Scholar To capture variability in these dynamics, attention must be paid to local norms surrounding the ways that people interact and spend their time. Local stakeholders (all individuals in an area, including those living in the communities of interest as well as local policymakers, health workers, and educators) manage complex risks in everyday practice, and using available resources and risk mitigation strategies can provide valuable insights into research. These local stakeholders can provide unique perspectives on a range of highly relevant behavioural responses, including those related to time management, food rationing, caretaking practices, and other strategies used to reduce the adverse effects of climate change. Accessing and chronicling this information allows researchers and policy makers to better determine the ways a household and community respond to aberrant climate events. Unfortunately, standard demographic and health surveys used for climate-health research rarely capture local norms surrounding the ways that people interact. To remedy this, we suggest augmenting climate-health research with qualitative methodologies and field work at every stage, to advance scientific and policy understanding of the effects of climate change on health. Three areas of qualitative research can be used to inform and augment research findings: context, perspectives, and policy. To promote contextual understanding, researchers could focus on a particular phenomenon or process of interest and find a systematic way to observe the way that a process unfolds. For example, Shively2Shively GE Infrastructure mitigates the sensitivity of child growth to local agriculture and rainfall in Nepal and Uganda.Proc Natl Acad Sci USA. 2017; 114: 903-908Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar found that rainfall at key developmental junctures affected growth trajectories in children under five years of age. Making specific policy recommendations based on these findings is difficult, but contextual studies might focus on how care practices are likely to be affected by rainfall at different ages, including how increases in rainfall may affect agricultural yields and demands for labour. Such studies of context involve techniques like ethnographies and broader-level ethnographic methods (including living in and engaging with communities, languages, and cultures), and start with the assumption that there are well-thought-out adaptive processes being implemented by members of the community. Context is not an attempt to understand everything about a country or culture, but rather an attempt to develop a culturally informed understanding of the object under study, including climate and food production, or climate and child care. Researchers observe the ways in which those processes unfold pre-intervention, asking questions of local informants, generally guided by or facilitated by local research associates. Data is generated via field notes kept by researchers. Although contextual studies might include talking with local stakeholders, studying perspectives would generally include interviews or focus group discussions. These interviews could then be used to provide additional information on the mechanisms, motivations, or cultural values underpinning an observation of interest. In the case of birth seasonality, for example, studies of perspectives could use focus group interviews to establish if women feel capable of choosing the time of year they become pregnant, or how important seasonal hunger patterns are in the choice to exclusively breast feed and in the duration of breastfeeding behaviour.9Grace K Considering climate in studies of fertility and reproductive health in poor countries.Nat Clim Chang. 2017; 7: 479-485Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar This method assumes that stakeholders make decisions and act in ways that reflect a strategic calculation of risks and benefits, and so the processes underpinning those calculations can be better understood by directly asking about their motivations and behaviours. Perspectives can be gained through conversations with various stakeholders and the list of questions can be rigid or flexible. In more exploratory cases it is generally best practice to use focus groups with a semi-structured protocol, because participants can discuss the topic together and come to a consensus. Flexible lists of questions allow researchers to ask about contradictions or rich points as they emerge.10Agar MH Ethnography: an overview.Subst Use Misuse. 1997; 32: 1155-1173Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar Interviews are often recorded and transcribed, and a qualitative researcher will use those written transcripts to look for themes that help provide insight into mechanisms, motivations, or values. Policy research can include a variety of tools, but is often based on conversations with policy makers or other officials entrusted with decision making and resource brokering. Interviews are useful in gaining insight into the history or justification of a policy or in understanding previous efforts to remedy a particular problem. Lists of questions can be rigid or flexible, and interviews are often transcribed and redacted to serve as data for later publication. Policy research can also be expanded to include archival research that consists of legal proceedings, newspapers, and other documents that might provide additional insight into the broader political context. Analysis of policy data looks similar to analysis of interview transcripts. Qualitative researchers might begin by looking at all instances of the word or phrase heatwaves or climate change in local media. Next, they might use those documents to identify elements of a pre-existing theory, or answer questions regarding public perceptions of heatwaves or climate change and how those have evolved over time. In conclusion, qualitative approaches can be used to design empirical studies that capture culturally informed perspectives by willingly participating stakeholders. Engagement with local stakeholders should begin in the very early stages of research design, and should be revisited throughout the duration of the study. Interactions with stakeholders can be systematic, scientific, and documented for the purposes of reliability and reproducibility, and importantly, should be published to facilitate access by the scientific community. Bringing everyday lived experiences of individuals into quantitative climate-change research can help ensure that science and policy reflects the strategies that local people are already using to protect their health, and addresses the concerns and challenges facing those who are most vulnerable. We declare no competing interests.

title: Addressing the complexity of prenatal and postnatal environmental exposures affecting childhood lung function
display_name: Addressing the complexity of prenatal and postnatal environmental exposures affecting childhood lung function

author.au_affiliation_raw: University Children's Hospital Basel (UKBB), 4056 Basel, Switzerland
Division of Respiratory Medicine, University Children's Hospital Zurich, Zurich, Switzerland

ab: Environmental pollution affects morbidity and mortality in children aged 0–5 years, not only in developed countries, but also in low-income and middle-income countries in particular.1 However, environmental exposures during this period of increased susceptibility in infants and children might have long-lasting effects that are often underestimated. Air pollution exposure during pregnancy is associated with reduced postnatal lung function,2 and several studies also show a sustained effect of prenatal air pollution exposure on lung function at age 5 weeks up to age 11 years.

title: A chance to implement One Health in the Middle East and north Africa
display_name: A chance to implement One Health in the Middle East and north Africa

author.au_affiliation_raw: Razi Vaccine and Serum Research Institute, Agricultural Research, Education and Extension Organization, Karaj, Iran
Razi Vaccine and Serum Research Institute, Agricultural Research, Education and Extension Organization, Karaj, Iran
author.institution_display_name: Razi Vaccine and Serum Research Institute

ab: Since 2016, November 3, has been One Health day, aimed at deepening comprehension of the holistic nature and necessity of a transdisciplinary approach to solving problems of global health.1One Health Day.https://www.onehealthcommission.org/en/events/one_health_day/Date accessed: March 20, 2019Google Scholar Over the 3 years in which One Health day has been celebrated internationally, the lowest number of educational and awareness-raising events were registered by participants from the Middle East and north Africa, with only two events in Turkey (2016 and 2018) and one in Qatar (2017).1One Health Day.https://www.onehealthcommission.org/en/events/one_health_day/Date accessed: March 20, 2019Google Scholar The term One Health was invented in 2003, to describe the interconnectedness of health of the ecosystem, animal, and human.2Khan MS Rothman-Ostrow P Spencer J et al.The growth and strategic functioning of One Health networks: a systematic analysis.Lancet Plan Health. 2018; 2: e264-e273Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar Today, with the financial and political backing of international organisations such as the World Organisation for Animal Health, Food and Agriculture Organization of the UN, WHO, UN, and World Bank, One Health is transforming from an interdisciplinary collaboration to global health governance. Other concepts, such as eco health, planetary health, future earth, and future health, although different all refer to a similar policy, encouraging different audiences to reach a global consensus on health.2Khan MS Rothman-Ostrow P Spencer J et al.The growth and strategic functioning of One Health networks: a systematic analysis.Lancet Plan Health. 2018; 2: e264-e273Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar Epidemic intelligence and the ability to identify an outbreak early can provide a crucial advantage in the eradication of infectious diseases, prompting response to prevent epidemics and the implementation of biological countermeasures.3Edelstein M Lee LM Herten-Crabb A Heymann DL Harper DR Strengthening global public health surveillance through data and benefit sharing.Emerg Infect Dis. 2018; 24: 1324Crossref Scopus (38) Google Scholar In 1851, when the World Health Assembly, WHO, and the International Health Regulations (IHR) were not yet established, after epidemics of cholera, plague, and yellow fever, the first International Sanitary Conference was held. 14 conferences and many years later, WHO was established.4Fidler DP From international sanitary conventions to global health security: the new International Health Regulations.Chin J Int Law. 2005; 4: 325-392Crossref Scopus (0) Google Scholar The aims of the International Sanitary Conference were legislation, enforcement of the reporting of the status of contagious diseases, and encouragement of international cooperation in controlling infectious diseases. The concerns of the 19th century are still concerns of today, giving rise to an urgent need to deal with these issues.4Fidler DP From international sanitary conventions to global health security: the new International Health Regulations.Chin J Int Law. 2005; 4: 325-392Crossref Scopus (0) Google Scholar Although the IHR came into effect in June, 2007, in practice, at that time there was little incentive to allow external investigation of a country's progress in dealing with epidemics. After the establishment of the Joint External Evaluation (JEE), political will increased and integrated logistical support for the Global Health Security was provided by national institutes and agencies, international organisations, and donors, resulting in more than 40 countries allowing external evaluation of their One Health infrastructure within 3 years.5Kandel N Sreedharan R Chungong S et al.Joint external evaluation process: bringing multiple sectors together for global health security.Lancet Glob Health. 2017; 5: e857-e858Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar The effects of the IHR JEE on the evaluation of One Health performance in the Middle East and north Africa, with the participation of 14 countries, revealed that more than 90% had an established surveillance system; however, only half had the capacity to monitor one to four zoonotic diseases. More than 80% of the countries had fundamental problems with the national stewardship plan for antimicrobial resistance.6Al Abaidani I Mohamednour SAS Addressing challenges in the Middle East at the human–animal interface under the 'One Health' concept. 14th Conference of the OIE Regional Commission for the Middle East; Istanbul, Turkey.http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Publications_%26_Documentation/docs/pdf/TT/2017_MO2_AlAbaidani.pdfDate: Oct 2–6, 2017Date accessed: March 20, 2019Google Scholar The effects of non-human epidemics are not limited to zoonotic diseases; the economic effect of mass depopulation and biodiversity loss ignites social inequity and unrest because of the complexity of social determinants of health. Additionally, financial instability will result from focusing solely on the human sector, at the cost of the animal kingdom and ecosystem. The political, economic, and societal consequences of epidemics of animal and zoonotic diseases (including, but not limited to, Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus, highly pathogenic avian influenza, and foot-and-mouth disease) in the Middle East and north Africa over the past decade indicates that it is time to direct more attention to the animal kingdom and the environment. The implementation of any policy and practice under the One Health and planetary health umbrellas will guarantee sustained success.2Khan MS Rothman-Ostrow P Spencer J et al.The growth and strategic functioning of One Health networks: a systematic analysis.Lancet Plan Health. 2018; 2: e264-e273Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar, 7Rushton J Bruce M Bellet C et al.Initiation of global burden of animal diseases programme.Lancet. 2018; 392: 538-540Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar If we look at the status of the countries of the Middle East and north Africa in controlling the outbreaks of animal and zoonotic diseases, as well as overcoming environmental challenges such as environmental damage, air pollution, drought and scarce fresh water, and a paucity of arable land, the most important initial step should be the establishment of a governing body to oversee an integrated One Health surveillance system for the early detection of threats at the animal–human–ecosystems interfaces.3Edelstein M Lee LM Herten-Crabb A Heymann DL Harper DR Strengthening global public health surveillance through data and benefit sharing.Emerg Infect Dis. 2018; 24: 1324Crossref Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 6Al Abaidani I Mohamednour SAS Addressing challenges in the Middle East at the human–animal interface under the 'One Health' concept. 14th Conference of the OIE Regional Commission for the Middle East; Istanbul, Turkey.http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Publications_%26_Documentation/docs/pdf/TT/2017_MO2_AlAbaidani.pdfDate: Oct 2–6, 2017Date accessed: March 20, 2019Google Scholar The challenges of the implementation of such a system should be carefully investigated. It might be that the experience of a public–private partnership such as the Middle East Consortium on Infectious Disease Surveillance (MECIDS) in a region, which has a history of decades of challenges, could be extended to other countries in the Middle East and north Africa.8Kimball AM Moore M French HM et al.Regional infectious disease surveillance networks and their potential to facilitate the implementation of the international health regulations.Med Clin North Am. 2008; 92: 1459-1471Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar, 9Stärk KD Kuribreña MA Dauphin G et al.One Health surveillance–more than a buzz word?.Prev Vet Med. 2015; 120: 124-130Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar The most serious challenge is developing the political will to support not just the establishment of an integrated surveillance system, but also intersectoral partnerships to help prevent and control diseases.3Edelstein M Lee LM Herten-Crabb A Heymann DL Harper DR Strengthening global public health surveillance through data and benefit sharing.Emerg Infect Dis. 2018; 24: 1324Crossref Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 5Kandel N Sreedharan R Chungong S et al.Joint external evaluation process: bringing multiple sectors together for global health security.Lancet Glob Health. 2017; 5: e857-e858Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar Considering decades of conflict, war, and unrest, the main question remains whether leaders in the Middle East and north Africa are willing to collaborate to implement the One Health surveillance system. The Seventh World Health Summit Regional Meeting to be held in Iran offers an exceptional opportunity to promote One Health and planetary health in the region. Topics such as health in uncertain situations, non-communicable diseases and mental health, global health in a transitional world, planetary health, and medical education are all emerging fields that stakeholders and decision makers from all around the globe can produce an operational plan for achieving their goals. Without a doubt, this will only be possible with the support of domestic policy makers and upstream policies. We declare no competing interests.
