title: Are we ready to establish a causal relationship between air pollution and pregnancy loss?
display_name: Are we ready to establish a causal relationship between air pollution and pregnancy loss?

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Public Health, School of Social Sciences, Humanities and Arts, University of California, Merced, CA 95343, USA
Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, Division of Intramural Population Health Research, Epidemiology Branch, Bethesda, MD, USA
author.institution_display_name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

ab: The incidence of pregnancy loss is about 28% in preconception cohorts,1Buck Louis GM Schisterman EF Sweeney AM et al.Designing prospective cohort studies for assessing reproductive and developmental toxicity during sensitive windows of human reproduction and development--the LIFE Study.Paediatr Perinat Epidemiol. 2011; 25: 413-424Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar and self-reported prevalence of pregnancy loss is increasing in the USA.2Rossen LM Ahrens KA Branum AM Trends in risk of pregnancy loss among US women, 1990–2011.Paediatr Perinat Epidemiol. 2018; 32: 19-29Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar The causes of most pregnancy losses are unclear, posing a major challenge for intervention efforts. Mounting evidence suggests that air pollution might affect embryonic and fetal development in both in vitro and population-based studies.3Legro RS Sauer MV Mottla GL et al.Effect of air quality on assisted human reproduction.Hum Reprod. 2010; 25: 1317-1324Crossref PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar, 4Munch EM Sparks AE Duran HE Van Voorhis BJ Lack of carbon air filtration impacts early embryo development.J Assist Reprod Genet. 2015; 32: 1009-1017Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar, 5Mendola P Ha S Pollack AZ et al.Chronic and acute ozone exposure in the week prior to delivery is associated with the risk of stillbirth.Int J Environ Res Public Health. 2017; 14: E731Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar, 6Ha S Liu D Zhu Y et al.Ambient temperature and stillbirth: a multi-center retrospective cohort study.Environ Health Perspect. 2017; 125: 067011Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar However, few studies have explored whether air pollution affects the risk of pregnancy loss, particularly in low-income areas of the world where the incidence is high. The scarcity of studies investigating the effects of air pollution on the risk of pregnancy loss is partly driven by the scarcity of available data coupled with the challenges associated with prospectively monitoring pregnancy loss and personal air monitoring. Existing studies often use retrospective data on known pregnancy or live births because of accessibility. This presents a crucial limitation because a considerable proportion of pregnancy losses occur early, even before entry into the health-care system. Thus, retrospective data cannot adequately capture early losses, leading to a missed opportunity to explore more upstream effects of air pollution. The second challenge involves assessment of air pollution. Personal exposures are commonly estimated using local stationary air monitors or mathematical models. Although feasible, these methods do not effectively capture small spatiotemporal variations in air pollution, especially because most women are mobile. These sources of measurement error are generally thought to be non-differential, adding random error that will bias study results towards the null. To better understand the causal relationship between air pollution and pregnancy loss, it is crucial to prospectively enroll participants before conception, use personal air monitors to measure air pollution, and implement detailed protocols with fertility and pregnancy testing. However, such studies would unquestionably be expensive and require high compliance from couples attempting to conceive, who might be difficult to identify and recruit. Alternatively, self-match case-control study designs have received attention because of their efficiency and ability to effectively control for time-invariant confounding. The study by Tao Xue and colleagues7Xue T Zhu T Geng G Zhang Q Association between pregnancy loss and ambient PM2·5 using survey data in Africa: a longitudinal case-control study, 1998–2016.Lancet Planetary Health. 2019; 3: e219-e225Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar is the first large study to examine the association between fine particles and pregnancy loss across 33 African countries. The authors took advantage of a large multicountry sample of 42 952 women with self-reported pregnancy losses (1998–2016), who also had a successful pregnancy before or after the index loss. Monthly area-level exposures to PM2·5 and its five major constituents were estimated using satellite remote sensing technology and the chemical transport models accounting for meteorological factors. For each pregnancy loss, the monthly average concentration of PM2·5 and its constituents during various windows of pregnancy was compared with the corresponding window of a successful pregnancy within the same mother. A 10 μg/m3 increment in PM2·5 over the full gestational length was associated with an increased risk in overall pregnancy loss (adjusted OR of 1·122; 95% CI 1·107–1·137), with similar results for miscarriage (1·125; 1·109–1·142) and stillbirth (1·094; 1·051–1·138). In pollutant-specific analyses, dust particles had the strongest effects on pregnancy loss risk. A major strength of this study is that its self-match nature adjusts for factors that do not change between the pregnancies (eg, genetics).8Maclure M The case-crossover design: a method for studying transient effects on the risk of acute events.Am J Epidemiol. 1991; 133: 144-153Crossref PubMed Scopus (1701) Google Scholar However, it is important to also note that factors that can change between pregnancies, which could be years apart, could have confounded the observed association (eg, lifestyle choices, stress, comorbidities, and seasonality) in addition to changes in maternal characteristics that might vary with age such as blood pressure, body-mass index, and chronic disease risk. Xue and colleagues7Xue T Zhu T Geng G Zhang Q Association between pregnancy loss and ambient PM2·5 using survey data in Africa: a longitudinal case-control study, 1998–2016.Lancet Planetary Health. 2019; 3: e219-e225Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar estimated exposure to air pollution using satellite remote sensing technology and the chemical transport model, which produces monthly outputs at a spatial resolution of 0·1° × 0·1° across Africa. This method is subject to misclassification because it cannot account for patterns in daily activities, residential mobility, or spatiotemporal variation less than 1 month and 0·1° × 0·1°. Nevertheless, given the scope of the study and the challenges related to personal monitoring, it provides a cost-effective opportunity to explore the effects of air pollution on fetal outcomes. Since pregnancy loss was self-reported, early losses were probably missed, especially those that occur early when women might not know they are pregnant. Furthermore, the exact date of loss was not known, leading to potential misclassification of the case and control periods. The authors have done several sensitivity analyses using different methods to select the control live-birth pregnancies and tested for potential effect modifiers. The overall findings were robust and at the same exposure level, women with increased maternal age or low socioeconomic status had higher risk. Given the growing complexity of environmental threats, future studies need to investigate susceptible subgroups and pollutant interactions. In summary, although large detailed preconception cohorts are still needed to establish a causal relationship between air pollution and pregnancy loss, the work by Xue and colleagues is an interesting and pragmatic approach to investigate the effects of air pollution on pregnancy loss in low-income and middle-income countries. We declare no competing interests. Association between pregnancy loss and ambient PM2·5 using survey data in Africa: a longitudinal case-control study, 1998–2016Our findings from African DHS data showing that PM2·5 exposure is significantly associated with increased risk of pregnancy loss add to the existing epidemiological evidence from middle-income and high-income countries on the health impacts of poor air quality. Our results support public health interventions for reducing ambient particulate matter to improve maternal health in Africa. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: The Paris agreement: charting a low-emissions path for a child born today
display_name: The Paris agreement: charting a low-emissions path for a child born today

author.au_affiliation_raw: University of Calgary Cumming School of Medicine, Yellowknife, NT X1A 2H7, Canada
Faculty of Epidemiology, Biostatistics, Occupational Health and Public Health, McGill University, Montreal, OC, Canada
Climate Equity Reference Project, Ottawa, ON, Canada

ab: 10 years have passed since The Lancet first stated that "Climate change is the biggest global health threat of the 21st century",1Costello A Abbas M Allen A et al.Managing the health effects of climate change: Lancet and University College London Institute for Global Health Commission.Lancet. 2009; 373: 1693-1733Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1620) Google Scholar and almost 5 years ago, the 2015 Lancet Commission on Health and Climate Change concluded that tackling this threat could be the greatest health opportunity of this time.2Watts N Adger WN Agnolucci P et al.Health and climate change: policy responses to protect public health.Lancet. 2015; 386: 1861-1914Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1017) Google Scholar Since then, initiatives such as the Planetary Health Clinicians' Initiative, fossil fuel divestment by health-related groups,3Watts N Amann M Arnell N et al.The 2019 report of The Lancet Countdown on health and climate change: ensuring that the health of a child born today is not defined by a changing climate.Lancet. 2019; 394: 1836-1878Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (639) Google Scholar and declarations of a climate emergency by health actors are evidence that the world's medics are mounting ever-greater responses to this existential threat. The year 2020 is a key point in human history: countries' first Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) were submitted before the Paris Agreement in 2015, and 2020 represents the last chance to enhance them before they take effect. For today's children to thrive, reduction commitments for greenhouse gas emission must be ambitious enough to set a course to keep the global temperature rise to 1·5°C–2·0°C,4Intergovernmental Panel on Climate ChangeGlobal Warming of 1·5°C—Summary for Policymakers.https://www.ipcc.ch/sr15/Date accessed: October 8, 2018Google Scholar in line with the Paris Agreement goals,3Watts N Amann M Arnell N et al.The 2019 report of The Lancet Countdown on health and climate change: ensuring that the health of a child born today is not defined by a changing climate.Lancet. 2019; 394: 1836-1878Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (639) Google Scholar and the policies to achieve these targets must have health and equity considerations woven throughout. Here, we aim to explain the essentials of the NDC process to the health community, and to identify key questions that they can ask of their governments immediately and throughout the year leading up to the UN Climate Change Conference 2020, COP26. In essence, NDCs lay out actions that countries commit to undertake to address climate change and represent one of the central mechanisms of the Paris Agreement. Countries set climate targets according to their individual circumstances and priorities. Of 184 NDCs analysed, only 121 (66%) include mentions of health, and these were generally insubstantial.5Wiley E Tcholakov Y Pétrin-Desrosiers C Al-Qodmani L Health in Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDCs). World Medical Association, France2019Google Scholar The 2019 Lancet Countdown on Health and Climate Change made starkly clear the two potential pathways possible for today's children.3Watts N Amann M Arnell N et al.The 2019 report of The Lancet Countdown on health and climate change: ensuring that the health of a child born today is not defined by a changing climate.Lancet. 2019; 394: 1836-1878Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (639) Google Scholar If the global community continues along its business-as-usual, high-emissions pathway, a child born today will experience a world 4°C warmer than the preindustrial average, with the potential for their health to be marred by undernutrition, increased vector-borne disease, wildfires, and heat-related effects on work, and for both their health and health systems to be affected by the difficult to quantify effects of migration, conflict, and a less-stable world.3Watts N Amann M Arnell N et al.The 2019 report of The Lancet Countdown on health and climate change: ensuring that the health of a child born today is not defined by a changing climate.Lancet. 2019; 394: 1836-1878Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (639) Google Scholar Alternatively, in a world embracing the Paris Agreement's ambition via rapid coal power phase-out, uptake of clean energy, electrification of transport, support for plant-rich diets, increased green space, and active commuting opportunities, a child born today will experience cleaner air, decreased chronic disease, strengthened social ties, and levels of warming in the latter part of the century likely to result in health and health system effects that are more manageable with adaptive measures compared with the high-emissions scenario.3Watts N Amann M Arnell N et al.The 2019 report of The Lancet Countdown on health and climate change: ensuring that the health of a child born today is not defined by a changing climate.Lancet. 2019; 394: 1836-1878Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (639) Google Scholar Climate-related effects are unevenly distributed both within and between populations, with people of lower socioeconomic status, women, children, the unborn, and Indigenous communities6Cunsolo A Ellis N Ecological grief as a mental health response to climate change-related loss.Nat Clim Change. 2018; 8: 275-281Crossref Scopus (317) Google Scholar disproportionately affected.7Walpole SC Rasanathan K Campbell-Lendrum D Natural and unnatural synergies: climate change policy and health equity.Bull World Health Organ. 2009; 87: 799-801Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar An explicitly equity-focused approach that protects human rights and supports the social fabric necessary for a functioning global society is required to enhance the health of all in an increasingly warm world.7Walpole SC Rasanathan K Campbell-Lendrum D Natural and unnatural synergies: climate change policy and health equity.Bull World Health Organ. 2009; 87: 799-801Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar Ambition and equity are inseparable topics when considering nations' fair shares of emissions reductions, and, generally, current high-income countries' NDCs are inadequate on both counts.8Robiou du Pont Y Meinshausen M Warming assessment of the bottom-up Paris Agreement emissions pledges.Nat Comm. 2019; 94810Crossref Scopus (69) Google Scholar, 9Holz C Kartha S Athanasiou T Fairly sharing 1.5: national fair shares of a 1·5°C-compliant global mitigation effort.Int Environ Agreements. 2018; 18: 117-134Crossref Scopus (70) Google Scholar, 10Kartha S Athanasiou T Caney S Cripps E Dooley K Dubash N et al.Cascading biases against poorer countries.Nat Clim Change. 2018; 8: 348-349Crossref Scopus (37) Google Scholar Developed countries command larger financial and technical resources to respond to climate change (their capacity) and have produced most of the emissions to date (their responsibility), while lower-income and middle-income countries (LMICs) have less responsibility, more severe effects, less capacity to adapt or mitigate, and are increasingly experiencing losses and damages for which adaptation is no longer possible. These consequences include slow-onset events such as desertification and sea-level rise, and so-called non-economic losses, including loss of life, degraded health, and losses induced by human mobility, loss or degradation of Indigenous territory, and reductions in biodiversity. Attention to emergency preparedness, disaster response, social supports, and issues of human displacement will be essential to address these challenges. The UN Environment Programme Emissions Gap Report shows that nations must triple the level of ambition of their first NDCs, and implement them to limit warming to 2·0°C. A fivefold increase is needed to limit warming to 1·5°C. To meet the Paris Agreement goals, all countries must move together and maximise mitigation, even in the face of costs associated with adaptation and loss and damage. Thus, for all countries to do their utmost and for developed countries to do their fair share, high-income countries have a dual obligation9Holz C Kartha S Athanasiou T Fairly sharing 1.5: national fair shares of a 1·5°C-compliant global mitigation effort.Int Environ Agreements. 2018; 18: 117-134Crossref Scopus (70) Google Scholar to decrease domestic emissions as fast as technologically and economically feasible, and commit to substantial international cooperation in terms of finance, technology transfer, and other elements to support mitigation in LMICs.9Holz C Kartha S Athanasiou T Fairly sharing 1.5: national fair shares of a 1·5°C-compliant global mitigation effort.Int Environ Agreements. 2018; 18: 117-134Crossref Scopus (70) Google Scholar Anything less means either increasing an inequitable burden on LMICs, missing the 1·5–2·0°C target, or both.9Holz C Kartha S Athanasiou T Fairly sharing 1.5: national fair shares of a 1·5°C-compliant global mitigation effort.Int Environ Agreements. 2018; 18: 117-134Crossref Scopus (70) Google Scholar The health sector can serve as a voice for equity worldwide and articulate to decision makers the human cost of failing to meet ambition and equity-related goals. Many no-regret mitigation interventions exist that improve health and decrease health-related costs, including coal phase-out,3Watts N Amann M Arnell N et al.The 2019 report of The Lancet Countdown on health and climate change: ensuring that the health of a child born today is not defined by a changing climate.Lancet. 2019; 394: 1836-1878Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (639) Google Scholar carbon taxation,2Watts N Adger WN Agnolucci P et al.Health and climate change: policy responses to protect public health.Lancet. 2015; 386: 1861-1914Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1017) Google Scholar elements of sustainable health care, and enhanced active transport infrastructure.2Watts N Adger WN Agnolucci P et al.Health and climate change: policy responses to protect public health.Lancet. 2015; 386: 1861-1914Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1017) Google Scholar These factors should be included in pathways to emissions reductions, with ambitious timelines designed to result in their adoption as soon as possible. Framing climate change in terms of health has been shown to generate hopeful emotions11Myers T Nisbet M Maibach E Leiserowitz A A public health frame arouses hopeful emotions about climate change.Clim Change. 2012; 113: 1105-1112Crossref Scopus (366) Google Scholar and nurses and doctors are some of society's most trusted messengers. Integrating health into NDCs might be the best way to create a narrative that unifies populations around a shared desire for a healthy response to climate change. Although climate change negotiations take place in international forums, decisions related to NDCs are made nationally. Global health workers must make clear that climate change is a health emergency and that ambitious NDCs are needed to map out an adequate treatment plan. Recognising that 2020 NDC updates are under development, national health sector actors—both clinicians and advocacy bodies—must focus energy on publicly communicating the catastrophic health risks for a child born today in a world continuing along its current high-emissions pathway. They must also communicate the opportunities for enhanced wellness and cost savings for health-care systems that are inherent in meeting the Paris Agreement goals. Health professionals with experience in climate-related health emergencies can contribute a humanitarian perspective via stories of patient and health-system effects.12Devine C Guevera M Biorklund B et al.The Lancet Countdown on Health and Climate Change. Policy brief on humanitarian impacts. Nov 2019. Lancet Countdown and Doctors Without Borders, London2019Google Scholar The health-sector must push for NDCs to be developed via an interministerial process. This push should include consultations with relevant sectors, the public, and public health, with a focus on ambition, equity, and the inclusion of policies that are mutually beneficial for health and climate. Initiatives like the NDC Partnership, which offers technical support for the development of NDCs, including from WHO, can be useful resources for governments. Between COP25 and COP26, continuous pressure must be applied by the health sector to ensure health is integrated into climate-related policy making across sectors, with a focus on creating an NDC roadmap for health. From a mitigation perspective, health economists can cost out co-benefits to health and wellbeing associated with various policy choices (eg, for a 2025 coal phase-out target vs a 2030 target) and ensure that these are incorporated into discussions. Additionally, the health costs of adaptation and the losses of life and damage to health-care systems associated with less ambitious mitigation should be factored into decision-making. Most importantly, the fact must be made clear that a healthy NDC is one that is enhanced to be in line with a nation's fair share of the global reductions necessary under the Paris Agreement to comprise both ambitious domestic emissions reduction and, in high-income countries, massive scale-ups in climate finance contributions. For example, via the Green Climate Fund or, under the right conditions, via global climate markets (article 6 of the Paris Agreement). Health organisations can also advocate for WHO, which currently has limited ability to receive funding from the Green Climate Fund, to become a full participant, in order for it be able to direct funds to health-focused programmes in LMICs. Finally, given the centrality of health to the wellbeing of a child born into today's changing climate, the global health sector should request that the presidency of COP26 make health a prominent focus of the gathering. NDCs are opportunities for nations to lay out roadmaps charting a course to a healthy, low-emissions pathway while maximising health and equity. COP25 and the interval between COP25 and COP26 are crucial time windows when the global community can influence the life trajectory of a child born today by considering health when updating NDCs in 2020. To facilitate, actors in the health sector should articulate national opportunities and risks related to different ambition scenarios and use their privileged voices to communicate those to decision makers and the public; contribute directly to the NDC review process and promote mechanisms to ensure links between ministries for years to come; and encourage public consultations in the process while bringing forth voices of their patients and those most affected. Populations will benefit from a health-centred, unifying conversation, and ministries of health and the environment should prepare for rich, ambitious dialogue. CoH is co-chair of the advocacy subcommittee of the WHO-Civil Society Working Group on Climate Change and Health and was employed by The Lancet Countdown on Health and Climate Change as a policy consultant in 2018 and 2019. YT and ChH declare no competing interests. A "super-year" for the environmentAs we enter a new year and decade, it is natural to reflect on past progress and goals for the future. It's not surprising then that 2020 is shaping up to be a critical year in establishing ambition for climate and biodiversity action. There is much optimism and anticipation that this year could be a turning point in our relationship with nature, leading to the notion of 2020 being a "super year" for the environment. But this will only happen through conscious effort, if we drift on as we are, it will be far from super for people or the planet. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: More than a diet
display_name: More than a diet
ab: In an Editorial published in The Lancet on Jan 16, 2019 was declared to be the year of nutrition. And indeed, this announcement was set to coincide with the launch of two Commissions investigating the links between food systems, human health, and the environment. The first, the EAT-Lancet Commission on healthy diets from sustainable food systems focused on identifying the challenges inherent to maintaining food systems that are both environmentally sustainable and beneficial for human health, whereas the second report, The Global Syndemic of Obesity, Undernutrition and Climate Change, was centred around human systems and their role in the interplay between climate, nutrition, and health.

title: Surging awareness
display_name: Surging awareness
ab: Environmental awareness has been steadily growing over recent decades, and although human activities remain far from sustainable, there has been something of an awakening in recent years so that the environment is seen as increasingly central to social and economic progress. Even if there is not yet any clear agreement on how to incorporate it.

title: Another piece of the puzzle: linking global environmental change, plant phenology, and health
display_name: Another piece of the puzzle: linking global environmental change, plant phenology, and health

author.au_affiliation_raw: Departments of Emergency Medicine, Environmental and Occupational Health Sciences, and Global Health, Schools of Medicine and Public Health, University of Washington, Seattle, WA 98105, USA. Electronic address: jjhess@uw.edu.

ab: Some scientific puzzles take many years to solve, despite a sense of what they will depict when fully assembled. There is now abundant evidence that long-term climate change is affecting plant phenology, advancing the date of spring phenological events like bud-set, leaf-out, and flowering, increasing total pollen counts, and delaying autumnal phase phenological events, particularly in temporal zones.1 Although it logically follows that changes in pollen season variables would be widely detectable as the climate changes, documentation of these expected findings—solution of this particular puzzle—has been challenging, until now.

title: Climate change and health: more research on adaptation is needed
display_name: Climate change and health: more research on adaptation is needed

author.au_affiliation_raw: General Practice Center, Nanhai Hospital, Southern Medical University, Foshan, China
Guangdong Provincial Institute of Public Health, Guangdong Provincial Center for Disease Control and Prevention, Guangzhou 511430, China
author.institution_display_name: Guangdong Provincial Center for Disease Control and Prevention

ab: Climate change is widely recognised as one of the biggest global threats of the 21st century. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has projected that global warming is likely to reach 1·5°C between 2030 and 2052 if climate change continues at the current rate.1The Intergrovernmental Panel on Climate ChangeSpecial Report. Global warming of 1·5°C.https://www.ipcc.ch/sr15/Date accessed: July 1, 2019Google Scholar Generally, climate change will exert adverse effects on human health. For example, many studies2Watts N Adger WN Ayeb-Karlsson S et al.The Lancet Countdown: tracking progress on health and climate change.Lancet. 2017; 389: 1151-1164Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (241) Google Scholar have found that heat-related mortality would increase in parallel with climate change. However, few studies have considered the effects of adaptation, which might lead to uncertainty in risk assessments of climate change. In The Lancet Planetary Health, Hicham Achebak and colleagues3Achebak H Devolder D Ballester J Trends in temperature-related age-specific and sex-specific mortality from cardiovascular diseases in Spain: a national time-series analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e297-e306Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar did a country-wide time-series analysis in mainland Spain and the Balearic Islands to assess trends in temperature-related cardiovascular disease mortality between 1980 and 2016. This is the first study to systematically investigate the health impact of the 1°C increase in annual temperature that has been observed in Spain since 1980. The authors found that the effects of warm and cold temperatures on cardiovascular disease mortality, as assessed by relative risk (RR) and attributable fraction, differed by sex and age group; the RR and attributable fraction of cardiovascular deaths due to warm and cold temperatures decreased over the 37-year time period for both sexes and all age groups. These reductions in RR and attributable fraction of temperature-related cardiovascular disease deaths might be associated with adaptive responses and more general factors, such as socioeconomic development, improved housing conditions, use of air conditioning, and health-care service development. A key message from this study was that the increased temperatures observed in Spain since 1980 occurred in parallel with substantial adaptations to both high and low temperatures. This finding highlights the importance of considering adaptation in health risk assessments of climate change.4Achebak H Devolder D Ballester J Heat-related mortality trends under recent climate warming in Spain: a 36-year observational study.PLoS Med. 2018; 15e1002617Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar Human susceptibility to high temperatures and heatwaves has substantially declined in the past five decades.5Petkova EP Gasparrini A Kinney PL Heat and mortality in New York city since the beginning of the 20th century.Epidemiology. 2014; 25: 554-560Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar However, the temporal health effects of cold temperatures remain uncertain. For example, a multi-country analysis6Vicedocabrera AM Sera F Guo Y et al.A multi-country analysis on potential adaptive mechanisms to cold and heat in a changing climate.Environ Int. 2018; 111: 239-246Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar showed either an increase, a decrease, or a stable trend in the effects of cold temperatures across countries. We hypothesize that if improvements in socioeconomic development and structural transformations contributed to the decline in heat-related mortality, a similar reduction in cold-related mortality would be expected. Consistent with this hypothesis, Achebak and colleagues reported that the effects of cold temperatures on mortality significantly declined between 1980 and 2016 in Spain. These findings suggest that long-term changes in cold-attributable mortality are dependent on location and the magnitude of changes in temperature. Although many studies have assessed the risk of heat-attributable mortality in the context of global warming, several studies7Gasparrini A Guo Y Hashizume M et al.Mortality risk attributable to high and low ambient temperature: a multicountry observational study.Lancet. 2015; 386: 369-375Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar have reported that cold temperatures were responsible for most temperature-related deaths. Therefore, when considering the effects of adaptation in the health risk assessment of climate change, it is also necessary to comprehensively consider the effects of both warm and cold temperatures and estimate the net effects of temperature changes; this approach could directly indicate the extent to which an expected increase in heat-related mortality could be offset by the decrease in mortality due to cold temperatures and adaptation in different climate change scenarios.8Gasparrini A Guo Y Sera F et al.Projections of temperature-related excess mortality under climate change scenarios.Lancet Planet Health. 2017; 1: e360-e367Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (354) Google Scholar Global warming has gained much interest in the health risk assessments associated with climate change, but many knowledge gaps remain. For example, few novel technical approaches and frameworks exist that integrate the effects of adaptation in the risk assessment of climate change. On the basis of their present study, Achebak and colleagues could develop an approach that integrates the associations between temperature and mortality into the risk assessment of climate change, to further estimate the net effects of temperature and adaptation on mortality in Spain. Additionally, causal pathways and physiological acclimatisation might differ with exposure to warm temperatures compared with cold temperatures, and vary among regions.9Arbuthnott K Hajat S Heaviside C Vardoulakis S Changes in population susceptibility to heat and cold over time: assessing adaptation to climate change.Environ Health. 2016; 15: 33Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar Multicentre studies are needed to identify the factors that modify the effects of temperature and temporal variation in mortality, and understand the mechanisms of temporal changes that are associated with human susceptibility to warm and cold temperatures. Although many previous studies have studied mortality as a health outcome of climate change, a 2019 study10Liu T Ren Z Zhang Y et al.Modification effects of population expansion, ageing, and adaptation on heat-related mortality risks under different climate change scenarios in Gangzhou, China.Int J Environ Res Public Health. 2019; 16: 376Crossref Scopus (17) Google Scholar has suggested that years of life lost is the most appropriate measure to summarise the associations between temperature and mortality because it indicates the extent to which lives are shortened by exposure to non-optimum temperature ranges.10Liu T Ren Z Zhang Y et al.Modification effects of population expansion, ageing, and adaptation on heat-related mortality risks under different climate change scenarios in Gangzhou, China.Int J Environ Res Public Health. 2019; 16: 376Crossref Scopus (17) Google Scholar Hence, the use of years of life lost is recommended for the estimation of the burden of diseases resulting from climate change. The study by Achebak and colleagues provides valuable information for policy makers and researchers for the development of strategies that enable adaption to the adverse health impacts of climate change. However, the study only included Spain. Studies that include more countries and time-series data for longer time periods are needed to further investigate the temporal trends in temperature-related mortality, especially regarding the effects of cold temperatures on mortality. We declare no competing interests. Trends in temperature-related age-specific and sex-specific mortality from cardiovascular diseases in Spain: a national time-series analysisIn Spain, the observed warming of the climate has occurred in parallel with substantial adaptation to both high and low temperatures. The reduction in the RR and the attributable fraction associated with heat would be compatible with an adaptive response specifically addressing the negative consequences of climate change. Nevertheless, the simultaneous reduction in the RR and attributable fraction of cold temperatures also highlights the importance of more general factors such as socioeconomic development, increased life expectancy and quality, and improved health-care services in the country. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: The march of climate policy
display_name: The march of climate policy
ab: Are the gilets jaunes protests in France an inevitable response to ambitious climate policy? With governments across the world declaring “climate emergencies”, climate policies have shot up the political agenda in many nations. Addressing the climate crisis requires governments to implement big, bold, policies to enact fundamental and rapid changes in national carbon usage but attempts so far have proved largely unpopular. This is perhaps best illustrated in France, where the “gilets jaunes”, or “yellow vests”, took to the streets to protest what they saw as the unjust increase in a fuel tax in the name of addressing climate change. Why implement policies that damage the wealth and health of the nation's poorest, they argue, when there are more polluting targets to go after? Failing to address climate change has well-established negative implications for human health. But climate policies that disproportionately affect society's poorest can also have significant negative impacts on health and wellbeing. In France, the gilets jaunes made this point felt in the strongest terms, with hundreds of thousands of citizens taking to the streets over the course of the last 7 months to protest. The marches continue, but reached their height in November and December, 2018, with three major national protests or “Acts”. As Davide Natalini, a Research Fellow at the Global Sustainability Institute at Anglia Ruskin University explains: “If a policy like this is known to affect the poorest parts of the population most, and these are the people who spend most of their income on commodities like fuel to heat their homes, then that means they have much less to spend in taking care of themselves like buying nutritious food, and having access to good healthcare.” At first, Macron was dismissive of the protests, saying the “people complaining about rising fuel prices are the same ones who complain about pollution and how their children suffer”. The gilets jaunes were regularly referenced in the media as a symbol of what happens when governments actually try to implement policies necessary to address the climate crisis. As Natalini has previously argued, France is the “only example we know of”, that has seen riots over a government policy that raises the price of high-carbon fuels in the name of mitigating climate change. But it probably won't be the last, Natalini says, as governments have to implement sometimes harsh policies to address the climate crisis. And the protests can quickly escalate, he explains: “These protests seemed to turn into a struggle between the working class and what they call the establishment. Something that is above, that they don't feel that they control, that they feel they are neglected by and excluded by.” As the protests rolled on, the President was forced to climb down, admitting that climate policies needed to be designed in a more inclusive, more just, way. Not least because many gilets jaunes support climate action, just not at the expense of many already disenfranchised members of society. The gilets jaunes argued that there are many ways the climate crisis can be addressed in a more equitable fashion. Policymakers have spent decades trying to make these options work effectively, but so far the impact on global emissions has been limited. That also hurts societies' poorest, as Kathryn Harrison, a professor of political science and the University of British Columbia explains: “The consequences of any poorly designed policy of any sort that hurts the poor can have consequences for public health,” she says. “But the contribution of climate policy is often exaggerated. We also know that if we don't address climate change, it will be the poorest that are hurt the most.” So there's an economic, environmental, and moral imperative to get buy-in to effective climate policies, she argues. Perhaps the best-known version of a policy that goes after big polluters rather than people is emissions trading. Under such schemes, companies need permits for each tonne of carbon dioxide they emit. If they emit less than the permits they hold, they can sell the excess credits to companies that emit more; thus creating a carbon market. The EU's emissions trading scheme (ETS) was launched in 2005. But early mistakes in its design—such as giving away the permits for free at the outset, rather than auctioning them—meant it was largely ineffective. Decades of tweaks and reforms now mean it functions with a carbon price liable to make some impact on companies' activities. But the EU's biggest carbon-saving driver to date remains the financial crash of 2008, due to the impact it had on manufacturing across the continent. China is planning on implementing a national emissions trading scheme in 2020, 7 years after it established pilot schemes in seven regions. There are also some regional schemes in North America, but on the whole policy makers in the US prefer a different approach. Most recently, momentum has been gathering behind a so-called Green New Deal—a grand idea with few policy specifics thus far. But for years, there has been some support for “fee and dividend” system, largely thanks to the support of renowned NASA scientist James Hansen. Under the scheme, a fee is levied on highly polluting products such as fossil fuels, and a dividend is then paid to every citizen. The idea is that it makes high-carbon products expensive and economically unattractive, while also giving everyone some economic benefit, keeping public opinion on-side and ensuring the poorest are not unduly harmed. An influential group of Republican former Secretaries of State and business leaders are supportive of the idea. They say the plan could “strengthen our economy, reduce regulation, help working-class Americans, shrink government and promote national security”. Despite being first officially proposed in 2009, however, it remains a legislative pipe-dream in a political arena in which climate policy is proving an increasingly polarising force. A simpler option is a flat carbon tax levied on high-carbon companies, set by the government, and reviewed periodically in line with the latest science and economics. The revenue from that tax could then be spent on bolstering state-provided health care, transport infrastructure, or other policies that could help society's poorest. It could also be spent on other climate mitigation or adaptation strategies, though most economists say this shouldn't be the predetermined aim. There is, of course, one major problem with the policy: “People don't like to be taxed”, Harrison points out. Governments have tried to call it other things, “a fee, levy, price, et cetera”, she says, “but then opponents just accuse the government of trying to hide something.” In Ireland, the government is trying to implement a combination of the carbon tax and dividend plans. And in Canada, an Ontario court just ruled that the carbon tax couldn't constitutionally be considered a tax as ultimately it's not for spending, it's “giving people all the money back”, Harrison says. And that's the best way to get people to buy in to such policies, she argues: “it's not about punishment, it's about incentives”. What the gilets jaunes protests made clear to all policymakers was that whatever option they choose, it must be fair to all in society. Without it, there will remain staunch opposition and the risk of conflating climate policy with blue collar job losses. A highly visible example of this occurred at last year's annual UN climate talks, in the old coal town of Katowice in Poland. At the meeting, the Polish trade union Solidarity put out a joint statement with a number of groups known for their climate scepticism arguing that: “The negative impacts of expensive energy on human health and welfare are manifest and devastating. Affordable energy is absolutely necessary to lift people out of poverty and secure a brighter future for the people of the world.” By “affordable energy”, they meant fossil fuels. The statement showed the deep faith that some representatives of blue-collar workers retain in the fossil fuel industry's ability to deliver jobs, despite evidence that emissions are rapidly decoupling from income. There are promising signs that global policymakers are engaging with the notion that any transition away from fossil fuels must be equitable, however. At the same meeting, the concept of a “just transition”—the idea that climate policies must be coupled with measures to provide those hit by the policies with new jobs and a new future—got top billing. Thanks to the gilets jaunes, the message that the climate crisis must be addressed, but in an equitable way, is now loud and clear.

title: Biodiversity, land use change, and human health in northeastern Madagascar: an interdisciplinary study
display_name: Biodiversity, land use change, and human health in northeastern Madagascar: an interdisciplinary study

author.au_affiliation_raw: Duke Global Health Institute, Duke University, Durham, NC, USA
Department of Evolutionary Anthropology, Duke University, Durham, NC, USA
Duke Global Health Institute, Duke University, Durham, NC, USA
Department of Sociology, Duke University, Durham, NC, USA
Department of Sociology, Duke University, Durham, NC, USA
Duke Global Health Institute, Duke University, Durham, NC, USA
Department of Biology, University of Antananarivo, Antananarivo, Madagascar
Department of Evolutionary Anthropology, Duke University, Durham, NC, USA
Department of Biology, University of La Réunion, Saint-Denis, Réunion, France
author.institution_display_name: Observatoire des Sciences de l'Univers de la Réunion
author.institution_lineage: https://openalex.org/I1294671590, https://openalex.org/I24715933, https://openalex.org/I2802818602, https://openalex.org/I4210090127, https://openalex.org/I4210113730, https://openalex.org/I4210131494, https://openalex.org/I4210148025, https://openalex.org/I4210164187, https://openalex.org/I4210166444

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Evolutionary Anthropology, Duke University, Durham, NC, USA

ab: BackgroundGiven rapid land use changes and climate change underway in many low-income and middle-income countries, it is vitally important to understand how ecosystem changes influence biodiversity and human health, and to identify actions that can improve conservation, while also improving human health. We are investigating how human activities alter ecological communities and influence infectious disease risk near Marojejy National Park in northeastern Madagascar. We are coupling (i) cutting-edge social science methods to investigate the drivers of human land-use decision-making, and (ii) ecological analyses to investigate how these land use decisions impact zoonotic infectious disease transmission in small mammals, domesticated animals, and humans.MethodsThe study team conducted preliminary fieldwork in one village in 2017 and 2018 including household surveys, social network surveys and trapping of small mammals to screen for parasites and pathogens. We constructed a social network of 500 people to investigate disease risk patterns based on agricultural co-working relationships. In addition, the team captured 552 small mammals and found variation in abundance and diversity across a gradient of human land use.FindingsResults show that illness is frequent within community households, with a high prevalence of fevers over the previous 3 months (40%). Non-native species have higher relative and total abundance in agricultural fields, with highest relative abundance of introduced species in the unsustainable rice farming setting. Prevalence of Leptospira, a pathogenic bacterium transmitted through urine and contaminated water, was over four times higher in paddy rice fields than in forests or hillside slash-and-burn fields.InterpretationOur findings are consistent with the hypothesis that changes in land use and biodiversity can influence animal health, which may in turn affect disease risk for humans. We are now expanding ecological and household data collection to additional villages, as well as developing choice experiments to better understand farmer decision making about sustainable agricultural practices.FundingDuke University Bass Connections programme for interdisciplinary research.

title: Building resilience through family planning and climate adaptation finance: systematic review and opportunity analysis
display_name: Building resilience through family planning and climate adaptation finance: systematic review and opportunity analysis

author.au_affiliation_raw: People, Health, Planet: Population Reference Bureau, Washington, DC, USA
KAM Consulting, Washington, DC, USA
Ecological Christian Organization, Kampala, Uganda
Reproductive Health Uganda, Kampala, Uganda

ab: BackgroundClimate change adaptation is on the forefront of the global agenda, and momentum for international financing for climate change adaptation projects is growing. This growth provides an opportunity to engage with adaptation decision makers and processes to include women's empowerment as part of multisectoral climate adaptation projects.MethodsA growing evidence base links women's met needs for family planning with reduced human vulnerability to climate change and enhanced resilience in the face of climate change impacts. Yet, population and family planning have been largely left out of adaptation proposals and projects. Through key informant interviews, a literature review, and research, the Population Reference Bureau identified how to promote the inclusion of family planning in climate adaptation strategies in ways that build resilience, improve health, and enhance women's economic empowerment.FindingsWays to integrate family planning into climate adaptation strategies included drawing the connections to and building the evidence base for including family planning in multisectoral adaptation approaches; reaching out to a country's designated authority to identify main climate change adaptation decision makers and develop an understanding of how adaptation finance flows; engaging in a country's National Adaptation Plan process to connect with stakeholders and identify country-driven adaptation priorities; and considering partnering with others in developing multisectoral proposals that include family planning and help to implement those proposals.InterpretationThe best opportunity for funding family planning and reproductive health within adaptation projects is to integrate women's empowerment—including family planning—within multisectoral proposals. The research includes an example of how to apply these key strategies, showing how the women's empowerment community could seize opportunities created by the importance of adapting to climate change and the growing availability of international climate financing to strengthen prospects for including women's health in climate adaptation projects. The Ecological Christian Organization of Uganda and Reproductive Health Uganda are following the Population Reference Bureau's research with a country-level strategy to advocate for the adoption of a multisectoral approach to climate adaptation in Uganda.FundingUnited States Agency for International Development (USAID).

display_name: Violence and mortality in Rohingya migrants from the Northern Rakhine State, Myanmar

author.au_affiliation_raw: Institute for Global Health, University College London, London WC1N 1EH, UK
London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, London, UK
author.institution_display_name: London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine

author.au_affiliation_raw: Institute for Global Health, University College London, London WC1N 1EH, UK

ab: The plight of the Rohingya people represents one of the key humanitarian issues of our time. This population, the largest stateless group in the world, has been persecuted within Myanmar, with many fleeing across the border to Bangladesh and to other countries.1 The study by Parveen Parmar and colleagues2 is particularly prescient given that Bangladesh has planned to stop accepting Rohingya migrants.3 Numerous eye-witness and case reports have emerged describing the degree of violence faced by the Rohingya, yet accurate estimates of overall mortality are largely missing.

title: The global issue of foreign waste
display_name: The global issue of foreign waste

author.au_affiliation_raw: Ecological Society of Shandong, Shandong Institute of Environmental Science, Jinan 250012, China
School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Shandong University, Jinan, China

ab: China is the largest global importer of foreign refuse waste. The categories of waste imported include electronic waste, unsorted paper, plastics, and textiles. Thousands of manual workshop-like enterprises dispose of these wastes in a crude manner (eg, from acid-stripping or open burning of electronic components and wires for metal retrieval). Sometimes, these wastes are dumped into water or directly on to soil. This practice has left the country with serious problems of air, water, and soil pollution,1Wong MH Wu SC Deng WJ et al.Export of toxic chemicals—a review of the case of uncontrolled electronic-waste recycling.Environ Pollut. 2007; 149: 131-140Crossref PubMed Scopus (647) Google Scholar and even poor neonatal health.2Qiu SS Huo X Liu JX et al.Association between prenatal lead and cadmium exposure from electronic waste recycling and the development of neonate.Journal of Shantou University Medical College. 2012; 25: 138-140Google Scholar Large amounts of persistent toxic substances, such as dioxin-like compounds, heavy metals, and brominated flame retardants, have been released into the environment during the waste dismantling processes, which have negative effects on the environment and human health. According to several studies in China, the levels of polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dixoxin and dibenzofurans, polybrominated dibenzo-p-dioxins and dibenzofurans, in the environment around an electronic waste dismantling area in the studies exceeded various national and international limits. The total exposure dose to dioxins for adults, children, and breast-fed infants in China exceeded the tolerable daily intake recommended by WHO.3Chan JKY Wong MH A review of environmental fate, body burdens, and human health risk assessment of PCDD/Fs at two typical electronic waste recycling sites in China.Sci Total Environ. 2013; 463–64: 1111-1123Crossref Scopus (97) Google Scholar The residents had a high incidence of skin damage, headaches, vertigo, nausea, and digestive ulcers.4Qiu B, Peng L, Xu X, Lin X, Hong J, Huo X. Medical investigation of e-waste demanufacturing industry in Guiyu town. Proceedings of the International Conference on Electronic Waste and Extended Producer Responsibility; Beijing, China: April 21–22, 2004; 79–83.Google Scholar To deal with this situation, China banned the imports of foreign garbage at the end of 2017. 1 year later, it has been shown that this was the right decision as the annual import of solid waste decreased by 46·5% in 2018.5Li GJ The speech of the minister of Ecology and Environment of China (MEE China) in 2019 national work conference of ecological and environmental protection [In Chinese].http://www.mee.gov.cn/xxgk2018/xxgk/xxgk15/201901/t20190127_691113.htmlDate accessed: January 27, 2019Google Scholar This decision supported by many people in China, although some feel differently. For example, some people are worried that the rising prices of raw materials will affect paper mills, and waste exporters in developed countries are concerned about where their rubbish will go. This ban means that thousands of garbage enterprises in China would be shut down and even more workers would lose their jobs, thus damaging the local economy. That is the price China has to pay. From a global perspective and according to the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and their Disposal, such enterprises are only the bottom link in the global chain of waste export and import disposal. What is the role and function of the waste exporter in this situation? They earn huge sums of money by selling rubbish to importers without any concern to whether these wastes are disposed of properly and legally. Sometimes, they receive substantial waste disposal allowances from their own governments, although they do not do anything except selling this waste. The largest importer country has taken responsible steps, and it is time for exporters and importers to work together to tackle the global issue of foreign refuse, and improve the level of public health. If not, this global issue will persist, and the only change will be the affected country and its residents. Yesterday it was China, tomorrow it could be another country. We declare no competing interests.

title: Mortality risk within counterfactual models: Puerto Rico and Hurricane Maria – Authors' reply
display_name: Mortality risk within counterfactual models: Puerto Rico and Hurricane Maria – Authors' reply

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Global Health, Milken Institute School of Public Health, The George Washington University, Washington DC 20052, USA
Department of Global Health, Milken Institute School of Public Health, The George Washington University, Washington DC 20052, USA
Department of Biostatistics and Epidemiology, Graduate School of Public Health, University of Puerto Rico, San Juan, PR, USA
Department of Biostatistics and Epidemiology, Graduate School of Public Health, University of Puerto Rico, San Juan, PR, USA
Department of Environmental Health, Milken Institute School of Public Health, The George Washington University, Washington DC 20052, USA

ab: The main argument by Jeffrey Howard and Alexis Santos-Lozada appears to be that because the predicted number of deaths from the displacement model in our analysis was lower than historical averages and previous counterfactual estimates for the period after Hurricane Maria, this estimate, and estimates of excess mortality associated with them therefore must be biased or inaccurate in some way. The opposite is in fact the case. It is estimates of excess mortality that ignore displacement that are biased. Mortality rates are defined as the number of deaths divided by the population at risk of dying over a particular period. Estimated deaths under the displacement scenario are less than historical ranges because massive out-migration reduced (by approximately 8%) the population at risk of dying on the island. For a constant mortality rate, a smaller number at risk will result in a smaller number of estimated deaths. All other estimates cited by Howard and Santos-Lozada, including their own, overestimate predicted (and underestimate excess) mortality in the current context simply because they do not take displacement into account. Their second critique is that we ignore selectivity associated with the risk of mortality between people who left the island and those who did not. The citation they offer in support of their assertion that “those who remain behind have characteristics associated with higher mortality risk” says nothing about mortality, though it does suggest selectivity in evacuation from New Orleans before Hurricane Katrina by race and education. Our estimates (and the census and displacement offsets) are conditioned on age, sex, socioeconomic status of municipality of residence, and interactions between them. These are major factors stratifying the risk of mortality, and probably, selectivity in migration after Maria. To the extent that both the risks of mortality and displacement are associated with these factors, this is accounted for in our estimates. Given the absence of any additional individual level information in the registration data, our multivariate analysis accounted for factors related to selective out-migration to the fullest extent possible. Lastly, the authors raise a seeming paradox. As they acknowledge, the only difference in the estimation of predicted deaths between our census and displacement models is the population at risk in each (by design, the counterfactual rates are the same). Why then, does there seem to be a higher mortality rate among the displaced in their simple tabular analysis? The answer is straightforward. They calculate mortality rates for each scenario from the size of the population at risk at the end of the period (February, 2018) and cumulative predicted deaths for the entire period (September, 2017, to February, 2018). This calculation ignores monthly variation both in displacement and mortality, which our analysis takes into account. Displacement cumulates over the period, with 46% of total person-months at risk lost over the entire period happening in December and January as seen in table 4 in our Article.1Santos-Burgoa C Sandberg J Suárez E et al.Differential and persistent risk of excess mortality from Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico: a time-series analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: 478-488Summary Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (101) Google Scholar This period is exactly when seasonal mortality in Puerto Rico peaks. In combination, this differential loss means that the displaced were disproportionately removed from the population at risk during the period of highest mortality. Considered over the entire period, their mortality rate would have been higher had they not left, simply because they left when mortality rates were highest, not because our model attributes them disproportionately higher mortality for some other reason, as Howard and Santos-Lozada seem to suggest. The goal of estimating excess mortality is to draw inferences about the number of deaths caused by an event. Though we estimated excess mortality both with and without displacement, we presented the displacement estimates to the Government of Puerto Rico as preferred because they capture deaths attributable to differences in mortality rates after the storm, accounting for the smaller population at risk due to displacement. We believe this yields a more accurate estimate of the number of deaths caused by the storm than does assuming (as in our census scenario, Howard and Santos-Lozada's own estimates, and the others they cite) that those displaced were still in Puerto Rico after the storm and at risk of mortality from the continuing hardships associated with its aftermath. We declare no competing interests. Mortality risk within counterfactual models: Puerto Rico and Hurricane MariaUsing data from the Puerto Rico Vital Statistics System obtained from the materials provided by Carlos Santos-Burgoa and colleagues,1 we compared the census-based and displacement models with death counts for Puerto Rico for the period after Hurricane Maria. We calculated confidence intervals for deaths from 2010 to 2016 for observed deaths (figure) and compared them with the pre-Hurricane and post-Hurricane counts (2017) and both counterfactual models. The displacement model falls outside of the pattern observed over the past 7 years before Hurricane Maria, while mortality between January and August does not (figure). Full-Text PDF Open AccessDifferential and persistent risk of excess mortality from Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico: a time-series analysisAnalysis of all-cause mortality with vital registration data allows for unbiased estimation of the impact of disasters associated with natural hazards and is useful for public health surveillance. It does not depend on certified cause of death, the basis for the official death toll in Puerto Rico. Although all sectors of Puerto Rican society were affected, recovery varied by municipal socioeconomic development and age groups. This finding calls for equitable disaster preparedness and response to protect vulnerable populations in disasters. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Introducing One Health to medical and veterinary students
display_name: Introducing One Health to medical and veterinary students

author.au_affiliation_raw: Melbourne Medical School, University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC 3010, Australia
Melbourne Veterinary School, University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC 3010, Australia

ab: We read with interest the Comment by Maria De Giusti and colleagues,1De Giusti M Barbato D Lia L et al.Collaboration between human and veterinary medicine as a tool to solve public health problems.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e64-e65Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar in which they highlight the benefits of using a One Health approach in human and veterinary medicine. As the authors aptly describe, human and veterinary medicine share common issues and challenges, such as zoonotic diseases and antimicrobial resistance. An interdisciplinary approach might be effective in overcoming the challenges common to both human and animal health. However, despite the attempts of various organisations and governments to foster interdisciplinary collaboration, there is still little cooperation between the two disciplines. The American Medical Association and American Veterinary Medical Association endorsed the concept of One Health in 2008,2King LJ Anderson LR Blackmore CG et al.Executive summary of the AVMA One Health Initiative Task Force report.J Am Vet Med Assoc. 2008; 233: 259-261Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar and pledged to improve communication between the two professions. A decade on and still little progress has been made. We propose that new strategies are required for the One Health initiative to gain traction. We suggest that one such strategy to improve communication between human and veterinary medicine is to begin with students. Introducing interdisciplinary group projects into the curricula of medical and veterinary schools would foster teamwork and early networking between veterinary and medical students. Similar projects are already being implemented in the USA. The Zoobiquity Research Initiative pairs veterinary students from the University of California Davis with medical students from the University of California Los Angeles to work collaboratively on projects affecting animal and human health.3Horowitz BN Bowers K Zoobiquity: what animals can teach us about being human. Random House, New York2012Google Scholar Encouragingly, Edwards and colleagues4Edwards JC Walsum Kv Sanders CW et al.Attitudes of veterinary medical students and medical students toward collaborative learning: an experiment.J Vet Med Educ. 2004; 31: 77-79Crossref Google Scholar reported that medical student attitudes towards collaborative learning were more positive after an interdisciplinary surgical skills session with veterinary students. Further studies trialing collaborative learning would provide insight into the feasibility and potential benefits of such a programme. Projects exploring the similarities and differences between the pathogenesis and treatment of common diseases affecting both animals and humans, such as cancer or heart disease, would help medical and veterinary students appreciate the clinical challenges shared by both fields. These learning exercises would provide medical and veterinary students with the opportunity to consider how a collaborative approach might benefit their future patients. Although we acknowledge that this strategy might be logistically challenging, it would certainly be possible in institutions with both a medical and veterinary medicine faculty. The current lack of collaboration between doctors and veterinarians represents a missed opportunity to benefit from interdisciplinary research and clinical practice. To seize this missed opportunity, we propose that medical and veterinary schools should consider incorporating the One Health Initiative into their curricula. We declare no competing interests. Collaboration between human and veterinary medicine as a tool to solve public health problemsThe implementation of an effective collaboration between human and veterinary medicine, environmental protection, and public health is not a fully achieved goal, although several examples of integrated approaches have been documented in Europe. The concept of one world, one health has recently appeared, indicating that the world has suddenly woken up to the link between animal diseases, public health, and the environment. The need for collaboration between the human, animal, and environmental health sectors is due to the increase in emerging human infectious diseases with a zoonotic origin and in the resistance of microorganisms to antimicrobial drugs. Full-Text PDF Open Access
