title: Misdiagnosing vulnerability to heatwaves in the media
display_name: Misdiagnosing vulnerability to heatwaves in the media

author.au_affiliation_raw: Warwick Medical School, University of Warwick, Coventry, CV4 7AL, UK

ab: Yet again we are faced with news about temperature records being broken. As regions, countries, cities, and individuals experience more frequent, intense, and extended heatwaves,1Watts N Adger WN Agnolucci P et al.Health and climate change: policy responses to protect public health.Lancet. 2015; 386: 1861-1914Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1018) Google Scholar people often turn to the media for advice on coping with what is already a substantial public health problem. For example, media coverage by television, radio, and newspapers has long been dominated by the medical model of health2Community Development and Health NetworkModels of Health. Community Development and Health Network.https://www.cdhn.org/sites/default/files/downloads/FACTSHEETS%201_Screen%20View%281%29.pdfDate accessed: July 4, 2019Google Scholar and its general advice on heat avoidance. This advice typically includes restricting physical activity, wearing loose and light-coloured clothing, drinking more water, cooling the body, and protecting against sunburn.3Hajat S O'Connor M Kosatsky T Health effects of hot weather: from awareness of risk factors to effective health protection.Lancet. 2010; 375: 856-863Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (286) Google Scholar This model of advice has been sustained during the recent and unprecedented heatwave across mainland Europe this summer. But this common sense and passive mode of communication is problematic because it places undue emphasis on individual physiological characteristics, such as genetics and health status, and individual behaviours, such as physical activity and drinking. It is not targeted at high-risk or the most vulnerable people—such as older people, the chronically ill, children, those who are socially isolated, and outdoor workers. Media institutions should instead adopt a broader, social model of health,2Community Development and Health NetworkModels of Health. Community Development and Health Network.https://www.cdhn.org/sites/default/files/downloads/FACTSHEETS%201_Screen%20View%281%29.pdfDate accessed: July 4, 2019Google Scholar which accounts for the wider determinants of health, including social, economic, and environmental factors (eg, income, housing quality, social networks, and healthy workplaces). Wider support actions should also be considered—eg, going to cool public places, such as libraries and community centres; promoting checks on vulnerable individuals; and providing information via heat-health telephone helplines. The power of the media in communicating risk and facilitating action should not be underestimated. Shifting the focus away from the medical model of health and towards a social model would more effectively recast the problem as one that is fundamentally about public health and not individual behaviours. I declare no competing interests. Record breakersThe last 22 years contain 20 of the warmest (global average) years on record. This trend is powerfully demonstrated by the popular #Showyourstripes initiative. That most of the warmest years have occurred very recently is hardly surprising given that our planet is being heated by increasing amounts of heat trapping CO2 in the atmosphere—primarily emitted from burning fossil fuels. In this context 2019, which has seen a number of record-breaking heatwaves, is displaying exactly the sorts of conditions that we should expect to see more and more often. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Contextualising the policy decision to ban asbestos
display_name: Contextualising the policy decision to ban asbestos

author.au_affiliation_raw: Cancer Epidemiology, Centro di Riferimento per l'Epidemiologia e la Prevenzione Oncologica (CPO) Piemonte, and Department of Medical Sciences, University of Turin, 10124 Turin, Italy
author.institution_display_name: Piedmont Reference Center for Epidemiology and Cancer Prevention

ab: As of July, 2019, more than 100 countries have not totally banned the mining, importing, exporting, trading, and use of asbestos.1International Ban Asbestos SecretariatCurrent asbestos bans.http://ibasecretariat.org/alpha_ban_list.phpDate: July 15, 2019Date accessed: August 9, 2019Google Scholar In these countries—including current major producers or users of asbestos such as Russia, Kazakhstan, China, India, and Indonesia—asbestos-related diseases will persist for decades longer than in other countries that have implemented an asbestos ban. Indeed, countries that banned asbestos a quarter of a century ago are still contributing substantially to the worldwide toll of more than 100 000 asbestos-related deaths per year. No ban has ever been promulgated in the USA,2Lemen RA Landrigan P Toward an asbestos ban in the United States.Int J Environ Res Public Health. 2017; 141302Crossref Scopus (9) Google Scholar where the current Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) standard in the workplace—ie, a concentration of 0·1 fibre per mL air—approximates the lowest detectable level with current measuring methods. In The Lancet Planetary Health, Ro-Ting Lin and colleagues report findings of a global comparison showing that, for any country, the odds of adopting a ban on asbestos are associated with both the level of government efficiency and ratification of two international Conventions regarding asbestos control in the workplace and in international trade—the UN's Basel Convention and the International Labor Organization's C162 Asbestos Convention.3Lin R-T Chien L-C Jimba M Furuya S Takahashi K Implementation of national policies for a total asbestos ban: a global comparison.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: 341-348Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar In a previous study, Bahk and colleagues suggested that the process of banning asbestos was conditioned by cognition of the burden of asbestos-caused diseases and experience in tackling social problems through adequate facilities.4Bahk J Choi Y Lim S Paek D Why some, but not all, countries have banned asbestos.Int J Occup Environ Health. 2013; 19: 127-135Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar To understand how stakeholders have shaped their attitude to asbestos during the years-long process leading to bans on asbestos, we should remember that the abandonment of asbestos has been preceeded by many notable events. First was the beginning of the environmentalist movement after publication, in 1962, of Rachel Carson's book Silent Spring. Second was the assessment, in 1977, by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) that all forms of asbestos are carcinogenic to man.5WHOIARCIARC Monographs on the evaluation of carcinogenic risk to humans: vol 14—asbestos. International Agency for Research on Cancer, Lyon1977Google Scholar Third was growing awareness around 1980 by industry, trade unions, and governments that safer substitutes for asbestos exist. Fourth, using data from cancer registries and mortality statistics, researchers began to produce estimates of the number of cancer cases attributable to asbestos.6Doll R Peto R The causes of cancer: quantitative estimates of avoidable risks of cancer in the United States today.J Natl Cancer Inst. 1981; 66: 1191-1308Crossref PubMed Scopus (3922) Google Scholar Fifth was increased awareness (expanding from the scientific milieu to people with asbestos-related illnesses and the general public) that mesotheliomas might be caused by relatively low exposure to asbestos outside the workplace (deplorably, cancer deaths from exposure in the general environment cause more emotion than occupational cancers). Sixth was creation in the 1980s and 1990s of ad-hoc advocacy groups (eg, BastAmianto in Italy) indicating that asbestos bans would be the only solution to health problems. Such groups included scientists and public health workers, medical associations, and other professional bodies. Finally, beginning in the 1970s, in the USA in particular, workers started suing manufacturers and suppliers of asbestos fibres they had handled. This action meant giant companies faced liabilities exceeding their worth and insurance combined.7Castleman BI Asbestos: medical and legal aspects.5th edn. Wolters Kluwer, Law and Business, New York2011Google Scholar As a result, from the 1980s in Europe and the USA, the market for asbestos-containing materials (ACMs) stopped being financially convenient. Unravelling how these many and varied factors—and others not noted here—have combined in different countries and periods is a challenge for health historians and economists. Banning asbestos is important, but it simply means stopping extraction, processing, importing, and trading asbestos or ACMs. In itself, a ban does not create an asbestos-free country. Rendering the ACMs present at the time of the ban harmless, more than 30 million tons in the case of Italy,8Ministero della SaluteQuaderno del Ministero della Salute no 15: stato dell'arte e prospettive in materia di contrasto alle patologie asbesto-correlate—maggio-giugno 2012. Ministero della Salute, Rome2012Google Scholar is a major challenge for politicians, environmental and public health services, and consultant scientists. It requires planning, prioritising, monitoring, and allocation of funds and should be characterised by transparency in releasing information to the public. Indeed, in many countries, decades after the ban, a number of questions remain open. For example, how many ACMs remain to be remediated? Have all schools and other public buildings been made asbestos-free? Where are ACMs finally disposed? And, has asbestos been eliminated from pipes and ovens in industry. Furthermore, banning asbestos does not imply any less attention for medical treatment, in view of the very long latency of asbestos-induced illness. On the contrary, efforts should be implemented to identify and compensate all patients with asbestos-related cancer, ensuring that they are attended in the most appropriate hospital units. Availability of adequate health surveillance for workers previously exposed to asbestos is also important. Public health authorities might also face difficulties in distinguishing between reliable versus unreliable scientific results. Indeed, many reports defending asbestos, which are intended to influence policy decisions on asbestos hazards, have been published.9Terracini B Mirabelli D Asbestos and product defence science.Int J Epidemiol. 2016; 45: 614-618Crossref PubMed Scopus (5) Google Scholar, 10Michaels D Doubt is their product. How industry's assault on science threatens your health. Oxford University Press, Oxford2008Google Scholar A few of these product defence reports have been followed by complaints to the publishing journal, with few followed by late declarations of competing interests or an erratum. In a quarter of reports reviewed in a survey of scientific reports on either extent or outcomes of exposure to asbestos, a statement regarding competing interests was missing.11Valenzuela M Giraldo M Gallo-Murcia S Pineda J Santos L Ramos-Bonilla JP Recent scientific evidence regarding asbestos use and health consequences of asbestos exposure.Curr Environ Health Rep. 2016; 3: 335-347Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar Authors declared no competing interests in 92 of 134 reports providing evidence of risk (positive reports) and in one of 11 that did not (negative reports). Such a mismatch between positive and negative studies has also occurred among epidemiological investigations of passive smoking, of side-effects of new drugs, and of other aspects of environmental cancer.12Barnes DE Bero LA Why review articles on the health effects of passive smoking reach different conclusions.JAMA. 1998; 279: 1566-1570Crossref PubMed Scopus (354) Google Scholar The scientific community and journals ought to become more thorough in detecting misquotations and implementing a coherent and strict policy on declarations of competing interests as well as sanctioning the absence of such a declaration. In any country, the social, cultural, and political factors shaping the debate and contributing to decisions on banning asbestos are complex and nuanced. At the scientific level, specious pro-abestos arguments disguised as science or scientific doubt should be identified and rejected. BT has served as an expert witness for the Public Prosecution Office and for the Court in asbestos trials. Implementation of national policies for a total asbestos ban: a global comparisonThis study confirms that adoption of both the C162 Asbestos Convention and the Basel Convention facilitates countries in moving towards a total asbestos ban. The effect was reinforced by government effectiveness. Both international programmes and new agreements towards total asbestos bans and government commitments are needed. Full-Text PDF Open Access

topics.name: topic
topics.display_name: Health Systems, Economic Evaluations, Quality of Life

title: Planetary health digest
display_name: Planetary health digest
ab: Plastics are designed to be durable and the ubiquitous and wasteful way they are typically utilised, along with poor waste management practices, is leading to an abundance of plastics in the environment. Large pieces of plastic are an eyesore and represent physical risks to wildlife but as plastics break down into small pieces, microplastics, they are more readily transported and more easily inhaled or ingested. Microplastics have been found very widely spread but the relative role of different transport mechanisms remains unclear. To investigate the role of atmospheric transport in microsplastic distribution into the arctic Melanie Bergmann at the Alfred-Wegener-Institute, Germany, and co-authors analysed snow samples from ice floes from the Fram Strait, near Greenland and, compared them with snow samples from remote (Alpine) and populated (Bremen) sites. They find substantial, but highly variable, concentrations of microplastic particles in Arctic snow. Concentrations were significantly lower than in European snow but higher than expected for such a remote northerly location such that atmospheric transport and deposition seem likely to be important mechanisms for microplastic transport. Research aiming to address complex sustainability challenges often apply “new” modes of research such as post-normal science or transdisciplinarity in order to enhance the practical utility of the knowledge created by incorporating relevant scientific disciplines and non-academic stakeholders. Jens Newig from Leuphana University, Germany and co-authors undertook a comparative analysis of 81 sustainability-oriented research projects, with in-depth analysis of six of these, to investigate the connections between research modes and societal and academic project outcomes. Results are complex but they find a general pattern that early involvement of non-academic partners does tend to enhance the practical societal outcome of research. However, there is often a cost in terms of academic measures of performance such as citations. Encouragingly though this trade-off is not inevitable and well-designed projects with clearly defined disciplinary as well as transdisciplinary phases are able to perform well by both measures. In the face of multiple global social and environmental changes resilience has become an international policy priority. Demonstrating that investments in resilience building are effective and going to the right people and places requires resilience measurement. Approaches tend to be objectively-oriented – using external definitions of resilience measured through observation or external verification, or subjectively oriented – based on people's own judgements of what resilience means to them, and self-evaluation of their own resilience. Lindsey Jones at the Grantham Research Institute, UK, and co-authors investigate if these different approaches yield similar results in northern Uganda. They find that the approaches share similar associations with key socio-economic drivers of resilience but sometimes differ markedly in terms of the contributions of important traits such as coping strategies, education and prior experience. The authors argue that there is a need for resilience evaluators to consider a diversity of knowledge sources and seek greater use of evidence in selecting resilience indicators. Images can be highly influential in shaping peoples' attitudes and preferences, but the role of media imagery in bringing sustainability challenges into everyday cultures and practices is largely neglected. To address this gap Saffron O'Neill, from the University of Exeter, examined over a thousand images associated with articles about climate change in UK and US newspapers between 2001 and 2009, a key period for public climate change engagement. She found a closely consistent visual discourse in UK and US newspapers which changed around 2005. Early framing tended to use distant imagery such as polar landscapes. After 2005, with the rise in climate scepticism, there was a rapid increase in visual coverage, and an increase in use of the contested visual frames with an increase in climate cartoons and protest imagery. Understanding visual use and its influence on peoples' engagement with issues is a vital component of an evidence-based approach to climate and sustainability engagement.

title: Building resilience of health systems to climate change in Pacific Least Developed Countries: implementation science
display_name: Building resilience of health systems to climate change in Pacific Least Developed Countries: implementation science

author.au_affiliation_raw: University of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA
University of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA

ab: BackgroundThe Pacific Least Developed Countries (LDCs)—Kiribati, the Solomon Islands, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu—are among the countries most vulnerable to climate variability and change. Key climate change risks include loss of livelihoods, coastal settlements, infrastructure, ecosystem services, and economic stability; and interaction of sea level rise with high-water-level events, threatening low-lying coastal areas. These risks result in increased health impacts, including deaths and injuries from extreme events (eg, heatwaves, storms, and floods); increased risks of infectious diseases (including food-borne, water-borne, and vector-borne); food insecurity and malnutrition; and diffuse impacts from loss of livelihoods and migration. The young, older adults, women of reproductive age, and people with disabilities are most vulnerable.MethodsBuilding resilience to climate change requires that these countries develop National Climate Change and Health Action Plans, including Vulnerability and Adaptation assessments.FindingsTemperature, precipitation, and extreme weather events can influence the incidence, geographic distribution, and seasonality of climate-sensitive health outcomes. In addition, many hospitals and community health centres are highly vulnerable to cyclones, floods, storm surges, sea level rise, and disturbances in water supply caused by drought or salination of aquifers. The capacity to provide health services, particularly in emergency situations, is substantially affected if buildings and essential supplies and amenities are damaged. The majority of health facilities are not resilient to climate-induced pressures in terms of structural, non-structural, and functional safety.InterpretationThe most effective measures to reduce vulnerability are (i) short-term programmes that implement and improve basic public health measures, including the provision of safe water and improved sanitation, secure essential health care, and increase capacity for disaster preparedness and response; and (ii) longer-term programs that enhance national health systems and institutions with climate change-related risks integrated into health governance, strengthen health information management systems, and ensure effective and accessible delivery of health services.FundingLeast Developed Countries Fund under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.

title: Sustainability assessment of Indian diets: a modelling study
display_name: Sustainability assessment of Indian diets: a modelling study

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, Kanpur, India

ab: BackgroundTransitioning from current to sustainable diets that have low environmental impacts and high nutrition and are culturally acceptable can contribute greatly towards the achievement of several national Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). With a population of 1·3 billion, widely prevalent malnutrition and increasing incomes, India's per capita consumption patterns will also play a key role over next decade in deciding the fate of United Nations 2030 global SDGs.MethodsHere we assess how the intake amounts of different food items in Indian diets must change in order to the meet the daily-recommended levels for 29 macro and micro nutrients while maintaining environmental footprints below the five food-related per capita planetary boundaries (carbon emissions, water, land, nitrogen and phosphorus use). We also put several cultural acceptability constraints to avoid obtaining an unrealistic diet.FindingsA considerable departure from current dietary behaviour is needed to transition from current to sustainable diets in India. While the daily per capita environmental footprints of current Indian diets are well below the respective planetary boundaries, the daily recommended levels for vitamins B12, E, and K, fibre, potassium, and choline are not being met currently, suggesting the need to pay special attention to them. The required changes include high increases (>200 g per capita per day) in fruits and vegetable intake, moderate increases in the intake of other grains (eg, millet, sorghum, rye), pulses, roots and tubers, fish and meat (about 30 g each) and a high reduction in intake of rice and dairy products (>100 g each).InterpretationFuture research should assess the potential of different leverage points from both the production side (eg, reducing food loss, filling yield gaps, improving technologies, biofortification) and the consumption side (eg, taxes, subsidies, campaigns, changes in physical microenvironment) to help transition towards sustainable diets.FundingInitiation Grant of IIT Kanpur, India (number 2018386).

title: Planetary Health Alliance 2019 call for abstracts
display_name: Planetary Health Alliance 2019 call for abstracts

author.au_affiliation_raw: Planetary Health Alliance, Cambridge, MA, USA
Harvard T H Chan School of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA
Harvard T H Chan School of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA
Stanford Center for Innovation in Global Health, Stanford, CA, USA
Division of Infectious Diseases and Geographic Medicine, Woods Institute for the Environment, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

ab: The Planetary Health Alliance is a consortium of over 130 dedicated universities, non-government organisations, government entities, and research institutes from around the world committed to advancing planetary health—an interdisciplinary field focused on understanding and quantifying the effects of accelerating environmental change on human health. The Planetary Health Alliance and Stanford University are organizing the third Annual Meeting on Planetary Health on Sept 4–6, 2019, at Stanford University (Palo Alto, CA, USA). As in past years, we are seeking abstracts for oral and poster presentations. In conjunction with the meeting, The Lancet Planetary Health will publish a booklet of selected outstanding abstracts. This year, there will be three categories for abstract submission: Scientific Research, Education, and Policy & Practice. Researchers, educators, policymakers and practitioners from any discipline relevant to planetary health are invited to submit an abstract of their work describing a recent study or current project that contributes to gaps in knowledge, governance, and imagination as reported by the Rockefeller–Lancet Commission on Planetary Health.1Whitmee S Haines A Beyrer C et al.Safeguarding human health in the Anthropocene epoch: report of The Rockefeller Foundation–Lancet Commission on planetary health.Lancet. 2015; 386: 1973-2028Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1122) Google Scholar Topics of interest include geographically diverse examples of approaches, methods, tools, and indicators to assess how, where, and why environmental change leads to meaningful public health impacts and to address solutions to planetary health challenges. If you have any questions about whether a topic is relevant, please visit the Planetary Health Alliance website for themes or e-mail [email protected] Submissions are due by 1700h EST (2200 h GMT) on April 1, 2019, and should be submitted online. Authors of accepted abstracts will be invited to present as oral or poster presenters at the 2019 Planetary Health Annual Meeting. Notifications of acceptance will be sent by 1700 h EST on April 30, 2019. Abstracts should be in English, 300 words maximum, and present detailed information on study or project design, methods, and results, even if preliminary. Attention should be given to describing the impact of a change in the structure or function of a natural system(s) on a dimension (or dimensions) of human health. Abstracts in the Education and Policy & Practice categories should include project objectives and parameters, audience or stakeholders engaged, and experience to date. Please lay out your abstract under the following headings: title (including a study descriptor if appropriate—eg, randomised), background (including context and aim), methods, findings, interpretation. Include names, titles, highest degrees, and affiliations of all authors; postal and email addresses for the corresponding author; any funding received (if none, state this); and a brief summary of the contributions of each author and any competing interests. Do not include references, tables, or figures. We declare no competing interests.

title: Drivers of health transition in the DPRK
display_name: Drivers of health transition in the DPRK

author.au_affiliation_raw: Pyongyang Medical College, Kim Il Sung University, Pyongyang, North Korea
Department of Community Medicine and Global Health, University of Oslo, Oslo, Norway
Department of Ophthalmology, Institute for Clinical Medicine, University of Oslo, Oslo, Norway
Landøya Secondary School, Asker, Norway
Department of Community Medicine and Global Health, University of Oslo, Oslo, Norway
Department of Community Medicine and Global Health, University of Oslo, Oslo, Norway

ab: The health situation and the drivers of the health transition in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK or North Korea) after the Korean War (1950–53) have mainly been discussed in international literature by scientists living outside the country. The current health challenges in North Korea range from chronic undernutrition and tuberculosis to non-communicable diseases.1Ministry of Public Health, North KoreaAnnual Health Report, DPR Korea 2017. Ministry of Public Health, Pyongyang2018Google Scholar, 2Country profile North Korea.http://www.healthdata.org/north-koreaDate: 2018Date accessed: May 14, 2018Google Scholar Reports from the Global Burden of Diseases, Injuries, and Risk Factors Study 2017,3GBD 2017 Mortality CollaboratorsGlobal, regional, and national age-sex-specific mortality and life expectancy, 1950–2017: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2017.Lancet. 2018; 392: 1684-1735Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (522) Google Scholar indicate no change in life expectancy from 1990 (71·8 years) to 2017, with a drop in 1995 (62·9 years) to 2000 (62·1 years), and a modest increase of 1·7 years from 2005 (70·3 years) to 2017 (72·0 years). The 2017 annual health report1Ministry of Public Health, North KoreaAnnual Health Report, DPR Korea 2017. Ministry of Public Health, Pyongyang2018Google Scholar shows a similar pattern in life expectancy: 74·5 years at the end of the 1980s, a drop in the mid-1990s, an increase to 70·3 years in 2010, reaching 72·7 years in 2015. The most common negative drivers and probable causes of the trends in life expectancy discussed in the international literature include the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, natural disasters in the 1990s,4Bjertness E Madar AA North Korea: a challenge for global solidarity.Lancet. 2014; 383: 1381-1382Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar and economic sanctions. These three factors have negatively affected North Korea's socioeconomic progress and public health,1Ministry of Public Health, North KoreaAnnual Health Report, DPR Korea 2017. Ministry of Public Health, Pyongyang2018Google Scholar and together have caused damage to achievements in health-care and welfare services in the form of malnutrition, incidence of communicable diseases, and high mortality rates, which were inconceivable in the past.1Ministry of Public Health, North KoreaAnnual Health Report, DPR Korea 2017. Ministry of Public Health, Pyongyang2018Google Scholar Economic sanctions against North Korea have been imposed by the USA since the 1950s and by the UN and EU over the past decade,5Sanctions against North Korea.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanctions_against_North_KoreaDate accessed: September 3, 2018Google Scholar with strict sanctions implemented in 2016 and 2017, respectively. In general, strict sanctions with large economic effects can have public health consequences, including on the availability of food, clean water, and medicines; however, when the economic effect is minor, public health is largely unaffected.6Allen SH Lektzian DJ Economic sanctions: a blunt instrument?.J Peace Res. 2013; 50: 121-135Crossref Scopus (76) Google Scholar The exact effects of economic sanctions on public health in North Korea are difficult to elucidate, but they cannot be tolerated if they negatively affect the wellbeing of the people. The sanctions are likely to have affected population health, and even more so in the past 2 years. For example, import restrictions on medical equipment and chemical compounds to produce medicines have led to insufficient supplies of antibiotics (both intravenous and tablet form), not only in rural hospitals, but also in the best-equipped hospitals in Pyongyang. Insufficient supply of modern medicines has prompted further development of traditional medicine (ie, Koryo medicine),7Lim B Park J Han C Attempts to utilize and integrate traditional medicine in North Korea.J Alt Complement Med. 2009; 15: 217023Crossref Scopus (10) Google Scholar especially in the past 2–3 years. In June, 2018, the Global Fund ended the tuberculosis and malaria programmes,8Burki T North Korea and the Global Fund.Lancet Infect Dis. 2018; 18: 501Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (5) Google Scholar which might pose a future burden to health in North Korea. Additionally, the 45% reduction in aid disbursements from development assistance committee countries from 2012 to 2017, might affect the life expectancy, health, and wellbeing of people in North Korea.9Organisation for Economic Co-operation and DevelopmentAid (ODA) disbursements to countries and regions [DAC2a].https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?datasetcode=TABLE2ADate accessed: February 4, 2019Google Scholar Examples of positive drivers of the health transition in North Korea are improved vaccination coverage, advances in medical technology (including the adoption of telemedicine in 2010), and long-distance online medical training between universities and hospitals. North Korea has put forward several economic reforms, including the Chollima movement in the late 1950s, to rebuild North Korea's economy after the Korean War, and the Mallima movement in 2017, which aimed to encourage faster economic transition. Despite the severe sanctions, the socioeconomy has developed, especially in the large cities, overcoming the economic crisis in the 1990s. The gross domestic product per capita increased from US$463 in 2000 to $1053 in 2014,1Ministry of Public Health, North KoreaAnnual Health Report, DPR Korea 2017. Ministry of Public Health, Pyongyang2018Google Scholar which is somewhat higher than estimates from the UN.10UN Statistics DivisionNational accounts estimates of main aggregates.http://data.un.org/Data.aspx?d=SNAAMA&f=grID%3A101%3BcurrID%3AUSD%3BpcFlag%3A1Date accessed: February 4, 2019Google Scholar At the core of the public health policy in North Korea is the adoption of preventive medicine in health activities, and strengthening of the universal free medical care system. The government guarantees, by both policy and law, to protect and care for the lives and health of people in North Korea,1Ministry of Public Health, North KoreaAnnual Health Report, DPR Korea 2017. Ministry of Public Health, Pyongyang2018Google Scholar and states that health is a human right. For example, the lives and health of mothers and children will be protected and promoted through maternity leave (240 days in 2015), shorter working hours for mothers with several children, and scaling up the network of maternity hospitals, nurseries, and kindergartens.1Ministry of Public Health, North KoreaAnnual Health Report, DPR Korea 2017. Ministry of Public Health, Pyongyang2018Google Scholar North Korea is actively trying to promote cooperation and exchange of both knowledge and people with other countries in public health. An example is the cooperation, established in 2010, between Pyongyang Medical College, Kim Il Sung University in North Korea and the University of Oslo in Norway. In an effort to become a leading university, Pyongyang Medical College acknowledges that it needs to contribute to the international scientific literature, which is scarce at present. The University of Oslo aims to assist Pyongyang Medical College to build capacity in international scientific writing, and a bilateral exchange of staff and students. The University of Oslo is offering seats at their international summer school to staff of Pyongyang Medical College to build competence in international community health, which might further strengthen the collaboration between Norway and North Korea, and ultimately improve population health. Kim Il Sung University is interested in establishing international cooperation in public health, clinical medicine, and basic medical science. Provision of e-learning resources and medical journals sent on a regular basis by mail and subscriptions from international universities and research journals are welcomed. Medical training programmes in both North Korea and abroad that include international partnerships might help to advance population health and wellbeing in North Korea and, in the end, all people globally. Such cooperation is supported by Richard Horton in the Lancet,11Horton R Offline: North Korea—the case for health diplomacy.Lancet. 2017; 390: 1016Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar suggesting that the health community can be a powerful diplomatic tool to advance health and wellbeing in North Korea through partnerships. University cooperation is a public health imperative, and can be done to foster global health solidarity. In light of the fifth North–South summit and talk between Comrade Kim Jong Un, chairman of the State Affairs Commission of North Korea, and Moon Jae-in, South Korean president, and meetings between North Korea and USA, the time to establish international and national academic cooperation is now.12Normile D Korean thaw raises hopes for scientific cooperation.Science. 2018; 360: 475-476Crossref PubMed Scopus (2) Google Scholar The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development promises to leave no one behind13UN General AssemblyTransforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Resolution adopted by the General Assembly on 25 September 2015.http://www.un.org/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=A/RES/70/1&Lang=EDate accessed: May 18, 2018Google Scholar—a pledge that should include both vulnerable populations and whole countries. The global community should aim to keep the promise of the Sustainable Development Goals to ensure healthy lives and promote wellbeing for all14UN Sustainable Development GoalsTransforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/post2015/transformingourworldDate accessed: February 4, 2019Google Scholar in a "just, equitable, tolerant, open, and socially inclusive world".13UN General AssemblyTransforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Resolution adopted by the General Assembly on 25 September 2015.http://www.un.org/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=A/RES/70/1&Lang=EDate accessed: May 18, 2018Google Scholar We declare no competing interests.

title: Humans, macaques, and malaria parasites in a shared and changing landscape
display_name: Humans, macaques, and malaria parasites in a shared and changing landscape

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Population Health and Disease Prevention, University of California, Irvine, CA 92697-3957, USA

ab: Plasmodium knowlesi, a simian malaria that naturally infects long-tailed macaques (Macaca fascicularis) and pig-tailed macaques (Macaca nemestrina), was discovered in a long-tailed macaque from Singapore in 1931.1Knowles R Gupta BMD A Study of monkey-malaria, and its experimental transmission to man.Ind Med Gaz. 1932; 67: 301-320PubMed Google Scholar Although simian malarias were known to be capable of experimentally infecting humans, questions remained about their zoonotic potential. The first known natural infection of a human by a simian malaria was documented in 1965, when a surveyor for the US Army Map Service, working deep in the jungles of peninsular Malaysia, was infected by P knowlesi.2Chin W Contacos PG Coatney GR Kimball HR A naturally acquired quotidian-type malaria in man transferable to monkeys.Science. 1965; 149: 865-965Crossref PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar Previous experimental P knowlesi infections in humans had revealed the daily fever pattern of this parasite and tests had also shown that rhesus macaques (Macaca mulatta) infected with P knowlesi developed severe disease and often died. This first known zoonotic infection was confirmed to be P knowlesi by experimental inoculation—by use of blood from the infected person—of seven other individuals (who subsequently developed daily fevers) and three rhesus macaques, all of which subsequently died. The possibility of zoonotic malaria had major implications for ongoing malaria elimination and eradication efforts and sparked a massive research project in the jungles where the zoonosis had likely occurred (central Pahang).3Warren M Cheong WH Fredericks HK Coatney GR Cycles of jungle malaria in west Malaysia.Am J Trop Med Hyg. 1970; 19: 383-393Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar Blood was collected from 1117 participants living in the area and M mulatta monkeys were subsequently inoculated. None showed signs of illness. Although it was apparent that P knowlesi could infect humans, the findings from this investigation led many to believe that this only occurred in rare circumstances.3Warren M Cheong WH Fredericks HK Coatney GR Cycles of jungle malaria in west Malaysia.Am J Trop Med Hyg. 1970; 19: 383-393Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar More than 30 years later, investigations into an abnormally high burden of Plasmodium malariae uncovered a large focus of misdiagnosed P knowlesi infections in Malaysian Borneo.4Singh B Sung LK Matusop A et al.A large focus of naturally acquired Plasmodium knowlesi infections in human beings.Lancet. 2004; 363: 1017-1024Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (769) Google Scholar Since then, human P knowlesi infections have been identified in most other nations in southeast Asia, although the heaviest apparent burden continues to exist in northern Borneo.5Singh B Daneshvar C Human infections and detection of Plasmodium knowlesi.Clin Microbiol Rev. 2013; 26: 165-184Crossref PubMed Scopus (310) Google Scholar Most cases have been detected through passive case detection, leaving questions about the true burden of the disease in endemic areas. An impressive cross-sectional study by Kimberley Fornace and colleagues,6Fornace KM Brock PM Abidin TR et al.Environmental risk factors and exposure to the zoonotic malaria parasite Plasmodium knowlesi across northern Sabah, Malaysia: a population-based cross-sectional survey.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e157-e158Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar in The Lancet Planetary Health, provides the first detailed description of the overall burden of P knowlesi across a wide geographical region that is endemic for the disease (four districts in northern Sabah of Malaysian Borneo). Approximately 5% of the total surveyed population was seropositive for P knowlesi. Predictors of exposure included male sex, older age groups, reported contact with macaques, and reported activities in forested areas. Environmental attributes that were positively associated with P knowlesi exposure included living near irrigated rice paddy fields and pulpwood plantations, and near fragmented oil palm plantations. Participants living near fragmented forests and at higher geographical elevations were less likely to be seropositive for P knowlesi. Contact patterns between humans, mosquito vectors, and macaques are influenced by movement and land use patterns across heterogeneous environments. The movement ranges of human, macaque, and mosquito populations are likely to span different spatial scales. The most appropriate spatial scale for predicting risk of exposure to P knowlesi is therefore unclear. Rather than choosing arbitrary spatial units for use in their model, Fornace and colleagues measured environmental variables at radii ranging from 100 m to 5000 m around participant households and used a data mining approach to choose a best fitting model. This approach could usefully be implemented with many other datasets and with different disease systems. Some key questions remain unanswered. Although it is clear that humans can acquire this infection from macaques, human-to-human transfer in nature has not been established. Further basic science and ecological research into this disease system is warranted. P knowlesi infections appear to be relatively rare and heterogeneously distributed, but it is possible that low-density infections are missed. Methods that are designed to detect low-density infections7Imwong M Hanchana S Malleret B et al.High-throughput ultrasensitive molecular techniques for quantifying low-density malaria parasitemias.J Clin Microbiol. 2014; 52: 3303-3309Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar might be informative for understanding the epidemiology of P knowlesi. Serological markers can be useful for measuring historical disease burdens, and are perhaps especially useful in situations where infections are rare. Serological work on P knowlesi is promising, but continued work on the longevity and seroreactivity of antigenic responses to the parasite are needed. In this study, the authors attempted to measure only recent exposure. However, it is not immediately clear why exposure would increase (almost linearly) with age. This might be the result of behavioural differences across age groups, repeated exposure across the lifespan, or a combination of both factors. Although globally rare, P knowlesi malaria will probably continue to have public health significance at least for northern Borneo, where it is the largest overall contributor to malaria8WHO Regional Office for Western PacificExpert consultation on Plasmodium knowlesi malaria to guide malaria elimination strategies, Kota Kinabalu, Malaysia, 1–2 March 2017: meeting report. WHO Regional Office for the Western Pacific, Manila2017Google Scholar and where the landscape is quickly changing. Malaria elimination is being considered by most nations in this region9WHOEliminating malaria in the greater Mekong subregion: united to end a deadly disease.http://www.who.int/malaria/publications/atoz/eliminating-malaria-greater-mekong/en/Date: November, 2016Date accessed: March 19, 2019Google Scholar but the primary focus has been on P falciparum, with a growing interest in Plasmodium vivax. This zoonotic malaria, which exists at extremely high prevalence in some macaque populations,10Lee K-S Divis PCS Zakaria SK et al.Plasmodium knowlesi: reservoir hosts and tracking the emergence in humans and macaques.PLoS Pathogens. 2011; 7: e1002015Crossref PubMed Scopus (221) Google Scholar poses unique challenges that will need to be addressed if all forms of malaria are to be eliminated. I declare no competing interests. Environmental risk factors and exposure to the zoonotic malaria parasite Plasmodium knowlesi across northern Sabah, Malaysia: a population-based cross-sectional surveyAlthough few infections were detected, P knowlesi exposure was observed in all demographic groups and was associated with occupational factors. Results suggest that agricultural expansion and forest fragmentation affect P knowlesi exposure, supporting linkages between land use change and P knowlesi transmission. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Mortality risk within counterfactual models: Puerto Rico and Hurricane Maria
display_name: Mortality risk within counterfactual models: Puerto Rico and Hurricane Maria

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Kinesiology, Health, and Nutrition, University of Texas at San Antonio, San Antonio, TX, USA
author.institution_display_name: The University of Texas at San Antonio

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Human Development and Family Studies, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, USA

ab: Using data from the Puerto Rico Vital Statistics System obtained from the materials provided by Carlos Santos-Burgoa and colleagues,1Santos-Burgoa C Sandberg J Suárez E et al.Differential and persistent risk of excess mortality from Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico: a time-series analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: 478-488Summary Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (101) Google Scholar we compared the census-based and displacement models with death counts for Puerto Rico for the period after Hurricane Maria. We calculated confidence intervals for deaths from 2010 to 2016 for observed deaths (figure) and compared them with the pre-Hurricane and post-Hurricane counts (2017) and both counterfactual models. The displacement model falls outside of the pattern observed over the past 7 years before Hurricane Maria, while mortality between January and August does not (figure). A comparison of the upper limits of the historical 95% and 99% CIs produced estimates of excess deaths of 1061 and 985, which are consistent with the census-based model1Santos-Burgoa C Sandberg J Suárez E et al.Differential and persistent risk of excess mortality from Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico: a time-series analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: 478-488Summary Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (101) Google Scholar and previous estimates.2Santos-Lozada AR Howard JT Use of death counts from vital statistics to calculate excess deaths in Puerto Rico following Hurricane Maria.J Am Med Assoc. 2018; 320: 1491-1493Crossref Scopus (63) Google Scholar Even though the predicted number of deaths in the displacement model was less than the historical ranges, it was the only estimate provided to the Government of Puerto Rico.3Andrade E Barrett N Colon-Ramos U et al.Ascertainment of the estimated excess mortality from Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico. August 28, 2018. Milken Institute School of Public Health, Washington, DC2018https://prstudy.publichealth.gwu.edu/Date accessed: April 16, 2019Google Scholar If death counts before Hurricane Maria fell within historical ranges, why is this outcome not the case for the counterfactual model? A counterfactual model is supposed to represent what would have been expected if an event did not occur, so why would the preferred counterfactual model include additional hurricane-induced population displacement? In addition, the only way this model would occur is by assuming higher mortality risk for those who were displaced than for those who stayed behind. This assumption ignores the selectivity mechanisms that operate after climate disasters regarding population mobility. Previous research, albeit in other contexts, has found that those who remain behind have characteristics associated with higher mortality risk.4Thiede BC Brown DL Hurricane Katrina: Who stayed and why?.Popul Res Policy Rev. 2013; 32: 804-824Crossref Scopus (47) Google Scholar The displacement model overstates the mortality risk for those who were displaced with a mortality rate ratio of 158 in comparison with the census-based model or 165 compared with the displacement model.5Santos-Lozada AR Howard JT Supplement to: ascertaining mortality risk within counterfactual models: Puerto Rico and Hurricane Maria. GitHub.https://alexisrsantos.github.io/Correspondence_Lancet/Date: 2018Date accessed: April 10, 2019Google Scholar Assuming a higher mortality risk for displaced individuals seems to contradict other findings within the Article,1Santos-Burgoa C Sandberg J Suárez E et al.Differential and persistent risk of excess mortality from Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico: a time-series analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: 478-488Summary Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (101) Google Scholar which shows a higher risk for individuals of an older age and lower socioeconomic status—ie, those who are less likely to migrate.4Thiede BC Brown DL Hurricane Katrina: Who stayed and why?.Popul Res Policy Rev. 2013; 32: 804-824Crossref Scopus (47) Google Scholar Estimates produced after Hurricane Maria have gravitated around 1000 excess deaths. A meta-analysis5Santos-Lozada AR Howard JT Supplement to: ascertaining mortality risk within counterfactual models: Puerto Rico and Hurricane Maria. GitHub.https://alexisrsantos.github.io/Correspondence_Lancet/Date: 2018Date accessed: April 10, 2019Google Scholar of previous estimates produced with vital statistics points towards a figure of 1093 (95% CI 943–1242). Excess death estimates comparing the observed deaths between September, 2017, and February, 2018, and the upper limit of the historical confidence intervals, are within the margins of the census-based model1Santos-Burgoa C Sandberg J Suárez E et al.Differential and persistent risk of excess mortality from Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico: a time-series analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: 478-488Summary Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (101) Google Scholar and previous estimates.2Santos-Lozada AR Howard JT Use of death counts from vital statistics to calculate excess deaths in Puerto Rico following Hurricane Maria.J Am Med Assoc. 2018; 320: 1491-1493Crossref Scopus (63) Google Scholar The census model captured all the previous estimates, produced before the publication of the Article, within its 95% CI.5Santos-Lozada AR Howard JT Supplement to: ascertaining mortality risk within counterfactual models: Puerto Rico and Hurricane Maria. GitHub.https://alexisrsantos.github.io/Correspondence_Lancet/Date: 2018Date accessed: April 10, 2019Google Scholar The outlier is the estimate derived from the displacement model; surprisingly, this estimate was the only one provided to the Government of Puerto Rico.3Andrade E Barrett N Colon-Ramos U et al.Ascertainment of the estimated excess mortality from Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico. August 28, 2018. Milken Institute School of Public Health, Washington, DC2018https://prstudy.publichealth.gwu.edu/Date accessed: April 16, 2019Google Scholar We declare no competing interests. Mortality risk within counterfactual models: Puerto Rico and Hurricane Maria – Authors' replyThe main argument by Jeffrey Howard and Alexis Santos-Lozada appears to be that because the predicted number of deaths from the displacement model in our analysis was lower than historical averages and previous counterfactual estimates for the period after Hurricane Maria, this estimate, and estimates of excess mortality associated with them therefore must be biased or inaccurate in some way. The opposite is in fact the case. It is estimates of excess mortality that ignore displacement that are biased. Full-Text PDF Open AccessDifferential and persistent risk of excess mortality from Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico: a time-series analysisAnalysis of all-cause mortality with vital registration data allows for unbiased estimation of the impact of disasters associated with natural hazards and is useful for public health surveillance. It does not depend on certified cause of death, the basis for the official death toll in Puerto Rico. Although all sectors of Puerto Rican society were affected, recovery varied by municipal socioeconomic development and age groups. This finding calls for equitable disaster preparedness and response to protect vulnerable populations in disasters. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Exposure to green spaces as a modifiable risk factor in attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder
display_name: Exposure to green spaces as a modifiable risk factor in attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Psychology, University of Canterbury, Christchurch, Canterbury 8081, New Zealand

ab: Geoffrey Donovan and colleagues1Donovan GH Michael YL Gatziolis D 't Mannetje A Douwes J Association between exposure to the natural environment, rurality, and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder in children in New Zealand: a linkage study.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e226-e234Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar should be commended for their creative exploration of the role that the natural environment plays in the development of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Exposure to green spaces has been associated with numerous health benefits for children's and adolescents' mental health,2Vanaken GJ Danckaerts M Impact of green space exposure on children's and adolescents' mental health: a systematic review.Int J Environ Res Public Health. 2018; 15: E2668Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar including positive stress reduction.3Hunter MR Gillespie BW Chen SY-P Urban nature experiences reduce stress in the context of daily life based on salivary biomarkers.Front Psychol. 2019; 10: 722Crossref PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar However, Donovan and colleagues' study is the first to extensively explore the role of the environment in the development of a chronic mental health condition that poses a substantial financial burden in terms of individual and societal costs. Donovan and colleagues1Donovan GH Michael YL Gatziolis D 't Mannetje A Douwes J Association between exposure to the natural environment, rurality, and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder in children in New Zealand: a linkage study.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e226-e234Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar identified all children (n=57 450) born in New Zealand in 1998, of which 49 923 were included in the study sample (after exclusion of those with no address or those who had left the country). The researchers assessed those children's exposures to green spaces yearly from gestation to 18 years of age on the basis of the rurality and greenness (normalised difference vegetation index [NDVI], calculated from satellite imagery) of their residential location. ADHD diagnoses were defined as hospital diagnosis or at least two recorded prescriptions for ADHD drugs. The results showed that living in a rural area between 2 years and 18 years of age had a protective effect against the development of symptoms associated with ADHD (odds ratio [OR] 0·670 [95% CI 0·461–0·974]), as did increased minimum yearly greenness exposure for the same period (standardised OR 0·841 [0·707–0·999] for second quartile vs first quartile of minimum NDVI exposure). Rurality or greenness exposure before 2 years of age did not affect the development of ADHD symptoms. The observed protective effect was evident even after controlling for known risk factors such as sex, ethnicity, maternal education, and maternal smoking. The authors speculated that green spaces probably exert their effect by moderating the expression of the symptoms of ADHD, rather than by preventing their initial development. This study is the most comprehensive cohort study to date to investigate this relationship. In addition to the large and mostly intact sample, the use of technology to assess greenness (ie, calculating NDVI from satellite imagery) and to link those data with a child's residential location throughout life, and thus with ADHD diagnoses, is a strength of the paper. Mental disorders constitute a considerable burden for modern communities, and evidence indicates that, despite access to evidence-based treatments, this burden is likely to escalate further.4Mulder R Rucklidge J Wilkinson S Why has increased provision of psychiatric treatment not reduced the prevalence of mental disorder?.Aust N Z J Psychiatry. 2017; 51: 1176-1177Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar, 5Jorm AF Patten SB Brugha TS Mojtabai R Has increased provision of treatment reduced the prevalence of common mental disorders? Review of the evidence from four countries.World Psychiatry. 2017; 16: 90-99Crossref PubMed Scopus (261) Google Scholar For children with ADHD, even when they have received the best standard of care, long-term financial, legal, psychological, and educational outcomes remain suboptimal.6Swanson JM Arnold LE Molina BSG et al.Young adult outcomes in the follow-up of the multimodal treatment study of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder: symptom persistence, source discrepancy, and height suppression.J Child Psychol Psychiatry. 2017; 58: 663-678Crossref PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar Focusing on variables that can reduce this burden is essential to prevent the development of such neurodevelopmental disorders. Donovan and colleagues' study1Donovan GH Michael YL Gatziolis D 't Mannetje A Douwes J Association between exposure to the natural environment, rurality, and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder in children in New Zealand: a linkage study.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e226-e234Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar highlights one controllable environmental variable that could easily be modified in modern home designs and through providing education on the important health benefits for children of spending time in natural environments. Their findings also fit comfortably within the context of a growing body of research showing the detrimental effects of other modifiable environmental factors on the expression of ADHD, such as poor nutrition7Taylor MR Chuang C Carrasco KD Nagatomo S Rucklidge JJ Dietary and micronutrient treatments for children with neurodevelopment disorders.Curr Dev Disord Rep. 2018; 5: 243-252Crossref Scopus (3) Google Scholar and early-life exposure to persistent organic pollutants.8Lenters V Iszatt N Forns J et al.Early-life exposure to persistent organic pollutants (OCPs, PBDEs, PCBs, PFASs) and attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder: a multi-pollutant analysis of a Norwegian birth cohort.Environ Int. 2019; 125: 33-42Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar Although other risk factors have been identified for the development of ADHD that are difficult to change, such as genetics,9Faraone SV Larsson H Genetics of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.Mol Psychiatry. 2019; 24: 562-575Crossref PubMed Scopus (375) Google Scholar Donovan and colleagues' study underscores that a focus on modification of the environment is essential to reduce the burden of mental illness. The link between the rural environment and microbial exposure, as postulated in the study, is intriguing. Some preliminary evidence suggests that microbial diversity might affect the expression of ADHD symptoms.10Prehn-Kristensen A Zimmermann A Tittmann L et al.Reduced microbiome alpha diversity in young patients with ADHD.PLoS One. 2018; 13: e0200728Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar We do not yet know whether manipulation of this diversity can improve the symptoms of ADHD; however, Donovan and colleagues' study suggests that greater exposure to green spaces might promote such changes. The opportunities for both prevention and intervention are obvious, but might require government policy to be adequately targeted. Some assumptions made in conducting the study are limitations to the findings. Children living in rural areas might be less likely to seek an ADHD diagnosis or to be able to access specialised professionals. Furthermore, a child's home environment does not constitute the entire living environment, and we cannot assume that reduced access to green space is associated with less time spent outside. Donovan and colleagues' study shows that linking satellite data with a mental health diagnosis is achievable, and the authors discovery of this novel way of exposing a modifiable risk factor for ADHD is commendable. As the technology becomes more sophisticated, so will the certainty in the findings. I declare no competing interests. Association between exposure to the natural environment, rurality, and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder in children in New Zealand: a linkage studyRurality and increased minimum greenness were strongly and independently associated with a reduced risk of ADHD. Increasing a child's minimum lifetime greenness exposure, as opposed to maximum or mean exposure, might provide the greatest increment of protection against the disorder. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Resistance to antibiotics of bacteria in tropical countries
display_name: Resistance to antibiotics of bacteria in tropical countries

author.au_affiliation_raw:
IHU Marseille - Institut Hospitalier Universitaire Méditerranée Infection (IHU - Méditerranée Infection
19-21 Bd Jean Moulin
13005 MARSEILLE 
FRANCE - France)

ab: The search for the source of resistance of bacteria to antibiotics is, I believe, too naive and too much based on guilt for human-related activity. This perception of the world yields analyses that claim to establish an exclusive link between the use of human-made antibiotics and the resistance of microorganisms to antibiotics. This connection neglects the importance of the source of natural antibiotics, which are present in the environment. Most antibiotics are secreted by microorganisms (ie, bacteria) of the actinomycetes phylum, or fungi.1Angelakis E Merhej V Raoult D Related actions of probiotics and antibiotics on gut microbiota and weight modification.Lancet Infect Dis. 2013; 13: 10889-10899Summary Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (134) Google Scholar The resistance of microorganisms to these natural antibiotics existed long before their medical use. β-lactamases are found in the genetic sequences of microorganisms from the Middle Ages, and the resistance of Staphylococcus aureus in the 19th century has been shown.2Raoult D Rolain JM The living croquet theory: the Staphylococcus aureus paradigm.Int J Antimicrob Agents. 2019; published April 12. DOI:10.1016/j.ijantimicag.2019.04.005Crossref Scopus (1) Google Scholar Antibiotics are assembled in microorganisms by non-ribosomal protein synthases and polyketide synthases, which are the only known translation devices outside the ribosome. Their existence might have preceded that of ribosomes and could be archaic translation machineries. Because biodiversity is generally much higher in the humid intertropical zone, as compared with temperate and cold countries, it is also likely to be the place where the most diverse microorganisms are found, as evidenced by the richness of the human microbiota in rural intertropical areas compared with urban or temperate areas.3Angelakis E Bachar D Yasir M et al.Comparison of the gut microbiota of obese individuals from different geographic origins.New Microbes New Infect. 2019; 27: 40-47Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar This biodiversity can be accompanied by a biodiversity of molecules with antibiotic activity. Additionally, the molecules secreted by non-ribosomal protein synthases and polyketide synthases have multiple activities—not only antimicrobial, but also antifungal. Against eukaryotes, some molecules are used as anticancer treatments. Some human β-lactamases have anticancer drug inhibitory activity as with mitomycin.4Lee SY Brem J Pettinati I et al.Cephalosporins inhibit human metallo β-lactamase fold DNA repair nucleases SNM1A and SNM1B/apollo.Chem Commun. 2016; 52: 406727-406730Google Scholar The spectrum of β-lactamase activity far exceeds anti-β-lactamine activity, playing a role in the digestion of nucleic acid.4Lee SY Brem J Pettinati I et al.Cephalosporins inhibit human metallo β-lactamase fold DNA repair nucleases SNM1A and SNM1B/apollo.Chem Commun. 2016; 52: 406727-406730Google Scholar Antibiotic resistance is a global concern and the source of resistance is often found in the world's intertropical or hottest regions.5Collignon P Beggs JJ Walsh TR Gandra S Laxminarayan R Anthropological and socioeconomic factors contributing to global antimicrobial resistance: a univariate and multivariable analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e398-e405Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (293) Google Scholar This specificity has not yet been satisfactorily explained, but has been supported by an extensive study by James Hassell and colleagues, which shows that a country's overall antibiotic use is not correlated with the proportion of bacterial resistance;6Hassell JM Ward MJ Muloi D et al.Clinically relevant antimicrobial resistance at the wildlife-livestock-human interface in Nairobi: an epidemiological study.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e259-e269Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar rather, the relationship is inverse: the lower the percentage of antibiotic prescription, the higher the proportion of antimicrobial resistance.5Collignon P Beggs JJ Walsh TR Gandra S Laxminarayan R Anthropological and socioeconomic factors contributing to global antimicrobial resistance: a univariate and multivariable analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e398-e405Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (293) Google Scholar We have confirmation of this in France, where antibiotic use is one of the highest in the world, and where the proportion of resistance is one of the lowest in the world.7Le Page S Dubourg G Baron SA Rolain JM Raoult D No global increase in resistance to antibiotics: a snapshot of resistance from 2001 to 2016 in Marseille, France.Eur J Clin Microbiol Infect Dis. 2019; 38: 395-407Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar The same is true in the USA, where difficult-to-treat Gram-negative bacteria represent a small proportion of the bacteria isolated from the blood cultures of hospitalised patients.8Raoult D Rolain JM The paradigm of the Shadoks and antibiotic resistance.Clin Infect Dis. 2019; published online March 6. DOI:10.1093/cid/ciz183Crossref Scopus (4) Google Scholar The reason for these differences remains poorly explained. Poor management of prescription of antibiotics in humans has been proposed,5Collignon P Beggs JJ Walsh TR Gandra S Laxminarayan R Anthropological and socioeconomic factors contributing to global antimicrobial resistance: a univariate and multivariable analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e398-e405Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (293) Google Scholar but this explanation only considers human-made antibiotics, neglecting those produced in the environment. Antibiotics can eventually be used as food by other microorganisms, which in turn develop enzymes to digest them for consumption.9Hibbing ME Fuqua C Parsek MR Peterson SB Bacterial competition: surviving and thriving in the microbial jungle.Nat Rev Microbiol. 2010; 8: 115-125Crossref Scopus (1475) Google Scholar Most families of antibiotics can be used as growth factors for soil microorganisms, and the digestion of penicillin and its use as a sole source of carbon has been shown in Escherichia coli transformed in vitro. This finding shows that antibiotics not only kill microorganisms, but also serve as a nutrient, especially in areas rich in environmental microorganisms. In addition, some arthropods have been shown to be capable of secreting penicillins and cephalosporins, leading to a less simplistic view of antibiotics, selection pressure exclusively from human-made drugs, and resistance.10Pontarotti P Raoult D Why do arthropods secrete β-lactams?.Int J Antimicrob Agents. 2019; 53: 4370Crossref Scopus (3) Google Scholar Thus, β-lactam resistance genes are detected in all vertebrates, including humans, but also in archaea, which are not sensitive to β-lactams.11Keshri V Panda A Levasseur A Rolain JM Pontarotti P Raoult D Phylogenomic analysis of β-lactamase in archaea and bacteria enables the identification of putative new members.Genome Biol Evol. 2018; 10: 41106-41114Crossref Scopus (12) Google Scholar Hassell and colleagues' work6Hassell JM Ward MJ Muloi D et al.Clinically relevant antimicrobial resistance at the wildlife-livestock-human interface in Nairobi: an epidemiological study.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e259-e269Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar shows that in Nairobi, a city where antibiotic prescribing is extremely low,5Collignon P Beggs JJ Walsh TR Gandra S Laxminarayan R Anthropological and socioeconomic factors contributing to global antimicrobial resistance: a univariate and multivariable analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e398-e405Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (293) Google Scholar the level of resistance of E coli is particularly high, not only in humans, but also in wildlife. This study must put into perspective a much less anthropocentric approach, integrating the fact that antibiotics are probably more than 3 billion years old, as are antibiotic-resistance enzymes, and that we can only understand, and therefore combat antibiotic resistance, if we have a more scientific vision of this world. In conclusion, public health considerations can lead to substantial simplification of a complex issue, in particular to enable the dissemination of simple, understandable health-care messages; however, this process can lead to messaging that is partly false. This issue needs to be acknowledged by the scientific community. Control measures should not prevent the integration of recent scientific data for fear of misuse of antibiotics. This line of thought might end up being dangerous for humans, and more emphasis should be put on the complexity of the relationships between antibiotics and the enzymes that, among others, digest them. I declare no competing interests. Clinically relevant antimicrobial resistance at the wildlife–livestock–human interface in Nairobi: an epidemiological studyUrban wildlife carry a high burden of clinically relevant antimicrobial-resistant E coli in Nairobi, exhibiting resistance to drugs considered crucial for human medicine by WHO. Identifiable traits of the wildlife contribute to this exposure; however, compared with humans, livestock, and the environment, low phenotypic diversity in wildlife is consistent with the hypothesis that wildlife are a net sink rather than source of clinically relevant resistance. Wildlife that interact closely with humans, livestock, and both human and livestock waste within households, are exposed to more antimicrobial resistant phenotypes, and could therefore act as conduits for the dissemination of clinically relevant antimicrobial resistance to the wider environment. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Examining the influence of weather on rotavirus infection
display_name: Examining the influence of weather on rotavirus infection

author.au_affiliation_raw: Climate Change Group, Centre for Radiation, Chemical and Environmental Hazards, Public Health England, Didcot OX11 0RQ, UK
School of Veterinary Medicine, Department of Veterinary Epidemiology and Public Health, University of Surrey, Surrey, UK

ab: Determining the influence of climatic factors on infectious diseases can be complex and beset by technical and epidemiological problems, although there is value in establishing the contribution of the environment in general, and weather in particular, to disease occurrence in order to prepare for future alterations in climate.

title: Mission accomplished? A scoping review and bibliometric analysis of the term “planetary health” in the peer-reviewed literature
display_name: Mission accomplished? A scoping review and bibliometric analysis of the term “planetary health” in the peer-reviewed literature

author.au_affiliation_raw: School of Population and Public Health, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada
Department of Geography, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada
School of Population and Public Health, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada
School of Population and Public Health, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada
Faculty of Forestry, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada
Department of Forest and Conservation Sciences, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada
The George Institute for Global Health, University of Oxford, Oxford, UK

ab: BackgroundPlanetary health is an emerging holistic health field that aims to disrupt the boundaries of unidisciplinary research by fostering collaborations, integrating Indigenous knowledge, facilitating education, and driving public and policy engagement. To understand to what degree the field has been successful in meeting this mandate, we conducted a scoping review and bibliometric analysis of the term "planetary health" in the peer-reviewed literature.MethodsAn interdisciplinary research team conducted a systematic literature search in 14 databases. The search strategy examined the years 2005–18 with the term "planetary health" in title, abstract, or keywords; no limitations were used regarding language or geographical location. Search results were sorted into three different categories: commentaries, education, and original research. Results in the latter were categorised under the themes suggested by the Planetary Health Alliance. Obtained bibliographic data were analysed with the R bibliometrix package.FindingsOur inclusion criteria identified 180 articles. Preliminary analysis showed that most publications (n=153, 85%) were commentaries, calls to action or framework suggestions. 12 publications reported on educational content and 15 publications reported original research. The themes "nutrition" and "changing food systems" were most commonly discussed in the research papers while "urbanization" and "changing biochemical flows" were not discussed. Ten publications considered Indigenous knowledge and traditions. The number of publications remained low until 2014 but has tripled since 2017. The USA was the most productive country (32%), followed by the UK (16%), and Australia (9%). The most common keyword was "climate change", followed by "public health".InterpretationPlanetary health aims to bridge the gaps both between academic fields and beyond academia. However, based on the results of this study, the term is currently mostly used in commentary-like publications. We need to "spread the word" to better connect researchers, academic fields, and efforts worldwide and under the planetary health umbrella.FundingNone.
