title: Real-time PM2·5 air pollution and social preferences: a large-scale behavioural game study using mobile apps in mainland China
display_name: Real-time PM2·5 air pollution and social preferences: a large-scale behavioural game study using mobile apps in mainland China

author.au_affiliation_raw: Business School, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China
Shenzhen Audencia Business School, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China
Department of Geography and Resource Management, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China
Department of Sociology, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China

ab: BackgroundAir pollution undermines people's physical health. So why wouldn't people take actions to reduce air pollution? We argue that social preferences might play a part. Specifically, we examined the links between air pollution, interpersonal trust, and preferences to buy so-called sin stocks (companies that polluted the environment). Because previous research has shown that high pollution induces a belief in immorality as a social norm (akin to "broken-window" effect), we predicted that pollution is linked to lower trusting and trustworthy behaviours, and higher likelihood to buy sin stocks. Second, we examined the moderating role of participants' subjective socioeconomic status (SSES). Specifically, previous studies have shown that low SSES induces a feeling of deprivation and higher vulnerability. Therefore, we predicted an interaction between pollution and SSES, such that low SSES participants in highly polluted environment should display the lowest levels of trusting and trustworthy behaviours, and highest likelihood to buy sin stock.MethodsWe recruited 4177 participants residing in 31 provinces of mainland China during January, 2018. Participants were asked to play three incentivised behavioural games measuring their likelihood to buy sin stocks, trusting behaviour, and trustworthiness, respectively. We disseminated our survey via a mobile phone application, making it possible to pay the participants according to their performance on the games, and estimate the instantaneous, real-time air pollution (PM2·5) from dynamic monitoring station data based on each participant's GPS information.FindingsWe found a robust main effect of pollution and an interaction effect between SSES and real-time PM2·5 levels, as we had predicted.InterpretationOur findings counter the common wisdom that people are motivated to take actions to improve their own environment. Instead, a polluted environment could create a bad norm that undermines trust and environmental protection.FundingPartial funding came from a seed grant for the Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK)—Chinese Academy of Social Sciences (CASS) Research Collaboration on Social Psychology offered by the Research Committee of CUHK.

title: Exploring the effect of house screening: are we making gains?
display_name: Exploring the effect of house screening: are we making gains?

author.au_affiliation_raw: Communicable Diseases Cluster, Protection of the Human Environment, Regional Office for Africa, World Health Organization, Cite du Djoue, Brazzaville, PO Box 06, Republic of the Congo. Electronic address: chandae@who.int.
author.institution_display_name: World Health Organization Regional Office for Africa

ab: The steady decline in global malaria burden between 2000 and 2015 averted millions of deaths via diagnosis, treatment, and vector control, but disturbingly stagnated between 2016 and 2017, as shown in the WHO World Malaria Report 2018,1WHOWorld malaria report 2018. World Health Organization, Geneva2018https://www.who.int/malaria/publications/world-malaria-report-2018/en/Date accessed: March 2, 2019Google Scholar which signals a wake-up call for response. By 2017, approximately 70% of the 219 million malaria cases were ascribed to ten African countries and India. The report also revealed an estimated additional 3·5 million cases in 2017 compared with 2016 in sub-Saharan Africa, with only 50% coverage of effective vector control in this region.1WHOWorld malaria report 2018. World Health Organization, Geneva2018https://www.who.int/malaria/publications/world-malaria-report-2018/en/Date accessed: March 2, 2019Google Scholar Notably, the suboptimal coverage and the inherent need to strengthen vector control cannot be over-emphasised. Efforts have been galvanised in the context of integrated vector management through the WHO Global Technical Strategy for Malaria 2016–30 and the Global Vector Control Response 2017–30 with an ultimate goal of implementing effective, locally adaptive, and sustainable vector control.2Chanda E Measuring the effect of insecticide resistance: are we making progress?.Lancet Infect Dis. 2018; 18: 586-588Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (4) Google Scholar Regrettably, contemporary vector control efforts are characterised by various challenges such as insecticide resistance, epidemics and emergencies, and residual transmission.3WHOGuidelines for malaria vector control. World Health Organization, Geneva2019https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/310862/9789241550499-eng.pdf?ua=1Date accessed: March 2, 2019Google Scholar Mitigation measures include resistance management strategies (ie, larval source management) and use of innovative personal protective tools with low-certainty evidence for public health value (ie, topical repellents, insecticide treated clothing, and eave tubes).3WHOGuidelines for malaria vector control. World Health Organization, Geneva2019https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/310862/9789241550499-eng.pdf?ua=1Date accessed: March 2, 2019Google Scholar Although larviciding and house screening were key vector control interventions during the preinsecticide era4Boyd MF The influence of obstacles unconsciously erected against anophelines (housing and screening) upon the incidence of malaria.Am J Trop Med. 1926; 6: 157-160Crossref Google Scholar and during the malaria eradication era,5Watson RB Maher HC An evaluation of mosquito-proofing for malaria control based on one year's observations.Am J Hyg. 1941; 34: 86-94Google Scholar they have been relegated to supplementary tools because of perceived low community-wide impact. Several empirical and operational studies have assessed effectiveness of these strategies but results have received little recognition.6Gimnig JE Slutsker L House screening for malaria control.Lancet. 2009; 374: 954-955Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar In The Lancet Planetary Health, Gerry Killeen and colleagues7Killeen GF Govella NJ Mlacha YP Chaki PP Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of epidemiological data.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: 132-143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar report results of a re-analysis of an observational series of epidemiological survey data in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, on suppression of malaria vector densities and parasite prevalence by scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing.7Killeen GF Govella NJ Mlacha YP Chaki PP Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of epidemiological data.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: 132-143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar The findings indicated the positive correlation of an empirically fitted downward time trend in malaria prevalence and malaria vector biting densities with an upward trend in city-wide window screening coverage and progressive rollout of larviciding. Other than larviciding, no other vector-control intervention in malaria control practice was scaled up over the period of the study. Reductions in vector densities in this study were similar to those in other studies8Getawen SK Ashine T Massebo F Woldeyes D Lindtjørn B Exploring the impact of house screening intervention on entomological indices and incidence of malaria in Arba Minch town, southwest Ethiopia: a randomized control trial.Acta Trop. 2018; 181: 84-94Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar and attest to the potential of house screening to contribute significantly towards improvement in vector control. An earlier study in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, provided anecdotal evidence that improved housing might be associated with decreased malaria prevalence.6Gimnig JE Slutsker L House screening for malaria control.Lancet. 2009; 374: 954-955Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar The study by Killeen and colleagues7Killeen GF Govella NJ Mlacha YP Chaki PP Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of epidemiological data.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: 132-143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar provides further evidence on the effectiveness of house screening. The Article presents a business case for vector control with private sector involvement through corporate social responsibility mandates. Although optimally designing and implementing house improvements remains a daunting task, house screening is potentially feasible for community deployment. Despite the availability of some guidance on supplementary interventions,3WHOGuidelines for malaria vector control. World Health Organization, Geneva2019https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/310862/9789241550499-eng.pdf?ua=1Date accessed: March 2, 2019Google Scholar key questions still need addressing. For example, what definitive role does conventional house screening play as a resistance management approach relative to innovative combinations of eave tubes and insecticides? What would be the implications of waning physical integrity of the screening materials? Given the quite high cost, what would be the sustainable modality for community-wide scale-up? What is the effect of house screening on residual transmission? Good-quality housing is a crucial factor in reducing malaria transmission across the spectrum of malaria endemicity.3WHOGuidelines for malaria vector control. World Health Organization, Geneva2019https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/310862/9789241550499-eng.pdf?ua=1Date accessed: March 2, 2019Google Scholar Killeen and colleagues'7Killeen GF Govella NJ Mlacha YP Chaki PP Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of epidemiological data.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: 132-143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar findings fall within the context of research efforts to provide hard evidence for the public health value of house screening. Other analyses of house screening interventions for malaria control have had promising results8Getawen SK Ashine T Massebo F Woldeyes D Lindtjørn B Exploring the impact of house screening intervention on entomological indices and incidence of malaria in Arba Minch town, southwest Ethiopia: a randomized control trial.Acta Trop. 2018; 181: 84-94Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar, 9Kirby MJ Ameh D Bottomley C et al.Effect of two different house screening interventions on exposure to malaria vectors and on anaemia in children in The Gambia: a randomised controlled trial.Lancet. 2009; 374: 998-1009Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar that have informed guidance on housing and health.3WHOGuidelines for malaria vector control. World Health Organization, Geneva2019https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/310862/9789241550499-eng.pdf?ua=1Date accessed: March 2, 2019Google Scholar Eave tube technology that involves house proofing with window screens combined with insecticide treated inserts10Killeen GF Masalu JP Chinula D et al.Control of malaria vector mosquitoes by insecticide-treated combinations of window screens and eave baffles.Emerg Infect Dis. 2017; 23: 782-789Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar has been investigated as a mitigation approach for insecticide resistance. Recognising the need to curb environmental determinants of health, larviciding and house screening are being assessed in a multicountry project in southern Africa. Acknowledging the public health risk of not having an effective insecticide-based intervention, house screening remains useful by acting as a physical barrier. Killen and colleagues7Killeen GF Govella NJ Mlacha YP Chaki PP Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of epidemiological data.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: 132-143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar highlight the importance of intersectoral collaboration with involvement of the private sector and operational research to develop cost-effective models for promoting and subsidising effective scale-up. House screening is a fundamental supplementary tool where core interventions have reached full scale and could potentially address the challenge of diversity and sustainability of interventions through private–public sector partnerships. I declare no competing interests. Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of parasitological and entomological surveysCommunity-wide mosquito proofing of houses might deliver greater impacts on vector populations and malaria transmission than previously thought. The spontaneous nature of the scale-up observed here is also encouraging with regards to practicality, acceptability, and affordability in low-income settings. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Planetary health digest
display_name: Planetary health digest
ab: Climate change is a global issue, but the media coverage it receives differs between countries, including how it is framed and contextualised. How an issue is framed is influenced by the broader socioeconomic and political landscape that the media is embedded in, but how these factors apply to the framing of climate change coverage is not clear. Hong Tien Vu at the University of Kansas and colleagues investigated articles discussing climate change from 45 countries to identify the most popular frames and how national characteristics affected this framing. The most popular ways to frame climate change were in terms of international relations or its economic impacts. In wealthier nations the media were more likely to use domestic politics and scientific evidence framings. Poorer nations' coverage tended to focus on international relations and direct impacts such as rising temperatures and more frequent disasters. Understanding how climate change is framed the way it is can help with understanding the way that the public engage with it and subsequent policy responses. Murders of people defending the environment and the number of countries in which these murders took place have both increased over the past 15 years. In countries such as Brazil and the Philippines, the numbers of deaths in 2017 were sufficient to meet common definitions of an armed conflict (a minimum of 25 deaths per year). Nathalie Butt at the University of Queensland, and colleagues used a database of recorded killings of environmental defenders to investigate the drivers behind this violence, who was most at risk and why. They find that in 2017, 185 recorded killings were identified, with Indigenous peoples representing about 30% of the victims. Conflicts over resources were the core drivers of violence, with agriculture, mining, and logging the most common industries involved. Killings were more likely in countries with weak rule of law and high corruption, indicating the need for governments and private sector stakeholders to investigate their supply chains, commit to eliminating violence, and be held accountable on their performance. The UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) encompass a very ambitious and broadly-based set of objectives. Making progress on all these fronts while minimising trade-offs is a tremendously challenging task, and some goals may even have a degree of inherent incompatibility. These relationships between indicators, though much discussed, are rarely analysed in practice. To investigate the compatibility of human development and conservation efforts Judith Ament at the Zoological Society of London and colleagues explore relationships between indicators of human development and wildlife abundance—birds and mammals—in the landscape (outside of protected areas) between 1996 and 2015. In lower income country settings, they find negative relationships between human population growth and bird and mammal abundance but a positive relationship between economic growth and wildlife population trends. Encouragingly, these findings suggest that there is much potential compatibility between conservation and development agendas. However, effective policy integration is not a given and further systematic integration research and practice among sustainable development strategies and disciplines is warranted. The social cost of carbon—the net economic damage to society resulting from each additional ton of CO2 emitted—is an economic concept which exerts great influence on climate policy. Its value is computed with Integrated Assessment Models (IAMs). These are essentially comprised of a set of “damage functions” used to estimate harm to society per ton of CO2 emitted and monetise it. Noah Scovronick from Emory University and co-authors select the social cost of carbon for closer inspection because the damage functions used to monetise the impacts of carbon emissions have been developed largely by economists without active participation of other specialists including health researchers. Consequently, they argue that conducting research applicable to damage functions is a unique opportunity for health professionals to directly inform climate policy. They go on to summarise the damage functions of the three leading IAM's used to calculate the social cost of carbon and describe specific study design characteristics that will help make research results applicable to future damage function application.

title: Growing out of consumption?
display_name: Growing out of consumption?
ab: Just over a year ago, the IPCC published a Special Report outlining what it would take to prevent global heating of more than 1·5°C and 2°C above preindustrial levels, and the projected impacts of each outcome. For many climate change insiders this felt like it was going to be a “more of the same” report. One that provided updated and stronger, but largely confirmatory information on the emission cuts needed to avoid the most damaging effects of climate breakdown and meet the Paris Agreement objectives. In certain respects that was true, but the report has undoubtedly made an impact in the world as discussed in a Feature in this issue. One of the key messages, that if we are to limit warming to 1·5°C then greenhouse gas emissions need to be halved by 2030 and reach net zero by 2050 brought home in clear terms what Naomi Klein had previously observed about climate change, “This changes everything.” These cuts and the short time in which they need to be made reveal the climate crisis to be not simply a big bump in the road that stretches out before us, but a chasm that cannot be navigated through conventional means, and without wanting to stretch the analogy too far, a growing chasm caused by the very means of travel we have been utilising. There is, as yet, no agreed plan for accomplishing the herculean task of emissions reduction even among those who do not deny the overwhelming evidence of climate heating, and naturally people hold very different perspectives on how the chasm should best be navigated. Perhaps the most fundamental and therefore controversial question relates to the role of continuing global economic growth in the pursuit of planetary health. Economic growth as measured by Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is at the very core of the economic system we are accustomed to, and for many economic growth is the very engine needed for a green transition. Indeed, Sustainable Development Goal eight enshrines economic growthcentral to the 2030 Agenda. We have become so accustomed to equating GDP growth with human progress and increased wellbeing that it is almost heretical to question the necessity for ever more growth, but here is the crux of the issue. Economists tend to think of the economy as being freed from the material constraints of the world by the ingenuity of humankind, but empirical evidence shows that growth in the economy has always involved comparable growth in resource use. When Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, was recently challenged on the issue of endless growth being impossible on a finite planet he remarked that he does not accept that, arguing instead that “there is carbon-light growth, there is asset-light growth”. Is he right? The answer depends on whether we can decouple economic growth from carbon and wider resource use fast enough and to a sufficient extent to reach net zero carbon emissions by 2050 while the global economy grows by around 3% per year. This equates to a doubling just over every 20 years, or approximately once every generation. Investigations into the rate of decarbonisation required to meet the Paris objectives in a growing global economy show them to be well above what is likely achievable, based on modelling and historical evidence. This shortfall has been dealt with by assuming that negative emissions technologies can be brought in to fill the gap. However, these technologies remain almost completely untested at the scale required to meaningfully impact atmospheric CO2 levels. The IPCC 1·5° C report did investigate a scenario for reducing emissions in line with the Paris Agreement that does not rely on negative emissions technology development. This Low Energy Demand scenario assumes reductions in global energy consumption of 40% by 2050, making the transition to 100% clean energy much more achievable. The key feature of this scenario is that global material production and consumption declines significantly. In other words, a planned reduction in the material and energy throughput of the global economy; what is sometimes referred to as degrowth. It remains unclear whether the pursuit of endless global economic growth is the engine of our salvation or our demise, but there is enough evidence to have some scepticism that growth is always good for people and the planet. The issues at stake are too important for this to rest on thought experiments, and faith. If we are to tackle the ecological and climate emergencies and make progress on human wellbeing, we need to be willing to investigate the very heart of our economy. A year of pushing for 1·5°CTo many, it seemed unlikely to have an impact. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Air quality alerts benefit asthmatics – Authors' reply
display_name: Air quality alerts benefit asthmatics – Authors' reply

author.au_affiliation_raw: Dalla Lana School of Public Health, University of Toronto, Toronto, ON, Canada
Department of Epidemiology, Biostatistics and Occupational Health, McGill University, Montreal, QC, Canada
Department of Family Medicine and Public Health and Scripps Institution of Oceanography, University of California, San Diego, CA, USA

ab: We appreciate the comments by Kaylee Ho and colleagues1Ho K Paez J Liu B Air quality alerts benefit asthmatics.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: 518Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2) Google Scholar on our study,2Chen H Li Q Kaufman JS et al.Effect of air quality alerts on human health: a regression discontinuity analysis in Toronto, Canada.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e19-e26Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar in which we evaluated the influence of an air quality alert programme on a wide array of health outcomes in Toronto, Canada. The Correspondence by Ho and colleagues presented an analysis using the 2007–10 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey in the USA, showing that individuals who had asthma were more likely to change their behaviours in response to deterioration in air quality than those without asthma.3Zipf G Chiappa M Porter KS Ostchega Y Lewis BG Dostal J National health and nutrition examination survey: plan and operations, 1999–2010.Vital Health Stat 1. 2013; 56: 1-37Google Scholar Their finding adds to the ongoing scientific discussion as to whether an air quality alert programme might encourage avoidance behaviours (eg, reducing outdoor travelling and physical activities) on days with high levels of pollution. Although we applaud the efforts made by Ho and colleagues to provide an explanation to one of our findings that air quality alerts were related to some reduction in asthma-related emergency department visits, their method is somewhat unclear. Without presenting the number of non-asthmatics, there is some ambiguity as to whether the four strata (lifetime asthma, current asthma, asthma attack in the past year, and asthma emergency department visit in the past year) were indeed mutually exclusive. In addition, it is uncertain whether the question about behavioural changes was responded to by both asthmatics and non-asthmatics, or only by individuals with asthma. Furthermore, Ho and colleagues compared the proportion of individuals who changed activity because of poor air quality between asthmatics and non-asthmatics within each of the four strata. This appears to imply that individuals who do not have asthma were also included in the four strata. Despite our observation that air quality alerts were related to some decreases in asthma emergency department visits, we did not detect a reduction in any of the other health outcomes examined. One important implication of these findings is that measures focusing only on days with the highest levels of pollution are unlikely to help to address the most harmful effects of air pollution, given the role of long-term air pollution exposure as a risk factor for major chronic diseases such as cancer, cardiovascular diseases, and respiratory diseases. Although there is an increasing interest in developing innovative programmes, such as personalised systems to protect high-risk subgroups from air pollution, converging scientific evidence over the past decades suggests that air pollution problems are best addressed through collective and enforceable actions. Such actions could be improvement in fuel standards and emission control, especially targeting specific sources such as power generation and industries that contribute substantially to air pollution, and improvement in urban and transportation planning, rather than advising individuals and leaving to them to protect themselves from the harmful effects of air pollution. We declare no competing interests. Air quality alerts benefit asthmaticsWe have read with interest the Article by Hong Chen and colleagues,1 particularly the evidence of reductions in asthma-related emergency-department visits associated with air quality alert programmes in Toronto (ON, Canada). We have compared changes in activity between people with asthma and people who do not have asthma using representative data from the 2007–10 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey in the USA.2 Full-Text PDF Open Access

ab: The Lancet Planetary Health addressed the issue of coal mining in the USA and the need for a fast reduction in intensive coal use.1The Lancet Planetary HealthMining the USA.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: E324Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2) Google Scholar, 2The Lancet Planetary HealthIs the time for coal in Europe over?.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: E233Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1) Google Scholar It should be noted that the USA and the EU are adopting different policies concerning coal mining incentives and coal use. The EU has adopted a general framework to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide by 2050, including decreasing extraction and burning of coal. Some countries, such as the UK and Italy, have set their withdrawal from coal use even earlier (by 2025). In February, 2018, the new EU Emission Trade System was approved, fixing a limit to coal price reduction and funding technological innovations. Moreover, applied research projects have been funded for coal-free steel production in Austria (Voestalpine), Germany (Salzgitter), and Sweden (Lund-HYBRIT) to test steel production by use of hydrogen and natural gas, in the frame of a general perspective of Clean Steel fostered by the European Commission. These pilots were presented at the Europe Beyond Carbon conference held at the European Parliament (Brussels, Belgium) on June 20, 2018, with the involvement of the Lancet Commission on Pollution and Health, and in Taranto (Italy) on Nov 26, 2018. The EU has also launched the Coal Regions in Transition Platform, in which the European Commission and financial institutions (eg, World Bank) set up bilateral meetings with mining regions to fund transition to a coal-free economy. A specific Horizon 2020 Call was opened to support actions for the development of regional roadmaps towards decarbonisation in coal-intensive regions. The European perspective on decarbonisation and long term emissions reduction was officially presented (EU's vision for a modern, clean, and competitive economy) by the European Commission on July 10–11, 2018, at the University of Brussels (Brussels, Belgium) as an important step towards COP24 held in Katowice, Poland, promoted by the UN to address the issue of climate change and its consequences on planetary health. The ambitious objective of coal use reduction set for 2050 should promote a deep reconsideration of the future of the EU steel industry, in which the traditional and low-value steel coming from coal-intensive processes does not have a long-term future. The EU should promote a new generation of plants able to produce clean and intelligent steel (with innovative material properties and characteristics). The new multiannual financial programme (2020–27) should devote relevant resources to stimulate and accelerate these changes and support Member States to create favourable conditions for a new sustainable and intelligent steel market. Mining the USAOn June 20, US President Donald Trump announced his intention to open up large areas of Minnesota's Superior National Forest to industrial activity, a move likely to benefit the mining company Twin Metals Mining Minnesota, which has previously expressed interest in this region. More precisely, Trump's plan is to undo one of his predecessor Barack Obama's final acts as president, a 20-year ban on industrial activity across about 234 000 acres of the national forest while studies on the potential environmental impacts of any mining-related activity are completed. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Antibiotic resistance, stewardship, and consumption – Authors' reply
display_name: Antibiotic resistance, stewardship, and consumption – Authors' reply

author.au_affiliation_raw: ACT Pathology, Canberra Hospital, Canberra, ACT, Australia
Monarch Institute, Melbourne, VIC, Australia
Microbiology Research, School of Medicine, Cardiff University, Cardiff, UK
Center for Disease Dynamics, Economics & Policy, Washington, DC, USA
author.institution_display_name: Center for Disease Dynamics, Economics & Policy

author.au_affiliation_raw: Center for Disease Dynamics, Economics & Policy, New Delhi, India
author.institution_display_name: Center for Disease Dynamics, Economics and Policy

ab: We agree with Koen B Pouwels and colleagues, that association does not mean cause and effect. In our paper, we acknowledged limitations in using national-level data on antibiotic usage and resistance patterns, and that antibiotic use is an important factor in antibiotic resistance. We note that our results, which show that the spread of resistant bacteria by anthropological factors is at least as important as antibiotic use, are supported by other studies.1Baker S Thomson N Weill FX Holt KE Genomic insights into the emergence and spread of antimicrobial-resistant bacterial pathogens.Science. 2018; 360: 733-738Crossref PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar Antibiotic sales data (IQVIA MIDAS database) have limitations, but these data provide the only source of harmonised global information on antibiotic consumption. Others have validated IQVIA MIDAS and demonstrated strong correlation with data from the European Surveillance of Antimicrobial Consumption Network.2Klein EY Van Boeckel TP Martinez EM et al.Global increase and geographic convergence in antibiotic consumption between 2000 and 2015.Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2018; 115: E3463-E3470Crossref PubMed Scopus (1355) Google Scholar We used global resistance data on 114 member states from WHO. We also used data from ResistanceMap and interrogated literature searches on Escherichia coli resistance. The results we observed were similar across the datasets. Some associations could be surrogates for other markers that are underappreciated—even Pouwels' example of meticillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus linked to unfair play of national football teams. This behaviour might reflect the culture of a country where rules are more often ignored, and thus, where support for hand hygiene campaigns, sensible antibiotic use and adequate public infrastructure are more likely scarce. Previous multivariate analysis3Collignon P Athukorala PC Senanayake S Khan F Antimicrobial resistance: the major contribution of poor governance and corruption to this growing problem.PLoS One. 2015; 10: e0116746Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar has also shown that higher levels of corruption are associated with higher antibiotic resistance rates. Others have shown that greater corruption is associated with higher regional antibiotic usage volumes within Europe.4Rönnerstrand B Lapuente V Corruption and use of antibiotics in regions of Europe.Health Policy. 2017; 121: 250-256Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar We used multiple regression analysis to disentangle many of the issues raised by Pouwels and colleagues. Since there is collinearity between some of the explanatory variables (eg, health system strength and antibiotics consumption), we observed a narrower list of statistically significant associations with multiregression than in our univariate analysis. Pouwels' supplementary figure, using purely simulated datapoints, serves to illustrate the well known problem that arises in interpreting simple bivariate correlations. Such graphs could equally well be drawn to imply a positive correlation of usage and resistance when in fact the underlying relationship is negative. The graphs in our appendix demonstrate that when important explanatory variables are not accounted for in the modelling (eg, poor infrastructure, poor health care expenditure), aggregated data can imply either a spurious positive or a spurious negative correlation between usage and resistance, even when there is no underlying relationship. We do not agree with Cédric Abat and colleagues, that “all simplifications including stating that antibiotic consumption in humans and animals favours the emergence of antibiotic resistance appear inherently wrong.” Rather, we agree there are examples where antibiotic usage does not correlate with observed resistance levels; however, there are also examples where positive linkages have been found.3Collignon P Athukorala PC Senanayake S Khan F Antimicrobial resistance: the major contribution of poor governance and corruption to this growing problem.PLoS One. 2015; 10: e0116746Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar, 5Nasrin D Collignon PJ Roberts L Wilson EJ Pilotto LS Douglas RM Effect of beta lactam antibiotic use in children on pneumococcal resistance to penicillin: prospective cohort study.BMJ. 2002; 324: 28-30Crossref PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar, 6Goossens H Ferech M Stichele RM Elseviers M Outpatient antibiotic use in Europe and association with resistance: a cross-national database study.Lancet. 2005; 365: 579-587Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1542) Google Scholar We agree with what seems implicit in Abat's letter and associated references—namely, that a reduction of antibiotic consumption alone will not be sufficient to control antimicrobial resistance. We think that improving sanitation, increasing access to clean water, ensuring good governance, and increasing public health-care expenditure are all necessary to reduce global antimicrobial resistance. We believe that our conclusion remains appropriate, that contagion—the spread of resistant strains and resistance genes—seems to be a dominant contributing factor to global antibiotic resistance. This online publication has been corrected. The corrected version first appeared at thelancet.com/planetaryhealth on March 4, 2019 This online publication has been corrected. The corrected version first appeared at thelancet.com/planetaryhealth on March 4, 2019 TRW is HEFC funded by the UK Government. SG is supported by a grant from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. RL is supported by IPA 16IPA1609427 from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to Princeton University. Download .pdf (.6 MB) Help with pdf files Supplementary appendix Anthropological and socioeconomic factors contributing to global antimicrobial resistance: a univariate and multivariable analysisReduction of antibiotic consumption will not be sufficient to control antimicrobial resistance because contagion—the spread of resistant strains and resistance genes—seems to be the dominant contributing factor. Improving sanitation, increasing access to clean water, and ensuring good governance, as well as increasing public health-care expenditure and better regulating the private health sector are all necessary to reduce global antimicrobial resistance. Full-Text PDF Open AccessAntibiotic resistance, stewardship, and consumptionPeter Collignon and colleagues1 aim to improve understanding of global antibiotic resistance drivers by quantifying associations between antibiotic resistance and potential contributing factors. A recent systematic review including 565 studies primarily reporting patient-level data found that antibiotic exposure, underlying disease, and invasive procedures had the greatest evidence of being antibiotic resistance drivers.2 Given the small evidence base for the role of community factors,2 we fully concur with Collignon and colleagues about the importance of considering such factors in the spread of antibiotic resistance. Full-Text PDF Open AccessAntibiotic resistance, stewardship, and consumptionWe read with interest the work of Peter Collignon and colleagues,1 in which the authors studied the effect of cofactors on the prevalence of precise antibiotic resistance profiles. Amongst their discoveries, the authors identified inverse relationships between global antibiotic consumption and the antibiotic resistance profiles that they studied. Full-Text PDF Open AccessCorrection to Lancet Planet Health 2019; 3: e68Collignon P, Beggs JJ, Walsh TR, Gandra S, Laxminarayan R. Antibiotic resistance, stewardship, and consumption–Authors' reply. Lancet Planet Health 2019; 3: e68—The webappendix of this Correspondence was not included with the publication and has been added online as of March 4, 2019. Full-Text PDF Open Access

Legal Initiative for Forest and Environment, New Delhi, India
New Delhi 110078, India

ab: Scientific evidence is the foundation of environmental and health-related policies and strategies.1Oxman AD Lavis JN Lewin S Fretheim A SUPPORT Tools for evidence-informed health Policymaking (STP) 1: what is evidenceinformed policymaking?.Health Res Policy Syst. 2009; 7: S1Crossref PubMed Google Scholar Best practices to promote the use of research evidence in policy making include timely and relevant findings, production of credible reports, and findings that can be translated into actionable recommendations. Despite recognition of these best practices, the gap between research and the translation of findings into policy and practice is wide, especially in low-income and middle-income countries (LMICs). Research done by academics rarely matches the needs of policy makers. Policy makers are often more interested in whether the results of research are implementable than in the research itself. Therefore, whereas most academics view the outcome of their research as useful for informing policy, their research often has little utility for policy formulation.2Lavis JN Oxman AD Lewin S Fretheim A SUPPORT Tools for evidence-informed health Policymaking (STP) 3: Setting priorities for supporting evidence -informed policymaking.Health Res Policy Syst. 2009; 7: S3Crossref PubMed Scopus (0) Google Scholar The mismatch between funder priorities and local needs also renders research evidence inadequate for translation into policy.3Chalmers I Bracken MB Djulbegovic B et al.How to increase value and reduce waste when research priorities are set.Lancet. 2014; 383: 156-165Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (860) Google Scholar The communication gap between researchers, funders, and policy makers further reinforces the mismatch. All these factors result in a failure to use evidence in policy making and action. This failure highlights the need for research to be informed and prioritised by stakeholder needs, to ensure that research evidence is translated to policy and practice.4Ioannidis JPA Greenland S Hlatky MA et al.Increasing value and reducing waste in research design, conduct, and analysis.Lancet. 2014; 383: 166-175Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (907) Google Scholar Social, economic, scientific, engineering, and medical evidence is used to support development of policy and delivery of services to the public. The translation of evidence to policy and practice can be especially problematic in the environmental health domain, particularly in countries with lax regulations, where business practices leading to illegal pollution are the norm, and where citizens often lack informational, organisational, legal, and political resources to mobilise support for action. In such instances, regulatory interventions through the justice courts have often proven to be successful (panel).PanelExamples of environmental litigationsIn 2013, the National Green Tribunal in India blocked plans for a 1050 MW coalfired power plant in Korba, Chattisgarh, on the grounds that the area was already critically polluted and the environmental impact assessment failed to consider the cumulative impact due to the proposed project.5Environmental Law Alliance WorldwidePolluting Coal Plant Stopped in Cuddalore.https://www.elaw.org/polluting-coal-plant-stopped-in-cuddaloreDate: 2014Date accessed: January 13, 2019Google ScholarIn 2003, in the case of Washington Toxics Coalition versus the US Environmental Protection Agency, the District Court ruled in favour of Washington Toxics Coalition and banned the use of 54 pesticides from waters supporting salmon populations in California, Oregon, and Washington.6US Environmental Protection AgencyEndangered Species Case—Washington Toxics Coalition v. EPA.https://www.epa.gov/endangered-species/endangered-species-case-washington-toxics-coalition-v-epaDate: 2018Date accessed: January 13, 2019Google Scholar In 2013, the National Green Tribunal in India blocked plans for a 1050 MW coalfired power plant in Korba, Chattisgarh, on the grounds that the area was already critically polluted and the environmental impact assessment failed to consider the cumulative impact due to the proposed project.5Environmental Law Alliance WorldwidePolluting Coal Plant Stopped in Cuddalore.https://www.elaw.org/polluting-coal-plant-stopped-in-cuddaloreDate: 2014Date accessed: January 13, 2019Google Scholar In 2003, in the case of Washington Toxics Coalition versus the US Environmental Protection Agency, the District Court ruled in favour of Washington Toxics Coalition and banned the use of 54 pesticides from waters supporting salmon populations in California, Oregon, and Washington.6US Environmental Protection AgencyEndangered Species Case—Washington Toxics Coalition v. EPA.https://www.epa.gov/endangered-species/endangered-species-case-washington-toxics-coalition-v-epaDate: 2018Date accessed: January 13, 2019Google Scholar In 2015, pollution was responsible for an estimated 9 million premature deaths, an overwhelming majority of which were in LMICs:7Landrigan PJ Fuller R Acosta NJR et al.The Lancet Commission on pollution and health.Lancet. 2017; 391: 462-512Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2009) Google Scholar an estimate that has prompted litigation against governments for inaction and against polluters for flouting rules. Judicial interventions, initiated by affected communities, citizen groups, and environmental organisations, have argued for the right to a clean and pollution-free environment and against corruption and inaction, within a human rights framework. Scientific evidence and conclusions are central to environmental litigation and are frequently contested.8Sali K Scientific evidence in environmental litigation.Nat Resources Environ. 2016; 30: 1-4Google Scholar Although the legal profession uses research evidence to affect policy change and action across the world in pollution abatement, it has been left out as a key stakeholder of research uptake. Public-interest lawyers often lack the tools and skills to critically appraise scientific literature; nor do they have the technical expertise or support from domain experts to provide supporting scientific evidence for their arguments. The scientific community for its part is apprehensive or not well informed of the legal procedures and court processes. This highlights the need for the environmental and public health research community to engage and collaborate with legal professionals to provide the relevant scientific evidence necessary to manage litigation processes. Additionally, the research community needs to recognise the legal pathway for formulating evidence-informed policies and the opportunities and challenges to produce evidence that is relevant to the legal community. The Lancet Commission7Landrigan PJ Fuller R Acosta NJR et al.The Lancet Commission on pollution and health.Lancet. 2017; 391: 462-512Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2009) Google Scholar on pollution and health—citing the example of India's National Green Tribunal, which provides its citizens with access to an independent judiciary to redress pollution injustices—suggests that countries must develop such legal mechanisms to advance environmental justice and reduce inequitable exposure of the poor and the marginalised. To strengthen such legal mechanisms, we believe that greater collaboration between the legal and environmental and public health communities is necessary. Such collaboration will provide impetus for the generation of research evidence that can strengthen the legal mechanisms and increase policy-level interventions for pollution control, especially in poorly regulated LMICs. We declare no competing interest.

title: Antibiotic resistance, stewardship, and consumption
display_name: Antibiotic resistance, stewardship, and consumption

author.au_affiliation_raw:
IHU Marseille - Institut Hospitalier Universitaire Méditerranée Infection (IHU - Méditerranée Infection
19-21 Bd Jean Moulin
13005 MARSEILLE 
FRANCE - France)

VITROME - Vecteurs - Infections tropicales et méditerranéennes (IHU Méditerranée Infection
19-21 Bd Jean Moulin
13005 Marseille - France)

MEPHI - Microbes évolution phylogénie et infections (IHU Méditerranée Infection
19-21 Bd Jean Moulin
13005 Marseille - France)

ab: We read with interest the work of Peter Collignon and colleagues,1Collignon P Beggs JJ Walsh TR Gandra S Laxminarayan R Anthropological and socioeconomic factors contributing to global antimicrobial resistance: a univariate and multivariable analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e398-e405Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (293) Google Scholar in which the authors studied the effect of cofactors on the prevalence of precise antibiotic resistance profiles. Amongst their discoveries, the authors identified inverse relationships between global antibiotic consumption and the antibiotic resistance profiles that they studied. Although some of the links they published remain for us unclear, these inverse relationships between antibiotic resistance and antibiotic consumption confirm our Alice's living croquet theory.2Raoult D Alice's living croquet theory.Int J Antimicrob Agents. 2016; 47: 249Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar Indeed, this theory, based on the game croquet illustrated in the novel Alice in Wonderland, suggests that it is impossible to predict the future for living beings, as the living world is governed by several factors and interactions that no single mathematical model can explain. As this tenet can also be applied to antibiotic resistance, all simplifications including stating that antibiotic consumption in humans and animals favours the emergence of antibiotic resistance appear inherently wrong. First, antibiotic resistance is not new and might result from a long history of intermicrobial conflict.3Rolain J-M Abat C Jimeno M-T Fournier P-E Raoult D Do we need new antibiotics?.Clin Microbiol Infect. 2016; 22: 408-415Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar Second, in patients hospitalised at our institution for bacteraemia and cerebrospinal fluid infections, the proportion of infections caused by invasive meticillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus decreased from 31·0% in 2001 to 12·8% in 2015, which occurred without any screening or isolation procedures being performed.3Rolain J-M Abat C Jimeno M-T Fournier P-E Raoult D Do we need new antibiotics?.Clin Microbiol Infect. 2016; 22: 408-415Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar We recently identified in low-income and middle-income countries that the increases in antibiotic consumption inversely paralleled deaths caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae, leading us to warn against the inclination to limit antibiotic consumption in these countries.5Abat C Gautret P Raoult D Benefits of antibiotics burden in low-income countries.Proc Natl Acad Sci. 2018; 115: e8109-e8110Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar The results from Collignon and colleagues1Collignon P Beggs JJ Walsh TR Gandra S Laxminarayan R Anthropological and socioeconomic factors contributing to global antimicrobial resistance: a univariate and multivariable analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e398-e405Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (293) Google Scholar support our conclusions. We declare no competing interests Anthropological and socioeconomic factors contributing to global antimicrobial resistance: a univariate and multivariable analysisReduction of antibiotic consumption will not be sufficient to control antimicrobial resistance because contagion—the spread of resistant strains and resistance genes—seems to be the dominant contributing factor. Improving sanitation, increasing access to clean water, and ensuring good governance, as well as increasing public health-care expenditure and better regulating the private health sector are all necessary to reduce global antimicrobial resistance. Full-Text PDF Open AccessAntibiotic resistance, stewardship, and consumptionPeter Collignon and colleagues1 aim to improve understanding of global antibiotic resistance drivers by quantifying associations between antibiotic resistance and potential contributing factors. A recent systematic review including 565 studies primarily reporting patient-level data found that antibiotic exposure, underlying disease, and invasive procedures had the greatest evidence of being antibiotic resistance drivers.2 Given the small evidence base for the role of community factors,2 we fully concur with Collignon and colleagues about the importance of considering such factors in the spread of antibiotic resistance. Full-Text PDF Open AccessAntibiotic resistance, stewardship, and consumption – Authors' replyWe agree with Koen B Pouwels and colleagues, that association does not mean cause and effect. In our paper, we acknowledged limitations in using national-level data on antibiotic usage and resistance patterns, and that antibiotic use is an important factor in antibiotic resistance. We note that our results, which show that the spread of resistant bacteria by anthropological factors is at least as important as antibiotic use, are supported by other studies.1 Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Attribution of reductions in malaria prevalence in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania
display_name: Attribution of reductions in malaria prevalence in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Epidemiology, Biostatistics, and Occupational Health, McGill University, Montreal, QC H3A 1A2, Canada
Department of Global Health and Population, Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA

ab: Dar es Salaam's Urban Malaria Control Project (UMCP) was launched in 2004 with the objective of implementing and assessing a microbial larviciding intervention. From 2004 to 2008, malaria prevalence decreased from 28% to less than 2%.1Maheu-Giroux M Castro M Impact of community-based larviciding on the prevalence of malaria infection in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.PLoS One. 2013; 8: e71638Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar This collapse of malaria vector populations was also observed in neighbouring regions of Tanzania.2Meyrowitsch DW Pedersen EM Alifrangis M et al.Is the current decline in malaria burden in sub-Saharan Africa due to a decrease in vector population?.Malar J. 2011; 10: 188Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar Part of the reduction preceded the initiation of larviciding activities and the introduction of artemisinin-based combination therapies. Yet, previous analyses suggested that larviciding was effective in reducing malaria prevalence.1Maheu-Giroux M Castro M Impact of community-based larviciding on the prevalence of malaria infection in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.PLoS One. 2013; 8: e71638Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar, 3Lawson AB Carroll R Castro M Joint spatial Bayesian modeling for studies combining longitudinal and cross-sectional data.Stat Methods Med Res. 2014; 23: 611-624Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar In their Article, Gerry Killeen and colleagues4Killeen GF Govella NJ Mlacha YP Chaki PP Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of parasitological and entomological surveys.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e132-e143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar reanalysed the UMCP data. Although it is reassuring that most of their results confirm those previously reported, their paper raises important concerns. First, the rollout of larviciding followed a stepped-wedge design. It involved sequential crossover of the city's wards from control to intervention such that, ultimately, all wards received the larviciding intervention. This implies that calendar time is a potentially crucial confounder and, following standard practice, must be included in the analyses.5Hemming K Haines TP Chilton PJ Girling AJ Lilford RJ The stepped wedge cluster randomised trial: rationale, design, analysis, and reporting.BMJ. 2015; 350: h391Crossref PubMed Scopus (661) Google Scholar Substituting another covariate for time in the model could grossly overestimate the intervention's impact. A second concern is that the authors mistakenly state that earlier analyses did not adjust for within-ward covariance. This is incorrect because previously reported odds ratios for larviciding included this adjustment in sensitivity analyses using ward-level fixed effects—confirming their robustness. The advantage of this specification is that it controls for “any time-invariant measured or unmeasured confounders of the larviciding-malaria relationship”,1Maheu-Giroux M Castro M Impact of community-based larviciding on the prevalence of malaria infection in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.PLoS One. 2013; 8: e71638Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar which is especially important for the UMCP whose larviciding allocation sequence was not randomised. Using fixed effects therefore provides a more robust estimate than using a random effects specification. Third, attributing changes in an observed health outcome to one specific intervention requires an appropriate control group. Although it is plausible that improved house proofing had a role in reducing malaria transmission, attributing the reduction to this factor alone, as implied by their analyses substituting calendar time, does not follow principles of causal attribution. The authors disregard household-level variations in house proofing to use city-wide coverage (with unrealistic discrepancies between the two estimates) and do not consider potential confounders. From 2002 to 2012, Dar es Salaam's population increased from 2·5 million to 4·3 million people and its density nearly doubled. There were noticeable reductions in urban agriculture, increases in bednet usage, introduction of artemisinin-based combination therapy, and clear improvements in literacy and socioeconomic status during the UMCP. The decision to attribute the bulk of the malaria decline to improved housing seems arbitrary and could misguide public health efforts by overstating its potential benefits. We declare no competing interests. Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of parasitological and entomological surveysCommunity-wide mosquito proofing of houses might deliver greater impacts on vector populations and malaria transmission than previously thought. The spontaneous nature of the scale-up observed here is also encouraging with regards to practicality, acceptability, and affordability in low-income settings. Full-Text PDF Open AccessAttribution of reductions in malaria prevalence in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania – Authors' replyWe thank Mathieu Maheu-Giroux and Marcia Castro for their Correspondence about our Article.1 Regarding concerns about the stepped-wedge design of the larviciding scale-up in our study, we agree and also note that scale-up was not randomised, but rather introduced earliest to the best-prepared wards. However, such compromises are normal and healthy in pragmatic assessments of effectiveness under realistic programmatic conditions, rather than efficacy under artificially controlled experimental conditions. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Daisies March: a Brazilian initiative in planetary health and gender equity
display_name: Daisies March: a Brazilian initiative in planetary health and gender equity

author.au_affiliation_raw: Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, Porto Alegre, Brazil
author.institution_display_name: Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul

author.au_affiliation_raw: World Organization of Family Doctors, Bangkok, Thailand

ab: Since 2000, in its first edition, the Daisies March has been consolidating itself as one of the largest social movements of women in Latin America, focusing in the fight against violence and in the search for autonomy for the women of rural areas, forests, and riversides, in a way inherently related to the socio-environmental sustainability of their communities and to the notion of planetary health. Recent studies have shown that actions that associate, for example, the reduction of carbon emissions to the promotion of gender equity, are more effective in their environmental results and in the more equitable distribution of income generated.1Cook NJ Grillos T Andersson KP Gender quotas increase the equality and effectiveness of climate policy interventions.Nat Clim Chang. 2019; 9: 330-334Crossref Scopus (36) Google Scholar In this project, we present the process of transformation of the guidelines claimed in the 2019 March in a didactic unit, suitable for popular education actions to be conducted by partners of the National Confederation of Agricultural Workers. The planned educational actions promote the voices of Rural Workers' Unions, family farmers, and public schools for the development of debates and referral of local actions aimed at more equal access to land and water; the development of local agroecological techniques; the food and energy sovereignty of rural, forest, and riversides communities; the conservation of socio-biodiversity; access to public health; economic autonomy, work, and income for women; and access to sexual and reproductive rights. As a pilot study, the actions will be conducted in five different municipalities of Rio Grande do Sul, during the year 2019, through a partnership with the Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul and have raised possible actions aiming to increase gender equity and promote planetary health. Contributors TC is an academic consultant of National Confederation of Agricultural Workers (CONTAG), for the development of activities of 2019 Daisies March. EFdB has contributed to the introduction of planetary health concept in the discussions promoted by this women's social movement. Declaration of interests We declare no competing interests.

title: Photo voice as a participatory approach to influence climate related health policy in the Sundarbans
display_name: Photo voice as a participatory approach to influence climate related health policy in the Sundarbans

author.au_affiliation_raw: Indian Institute of Public Health, Bhubaneswar, India
Independent Consultant in Environmental Health and Policies, Delhi, India
Independent Consultant, Kolkata, India

ab: The IPCC Fifth Assessment Report highlights community-based strategies to drive effective and ecologically sustainable local adaptation strategies. A climate change hot spot, Sundarbans, India, needs collective action between communities and for local level health and non-health decision makers to find sustainable solutions to combat the impacts of climate change on child health. In our photovoice study, mothers examined mediating factors by which climate change was impacting their child's health. Over 80 mothers with at least one child aged 0–6 years took photographs to document the impact of climate change on factors affecting child health. During facilitated fortnightly group meetings, mothers identified and categorised the major factors affecting their children's health. Participants collectively selected the photographs most reflective of the mediating factors and presented their findings to the local and state health administrations to identify mutually agreeable solutions. Mothers identified five mediating factors. These included food security, livelihood, water and sanitation, accessibility of the health-care system, and breaching of embankments. The findings were presented by the mothers to community-level and state-level policy makers. The interactions resulted in the initiation of resilient road infrastructure, increased human resource availability in primary health centres during floods, and local government representatives demanding long-term adaptation strategies to address climate impacts. Child health is affected by climate change through multiple pathways. Participatory approaches like photo voice can be used effectively to reflect ground level experiences of climate-vulnerable communities, empower them, and provide a collaborative and inclusive platform to design policies and initiatives for the creation of climate resilient health systems and communities. Funding Future Health System Research consortium funded by DFID. Contributors UG drafted the abstract which was modified by BS and SB. UG and SB are the co-investigators of the study. BS is the supervising author. Declaration of interests We declare no competing interests.

title: An arts-based approach to community documentation and revitalization of nutritious and drought-tolerant indigenous crops for climate change adaptation
display_name: An arts-based approach to community documentation and revitalization of nutritious and drought-tolerant indigenous crops for climate change adaptation

author.au_affiliation_raw: The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada

ab: Indigenous knowledge and traditional practices around indigenous small grains are critical tools in the quest to improve community health and adapt to climate change. As a scholar and an artist, I work with Indigenous communities in Sikkim in the Indian Himalayas and in Mazvihwa, Zimbabwe, documenting nutritious and drought-tolerant indigenous small grains using arts-based methodologies, such as drawing. This course of study began with my 13 months of fieldwork (2011–12) in the Lepcha Indigenous community in Sikkim. I demonstrated how dependence on a monocultural cardamom agricultural system introduced in the 1950s had collapsed due to plant disease while local agricultural biodiversity was being lost. This research used both qualitative and quantitative methods, involving case studies at three scales on land use changes in the Lepcha territory following the expansion of cardamom. The first is a coarse-grained GIS study of land use change for the village from 1989 to 2012. The other two are fine-grained key-informant interview studies—one on land use change, and the second on the persistence of traditional food plants. I found a decline in crop diversity in the area devoted to the monocultural cardamom cash crop system. Thus I documented 36 neglected traditional food plants with my illustrations, including 16 indigenous small grains, and 20 gathered plants, representing 14 different plant families. Decreased cash crop production was also evident in Mazvihwa. During the preliminary field study in 2016, I found that indigenous small grains survived in the fields significantly more often than monocultural maize. There I conducted drawing workshops, created an opportunity for community members to reconnect to the neglected plants, and to revalue their Indigenous knowledge. My project builds a collective community resource as communities reflect on their traditional skills and knowledge around neglected small grains, contributing to maintaining agricultural biodiversity and ultimately contributes to planetary health. Funding Scott Travel Scholarship from the Department of Landscape Architecture and Environmental Planning, UC Berkeley, and the Public Scholar Initiative of The University of British Columbia. Declaration of interests I declare no competing interests.

title: Estimating health-related costs of ten US climate-sensitive events in 2012: a retrospective study
display_name: Estimating health-related costs of ten US climate-sensitive events in 2012: a retrospective study

author.au_affiliation_raw: Natural Resources Defense Council, New York, NY, USA
University of California-San Francisco, San Francisco, CA, USA
Natural Resources Defense Council, New York, NY, USA
Natural Resources Defense Council, New York, NY, USA

ab: BackgroundClimate change threatens human health, but there is a lack of evidence on the economic toll of these risks. Health-related cost estimates for climate-sensitive impacts illuminate an understudied impact of climate change and highlight how this threat is affecting sectors beyond property and infrastructure. Furthermore, cost estimates can guide health interventions and help public health professionals assess whether climate change adaptation measures are achieving their intended benefits.MethodsWe estimate mortality and morbidity costs associated with ten climate-sensitive case studies spanning eleven US states in 2012 (when the country experienced some of its warmest weather to date); the case studies include wildfires, extreme heat, West Nile Virus and Lyme disease, extreme precipitation and flooding, harmful algal blooms, allergenic pollen, ozone air pollution, and a major hurricane. We estimate the mortality and morbidity associated with each event using data reported in peer-reviewed epidemiology studies, state and federal data, and environmental public health tracking network data collected by state public health agencies. We augment this information with imputed incidence data from national healthcare utilisation statistics.FindingsApplying value of a statistical life and cost-of-illness approaches to publicly-available data from the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, we estimate total health-related costs associated with these case studies (from 917 deaths, 20 568 hospitalisations and 17 857 emergency department visits) of about $10·0 billion in 2018 dollars, with a sensitivity range of $2·7 billion to $24·6 billion.InterpretationBy better characterising these health damages in economic terms, this work helps characterise the burden that climate change already places on human health. In doing so, we provide a quantitative framework for broader estimation of climate-sensitive health-related costs. Expanded quantification of the budgetary pressures posed by climate change can help decision makers engage with the scale of the challenge and prioritise efficient adaptation strategies to protect public health.FundingNone.

title: Understand the effect of environmental and structural migration factors on the sexual and reproductive health of youth in central Asia and Africa: a modelling study
display_name: Understand the effect of environmental and structural migration factors on the sexual and reproductive health of youth in central Asia and Africa: a modelling study

author.au_affiliation_raw: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, USA
Harvard T H Chan School of Public Health, Cambridge, MA, USA
Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, USA
Harvard T H Chan School of Public Health, Cambridge, MA, USA

ab: BackgroundEvery year millions of young people between the ages of 10 and 24 years in central Asia and Africa migrate to urban areas in search of better opportunities. Common factors driving youth migration include environmental degradation, war and conflict, and lack of economic opportunity and poverty. In collaboration with the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), our aim was to study the effect of migration on the sexual and reproductive health (SRH) needs of youth in Nairobi, Cairo, Beirut, and Tunis through the development of technological solutions for data collection and identification of youth most vulnerable to SRH issues.MethodsWe designed a web application useful for both migrants and researchers that contains a 27-question survey to collect migrant data on basic profile metrics such as their geographical journey and their sexual relations. This data can be used to inform the UNFPA's service, delivery, and policy efforts. The website also features a geographical healthcare centres map and safety tips for migrants. Additionally, we artificially created a dataset of 1000 migrant profiles to train a machine learning model to predict SRH vulnerabilities in young people.FindingsThe neural network model and the support vector machines algorithm demonstrated high accuracies of 0·92 and 0·90 respectively in predicting the most vulnerable youth. We optimised our algorithm to minimise false-negatives, even at the cost of a few false-positives.InterpretationOur results provide an opportunity to identify vulnerable youth for local officials to potentially reach out to in order to prevent SRH issues and to understand how such vulnerabilities might stem from their environmental and structural migration factors. Furthermore, researchers can investigate based on data collected from the web application how overcrowding of migrants in urban areas outstrips the areas of resources to further compromise the SRH health of the migrants.FundingNone.

title: Valuation of the urban environment by its potential impact on human health: a modelling study for the UPSTREAM project
display_name: Valuation of the urban environment by its potential impact on human health: a modelling study for the UPSTREAM project

author.au_affiliation_raw: University of Bath, Bath, UK
University of Bath, Bath, UK

ab: BackgroundUrban environments are placing an increasing burden on our life support systems. Research is needed further upstream in urban governance and on the role of economic valuation in critical decision-making. The three-year pilot study, Moving Health Upstream in Urban Development (UPSTREAM), funded by Wellcome, has made a small, but important contribution to research in this area. We report here on the results of the workstream to quantify the scale of the impact that the built environment has on health in monetary terms.MethodsFollowing a systematic literature review carried out by University of the West of England, observed health impacts associated with different characteristics of the environment were applied to a hypothetical population of 1000 people. Unit values for the societal cost of around 60 health outcomes were defined using existing valuation evidence. Reference values were established for the intervals between worst-case and best-case scenarios in the UK new build housing context.FindingsWe estimated the societal value of health impacts arising from 26 characteristics of the built environment, including green space, air quality, noise, overheating and proximity to a main road. It is possible to use these findings to compare the relative importance of each feature.InterpretationEven in the context of a well-regulated sector, the UK new build environment shows potential for significant differences in health impacts between the best and worst quality of design. Although interior conditions such as thermal comfort are important, it is the wider environmental context such as green space and air quality where the largest impacts occur. We have shown that this potential for change can be monetised in terms of the impact on health, using a metric that might be useful for social planners.FundingThe Wellcome Trust.

title: Looking for leaders
display_name: Looking for leaders
ab: A good proportion of our editorial column space this year has been devoted to the stream of scientific reports summarising the full extent of the global climate and biodiversity emergencies we face and the popular movements that have arisen as a result of the lacklustre and frankly insufficient government and business response to these emergencies. Last month saw one of the largest coordinated international demonstrations in history. An estimated six million people took to the streets in the youth led climate strikes timed to try to influence the UN Climate Action Summit in New York. These movements are certainly raising the profile of climate change and the need to rapidly cut emission and reverse ecological degradation. The overall picture from the summit though was disappointing, we still aren't seeing decarbonisation at the scale and pace needed to even have a 50% chance of meeting the Paris Agreements objectives. In particular most of the plans submitted by the major economies lacked sufficient ambition with few national leaders displaying any real idea how they will implement their existing emissions reduction commitments let alone ramp up their ambition. This is perhaps not surprising since the scale of the challenge is large, and it represents a major departure from business as usual thinking and planning. It's all too easy for difficult decisions to be put off for others and for national leaders to blame other nations for not doing enough to curb their emissions. As a concerned citizen seeing our socio-political juggernaut on a collision course and taking little evasive action what options do we have? For many the answer is to rebel. October is set to witness an International Rebellion lead by the group Extinction Rebellion (XR). Many participants are willing to go a stage further than the climate strikers and in addition to taking to the streets to demonstrate the scale of public support for action to avert environmental crises there will be many acts of peaceful civil disobedience. We won't know the scale of these efforts until after this issue is published but events are planned in cities from Toronto, New York, Sydney, Buenos Aries and Istanbul to name just a few. Given how effective previous such rebellions have been in raising the profile of climate and ecological breakdown earlier this year it is hard to imagine this will not have further impact no matter how you might feel about the disruption. It seems those in the highest corridors of power really haven't woken up to how serious these challenges are or how significant the level of public feeling is becoming. The traditional academic approach to policy change is to provide ever more and better information and hope that politicians, legislators and the business community are paying attention and become convinced by the arguments. That approach has proved largely unsuccessful so far, particularly in mobilising climate change mitigation actions, but the combination of public activism backed up with authoritative scientific assessments does seem a powerful one. It's hard to dismiss these activists, even teenagers taking time off school, when the arguments they make are largely a correct representation of the best available science. The protests represent both a counter-culture movement, challenging existing social and economic norms, and an appeal to the conventional authority of science. The IPCC's latest Special Report on the ocean and cryosphere released in September provided an update on the scientific picture since the IPCC's fifth assessment report (AR5) – published in 2013-14. There is little that will surprise those who have read previous reports but it is noteworthy that many changes are occurring at a rate and magnitude erring towards the high end of projected scenarios. The report serves to remind us that everyone depends directly or indirectly on the ocean and cryosphere, and warns that communities in close connection with coastal environments, small islands, polar regions and high mountains are particularly exposed to projected levels of sea level rise, glacier melt and permafrost thaw. The report reiterates the need for urgent and ambitious emissions reductions coupled with sustained and ambitious adaptation actions to avert the climate impacts that are already locked in. If you are concerned about climate change and ecological collapse and their implications for society, there is a great deal of evidence that you are right to be concerned but little conventional leadership in taking the steps necessary to address these issues. What choice do people have left but to peacefully rebel?
