topics.display_name: Renewable Energy, Sustainability and the Environment

title: Planetary health digest
display_name: Planetary health digest
ab: Groundwater extraction by pumping from underground aquifers is crucial to support agriculture and other human activities in areas where surface water supplies are insufficient. However, extraction often far exceeds the recharge rate of these aquifers, leading to falls in groundwater levels. As the groundwater level drops, the patterns of discharge into rivers, lakes, and other freshwater environments also change, with potentially devastating consequences for these ecosystems. Inge de Graaf, University of Freiburg, Germany, and co-authors investigated the impact of groundwater pumping on groundwater discharge, identifying where environmentally critical streamflow reductions are already occurring and where they can be expected to occur in the future. They find that these environmental flow limits have already been reached in a substantial proportion of the world's watersheds in which pumping occurs (15–21% depending on the climate projections used), and that this number is expected to grow significantly by 2050 (estimates of 42–79%). With this illustration of the scope of the challenges ahead, the authors call for the integration of groundwater requirements into any future assessment of worldwide water sources. Seafood is the most rapidly expanding food production sector and has been proposed as having a key role in sustainable diets. Existing mechanisms to encourage sustainability in the industry have largely focused on governmental regulations, market-based approaches (eg, certification), and voluntary commitment by companies. The role of financial mechanisms has been speculated on but has so far remained understudied. Using a content analysis of two leading seafood-focused media outlets, qualitative examples, and descriptive statistics of shareholder analysis, Jean-Baptiste Jouffray from the Stockholm Resiliency Centre, Sweden, and colleagues aimed to identify key financial leverage points for encouraging sustainability in the seafood sector. These leverage points focus on mainstream financial mechanisms and can be divided into actions from three types: sustainability covenants on loans from banks, stock exchanges requiring certain environmental criteria be met for a company to be listed, and shareholder activism. While these mechanisms are, by their nature, restricted to larger businesses, they could exert a powerful influence and might also be relevant to other extractive industries. The urban heat island (UHI) effect is a well known consequence of urbanisation and the resulting replacement of natural environments with constructed ones. It can have serious consequences for human health, as elevated temperatures pose direct risk for conditions such as dehydration and heat stress, as well affecting existing disorders such as cardiovascular and respiratory diseases. With the continuing growth of the world's urban population and the diversity of these cities it is important to understand the which populations are most at risk. To this end, Tirthankar Chakraborty from the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, USA, and colleagues conducted an analysis of 25 cities around the world, looking at the neighbourhood-level UHI effect and income to identify socioeconomic disparities. The results differed with city characteristics, but the majority (18 [72%] cities) had UHI effects that disproportionately affected people on lower incomes, and these effects were closely correlated with indices of urbanicity and greenness. The authors' findings suggest that city-specific measures will be needed to tackle the issue of UHIs, and that doing so could be one way to tackle the issue of health inequalities within cities. Fires in Indonesia are a major source of particulate matter pollution both within the country and in neighbouring countries in equatorial Asia. Furthermore, they represent a significant contribution to global greenhouse gas emissions, with fires in 2015 releasing an amount of CO2 equivalent to the yearly fossil fuel combustion of India or Japan. These fires are mainly from land clearance for cultivation or wildfires during drought periods, which are exacerbated by the drainage of carbon-rich peatlands. Miriam Marlier from the RAND Corporation, Santa Monica, USA, and co-authors created a decision-support tool to estimate the magnitude of fire emissions over the coming decades, their public health impacts, and the gains that could be made with various land management approaches. They report that the PM2·5 released by these fires would be responsible for an average of 36 000 excess deaths per year across Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore, and that the majority (>60%) of these emissions were the result of fires on peatlands. The study highlights the importance of policies to block fires in peatlands, which the authors predict could prevent two-thirds of these excess deaths. For more on seafood production see https://advances.sciencemag.org/content/5/10/eaax3324 For more on seafood production see https://advances.sciencemag.org/content/5/10/eaax3324

title: Correction to Lancet Planet Health 2018; 2: e329–30

title: Record breakers
display_name: Record breakers
ab: The last 22 years contain 20 of the warmest (global average) years on record. This trend is powerfully demonstrated by the popular #Showyourstripes initiative. That most of the warmest years have occurred very recently is hardly surprising given that our planet is being heated by increasing amounts of heat trapping CO2 in the atmosphere—primarily emitted from burning fossil fuels. In this context 2019, which has seen a number of record-breaking heatwaves, is displaying exactly the sorts of conditions that we should expect to see more and more often. Indeed, the trend is now so clear that it almost seems mundane to talk about temperature records being broken again, as climate vlogger Adam Levy (@ClimateAdam) put it “it's hard to talk about all this constant record breaking without sounding like a broken record”. In January persistent high-pressure in the Tasman Sea blocked cold fronts and cooler air, contributing to a prolonged heatwave across much of Australia with many records being broken. Temperatures peaked at 49·1°C (120°F) at Marble Bar in northwestern Australia and extreme temperatures persisted over much of the country for several weeks. Combined with severe drought, the hot weather facilitated major wildfire outbreaks in the southeast of Australia. Heat took its toll on wildlife too with mass fish deaths and fruit bats falling dead from trees among the reported impacts. In May and early June, India and Pakistan experienced two pronounced heatwaves. Temperatures reached 48°C (118°F) in some areas and though reported deaths vary, it's clear that the numbers are in the high hundreds to over a thousand. Failure to maintain an adequate supply of electricity and water to prevent heat-related deaths and sickness lead to public protests in many regions. Clearly there is much room for improved heatwave planning before the next such event in the region. In late June Europe experienced an atmospheric pressure system, which allowed hot air from north Africa to travel up into Europe where it led to temperatures up to 10°C above normal for the month. Historical records at locations in France, Switzerland, Austria, Germany, the Czech Republic, and Spain were all broken, with Spain experiencing its worst wildfires in 20 years in the sweltering dry conditions. A Comment in this issue provides some context for understanding if this is the new norm, how bad things might get, and whether heat planning has improved since the disastrous events of 2003. In addition to becoming “old news”, heatwaves have several other public relations problems. Press coverage of heatwaves tends to focus on images of sun bathers and people playing in fountains, thus failing to recognise the more dangerous and life-threatening side of extreme heat. Furthermore, although we know from historical heatwave events that the numbers of excess deaths—those beyond the normal level of mortality for a given period—are often high they can only be identified statistically as data becomes available following the event. Consequently, the deaths reported in the media tend to be the relatively small number of people who died from direct heat-related conditions. This can make heatwaves feel relatively unthreatening and even pleasant in much media coverage. Furthermore, as pointed out in a Correspondence in this issue, where the media covers ways to avoid the worst impacts of heat they focus on individual vulnerabilities and behaviours rather than on social factors like income, housing quality, social networks, and healthy workplaces. More balanced reporting of social factors would help cast the problem as one of public health and not just individual behaviours. It's not all bad news though, an Article in this issue indicates that there was a reduction in heat-related mortality, at least from cardiovascular disease, in Spain between 1980 and 2016, although this wasn't explicitly down to climate adaptation. Perhaps even more encouragingly heat wave plans in Europe developed after 2003 do seem to have increased preparedness, reducing the negative impacts of the heatwave, although that will not be fully clear for some months. These plans also benefited from accurate forecasts, the temperature record in France was forecast by Météo-France three days in advance. It is certain that we will experience more and more extreme heat events and there is plenty of room for improved planning to adapt to these changes and minimise their impacts, in addition to cutting the carbon emissions which are driving the problem. For the #ShowYourStripes initiative see https://showyourstripes.info/For more on Australia's extreme temperatures see http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/current/statements/scs68.pdf For the #ShowYourStripes initiative see https://showyourstripes.info/ For more on Australia's extreme temperatures see http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/current/statements/scs68.pdf The day the 2003 European heatwave record was brokenOn June 28, 2019, a temperature of 45·9°C was recorded at a weather station in France, exceeding the country's previous temperature record—set during the infamous 2003 heatwave—by almost 2°C. The heatwave peaked over central and northern Europe, fuelled by a very persistent planetary-scale Rossby wave (giant meanders in upper-tropospheric winds), which turned into an omega block, so named because its shape resembles the Greek letter (Ω). This blocking event led to hot air from northern Africa being transferred to Europe (figure). Full-Text PDF Open AccessMisdiagnosing vulnerability to heatwaves in the mediaYet again we are faced with news about temperature records being broken. As regions, countries, cities, and individuals experience more frequent, intense, and extended heatwaves,1 people often turn to the media for advice on coping with what is already a substantial public health problem. For example, media coverage by television, radio, and newspapers has long been dominated by the medical model of health2 and its general advice on heat avoidance. This advice typically includes restricting physical activity, wearing loose and light-coloured clothing, drinking more water, cooling the body, and protecting against sunburn. Full-Text PDF Open AccessTrends in temperature-related age-specific and sex-specific mortality from cardiovascular diseases in Spain: a national time-series analysisIn Spain, the observed warming of the climate has occurred in parallel with substantial adaptation to both high and low temperatures. The reduction in the RR and the attributable fraction associated with heat would be compatible with an adaptive response specifically addressing the negative consequences of climate change. Nevertheless, the simultaneous reduction in the RR and attributable fraction of cold temperatures also highlights the importance of more general factors such as socioeconomic development, increased life expectancy and quality, and improved health-care services in the country. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Planetary health research digest
display_name: Planetary health research digest
ab: The contributions that nature makes to humans depend on local social and ecological factors, but there is a lack of high-resolution data mapping the magnitude of these contributions at a global scale. Rebecca Chaplin-Kramer, from Natural Capital Project at Stanford University, and colleagues selected water quality regulation, coastal risk reduction, and crop pollination as examples of these natural contributions to investigate. They used modelling and open-source data to produce spatially explicit global estimates of these contributions and people's needs for them, and combined these with three diverse scenarios from the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways to investigate possible future changes. The resulting estimates showed that, in many parts of the world where nature's contributions are the most beneficial to people, the ability of nature to provide them will decline, particularly in Africa and south Asia. Without sustainable development policies being enacted, billions of people will be put at risk of higher water pollution and lost crop production due to insufficient pollination. By mapping these natural contributions and people's needs for them, future locally appropriate policies can be designed to close the gaps between them. A large proportion of the species most at threat in the planet's ongoing biodiversity crisis are small arthropods. Land use has been indicated to be a key driver of arthropod biodiversity loss, but there have been few large scale studies into the specific elements responsible for this decline. Sebastian Seibold of the Terrestrial Ecology Research Group at the Technical University of Munich, and colleagues investigated changes in arthropod diversity and biomass across 150 grassland and 140 forest sites in Germany between 2008 and 2017 and how land use types affected these changes. They found declines in biomass and species diversity across grassland and forest sites, with additional reductions in abundance in grassland sites. Declines occurred at all trophic levels and in grasslands, the declines were greater in areas of increased arable land cover. These findings add to the argument that land use practices should be considered across the landscape rather than just the land being managed. Phasing out fossil fuels will be crucial to achieving the goals of the Paris Agreement, but policies to do so will need to be acceptable to the public to be effective. The phasing out of fossil fuel-powered cars presents a particular challenge given the scale of the effect this will have on people's daily lives. Adrian Rinscheid, from the Institute for Economy and the Environment of the University of St Gallen, and colleagues set out to identify what would be most publicly acceptable in policies to phase out fossil fuel-powered cars in the USA. They used a demographically representative sample of 1520 US residents who were asked to rate 24 320 hypothetical policy scenarios in a conjoint experiment to identify which characteristics made policies appealing. The policies identified as being most acceptable were those that took effect no later than 2030, used subsidies rather than taxes or bans, afforded greater (ie, >30%) reductions in pollution, and cost the least. Endorsement by trusted groups also improved acceptability, but depended on individual preferences (eg, political party affiliation). The authors make the case for early adoption of softer policy measures over more distant, but stronger options such as bans and taxes. Dietary risk factors are a major cause of non-communicable disease burden in India, including low fruit and vegetable consumption. While average fruit and vegetable consumption in India has previously been reported to be low compared with WHO-recommended levels (400 g/person/day), the key socioeconomic and demographic drivers of consumption remain unknown. Samira Choudhury, of the Centre for Development, Environment and Policy at SOAS University of London, and colleagues analysed data from a nationally representative survey of household consumption and expenditure in India for 2011–12. They found that median fruit and vegetable consumption was low at 200 g/person/day, with a highly unequal distribution. The only variables with a significant effect among the lowest percentiles of consumption were household income and belonging to socioeconomically disadvantaged castes or tribes. Although economic growth could potentially raise incomes, downstream policies that directly affect consumers, such as government provided fruit-and-vegetable-rich meals, could have more rapid effects and be more directly targeted at disadvantaged groups. Fore more on mapping nature's contributions see https://science.sciencemag.org/content/366/6462/255.fullFore more on arthropod biodiversity see https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-019-1684-3Fore more on fossil fuel phase out see https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/14693062.2019.1677550Fore more on fruit and vegetables in India see https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2211912419300884#! Fore more on mapping nature's contributions see https://science.sciencemag.org/content/366/6462/255.full Fore more on arthropod biodiversity see https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-019-1684-3 Fore more on fossil fuel phase out see https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/14693062.2019.1677550 Fore more on fruit and vegetables in India see https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2211912419300884#!

title: To Paris via land
display_name: To Paris via land
ab: On August 2–7, the IPCC convened to approve a new report, Climate Change and Land: an IPCC special report on climate change, desertification, land degradation, sustainable land management, food security, and greenhouse gas fluxes in terrestrial ecosystems. As the report outlines, the continuing growth of the world's population and wealth has so far depended heavily on the expansion of land use for forestry and agriculture, with more than 70% of the ice-free surface of the Earth now being directly affected by human activity. However, as land use intensifies, so too do the risks of land degradation, desertification, and increasing greenhouse gas emissions that contribute to climate change, further enhancing these threats to food security and biodiversity. Central to understanding climate change is that land can be both a source and a sink of greenhouse gases: the net effect depends on the use this land is put to and the way that it is managed. CO2 sequestration by soils and vegetation, for example, act to reduce the concentration of atmospheric greenhouse gases, while methane emissions from rice cultivation and ruminant livestock rearing, and the conversion of excess nitrogen fertilisers to nitrogen oxides are contributors to the growth in atmospheric greenhouse gases. During 2007–16, land acted as a sink for an estimated 11·2 GtCO2 per year, or roughly 29% of total CO2 emissions, according to the report. However, whether the land can continue to sustain this sink is directly threatened by climate change. Together agriculture, forestry, and other land uses are estimated to produce the equivalent of 12·0 GtCO2 per year, or 23% of anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions. As such, land-based adaptation and mitigation responses are crucial to addressing climate change. Probably the most discussed of the responses included in the IPCC report are those related to food systems, particularly diets. Like previous reports on sustainable food systems, it discusses the potential benefits of populations adopting more varied and balanced diets incorporating more plant-based foods, as well as the use of more sustainable agricultural practices and strategies to reduce food waste. However, the report is not confined to food, and the authors present other possible mitigation and adaptation approaches across a range of settings, including sustainable forest management, direct interventions to prevent or reverse desertification, and conservation of high-carbon ecosystems such as peatlands. The problems facing the way we use land are closely interrelated, and consequently so are the solutions, with most options having many potential co-benefits. For example, approaches aiming to restore degraded land could also enhance its ability to act as a carbon sink, as well as provide benefits to local biodiversity and/or food security. While land-based mitigation will be essential to keeping the global temperature increase below 1·5°C, or even 2°C, there are limits to what this can achieve. As well as the clear logistical and financial challenges involved, there are also huge cultural ones, such as those involving dietary change. Land ownership and access is another thorny issue; in many of the most vulnerable communities, the people working the land and most exposed to the effects of degradation and climate change are not recognised as land owners. Without secure land tenure, it is difficult to implement any long-term plans to enhance sustainability, but any solutions involving land ownership reform will require significant political will behind them. The intrinsically finite area of land available for mitigation, food production, wildlife, cities and almost everything else we do is also a key challenge. Large-scale conversion of land for purposes such as afforestation and reforestation—and especially growth of crops for bioenergy—need to be implemented carefully to avoid creating new risks for land degradation and food security, among other problems. Despite the challenges There is much that must be accomplished through careful land use and management. The IPCC report makes it clear that two of the most important prerequisites for achieving meaningful change will be having a clear climate target and identifying which combinations of solutions nations are willing to implement. The Paris Agreement largely addresses the former, whereas the latter will need discussion and implementation in the imminent future. What is certain is that change is needed, and it is needed soon. With the close links between land and climate, deferring action is only going to make these challenges steeper.

concepts.display_name: Land use, land-use change and forestry

title: Looking backwards and forwards
display_name: Looking backwards and forwards
ab: Looking back over 2019 through a planetary health lens, the key themes of the year might be emerging public awareness and advocacy, and inadequate practical action. The rhetoric around climate change has notably changed with “climate emergency” and “climate breakdown” and “public health emergency” being increasingly used to describe the various climate challenges we are inflicting upon ourselves. In Iceland, a plaque commemorating the former Okjökull glacier—the first officially lost to the climate crisis—displays text that perfectly captures the climate zeitgeist: “This monument is to acknowledge that we know what is happening and what needs to be done. Only you know if we did it.” The value and potential for youth leadership has also emerged as a key theme over the last year, while the IPBES global assessment report also brought home the true severity of the biodiversity crisis that we are facing. Meanwhile, many of the sustainable development goals are looking increasingly far from being achievable by 2030, with some even worsening. These are not disparate unconnected problems, but are all maladies of our current socioeconomic system; the net effect is far from what we could reasonably describe as a state of planetary health. In the last 70 years we have radically changed both our lives and the world around us. This has benefited many people, but the environmental cost has been enormous, such that our current course is simply unsustainable even if it were ideal. And clearly for many, indeed most people, it is far from ideal. The health implications of unchecked climate heating are also becoming increasingly clear as laid out in the latest Lancet Countdown report. “A business as usual trajectory will result in a fundamentally altered world… the life of every child born today will be profoundly affected.” At the time of writing, political leaders and climate diplomats are meeting in Madrid for the UN Climate Change Conference (COP25). It is hoped that countries will ramp up their decarbonisation pledges during 2020 prior to the critical meeting next year in Glasgow. So far, the negotiations in Madrid have been dominated by conflict over the “Article 6” rules, for international cooperation, especially carbon markets, and how to support countries that have been irreversibly harmed by climate change—known as loss and damage. These are important components of the Paris Agreement that need to be nailed down, but given that emissions are still rising it's hard not to wonder if this is going to be enough. So, what's the block? Why is so little actually happening to change anything? This is the question so many young people are angrily asking. The Paris Agreement introduced a system of voluntary mitigation pledges over the old top-down approach of strict emissions limits, although these limits do still exist aspirationally. It has been argued that this voluntary approach resulted in a process that no longer focussed on what is environmentally desirable, but rather on what is politically feasible. Such an approach seems to have been largely effective in overcoming diplomatic gridlock, but it is vulnerable to a growing inconsistency between talk, policy, and action. Perhaps because of the need for politically expedience, policies to date have focused on enabling rapid deployment of renewable energy, with some notable success, but with few parallel policies designed to actively phase out fossil fuel technologies. Arguably, without a much stronger focus on directly cutting the use, or at least emissions from, fossil fuels, carbon emissions are likely to continue to grow in parallel with clean energy capacity. It's easy to see that policies designed to directly limit or reduce fossil fuel use will be politically contested far more than those designed to promote relatively clean technologies, so perhaps we haven't really sidestepped the tough negotiations but simply kicked them down the road once more. We have focused primarily on the climate emergency here given the ongoing COP25 conference and the importance of climate stability to all other endeavours, but issues of human development and protection of nature are no less important or crosscutting. As we move increasingly from only providing evidence of the nature of the problems we face to also prioritising and implementing solutions, we need to embrace the inherently political nature of those choices. As has been identified in climate change adaptation, these choices need to be understood as sociopolitical processes rather than politically neutral managerial decisions. If we cannot take that step, then the gap between talk and action is likely to continue to confound us.

ab: We welcome the comments from Bence Mátyás concerning our Article about the associations between suicide mortality and green and blue space.1Helbich M Beurs DD Kwan MP O'Connor RC Groenewegen PP Natural environments and suicide mortality in the Netherlands: a cross-sectional, ecological study.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e134-e139Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar Here, we would like to respond to his two observations. First, Mátyás commented that our study was not “the first of its kind” and corroborated this statement with a reference to Nutsford and colleague's 2016 retrospective study.2Nutsford D Pearson AL Kingham S Reitsma F Residential exposure to visible blue space (but not green space) associated with lower psychological distress in a capital city.Health Place. 2016; 39: 70-78Crossref PubMed Scopus (191) Google Scholar After careful deliberation, we concluded that his observation is only partly valid because, as he correctly states in their Correspondence, Nutsford and colleague's study correlates blue space with psychological stress, but not with suicide mortality. We acknowledge, as we do in the Article, that evidence about the potential salutogenic effects of blue space on mental health is mounting. However, we stress that whether this evidence applies to suicide mortality, remains an open question. Second, Mátyás queries the absence from our models of psychological wellbeing. His observation is correct and, as in any ecological study with official statistics, the difficulty is that such important personal level variables are often absent. Indeed, as a result of such limitations, we did not attempt to draw final conclusions on these matters, although we did raise them as topics for further research to understand the underlying mechanisms. We declare no competing interests. This research received funding from the European Research Council under the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation program (grant agreement number 714993). Natural environments and suicide mortality in the Netherlands: a cross-sectional, ecological studyOur findings support the notion that exposure to natural environments, particularly to greenery, might have a role in reducing suicide mortality. If confirmed by future studies on an individual level, the consideration of environmental exposures might enrich suicide prevention programmes. Full-Text PDF Open AccessSuicide mortality and natural environmentsMarco Helbich and colleagues' important Article1 investigated the correlation between suicide mortality and natural outdoor environments, such as green (grass, forests, and parks) and blue (visible bodies of lakes, rivers, and seas) spaces. One of their findings contradicted their hypothesis, which stated that coastal proximity is negatively associated with suicide mortality. When discussing their study, the authors found that blue space visibility did not necessarily correlate with mental health. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Suicide mortality and natural environments
display_name: Suicide mortality and natural environments

author.au_affiliation_raw: Universidad Politécnica Salesiana, Ecuador, Rumuchaca y Morán Valverde S/N, 1712536 Quito, Ecuador. Electronic address: bmatyas@ups.edu.ec.

ab: Marco Helbich and colleagues' important Article1Helbich M Beurs DD Kwan MP O'Connor RC Groenewegen PP Natural environments and suicide mortality in the Netherlands: a cross-sectional, ecological study.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e134-e139Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar investigated the correlation between suicide mortality and natural outdoor environments, such as green (grass, forests, and parks) and blue (visible bodies of lakes, rivers, and seas) spaces. One of their findings contradicted their hypothesis, which stated that coastal proximity is negatively associated with suicide mortality. When discussing their study, the authors found that blue space visibility did not necessarily correlate with mental health. Then, however, they add that they believe their study is the first of its kind, so they are not sure whether their findings are specific to their case study. This study is very valuable and comprehensive. Nevertheless, it should be mentioned that there was a retrospective study published 2 years earlier by Nutsford and colleagues2Nutsford D Pearson AL Kingham S Reitsma F Residential exposure to visible blue space (but not green space) associated with lower psychological distress in a capital city.Health Place. 2016; 39: 70-78Crossref PubMed Scopus (195) Google Scholar who found that a higher visibility of blue space is associated with lower psychological distress. Helbich and colleagues' analyses were based on the officially registered suicide deaths per municipality for the period 2005–14 in the Netherlands. Considering that suicide mortality was studied in Helbich and colleagues' study, and not other factors that correlate with psychological wellbeing (such as percieved self-efficacy, autonomy, competence, intergenerational dependence, and self-actualisation)3WHOThe world health report 2001. Mental health: new understanding, new hope. World Health Organization, Geneva2001Google Scholar, the authors' statement should be refined to something like “Our finding is that blue space is not necessarily associated with suicide mortality”. With this minor correction, the apparent contradiction could be dispelled because suicide mortality was the only factor analysed, and other factors contributing to overall wellbeing (such as those previously mentioned) were not analysed. Conversely, modelling of data is one of the most important means of drawing conclusions from analyses. Helbich and colleagues' analyses is a well-structured and seemingly reliable. Furthermore, to aid the reader's understanding of the present study's findings, it is important to draw attention to positive findings from other (previously published) studies that have explored a similar hypothesis. I declare no competing interests. Natural environments and suicide mortality in the Netherlands: a cross-sectional, ecological studyOur findings support the notion that exposure to natural environments, particularly to greenery, might have a role in reducing suicide mortality. If confirmed by future studies on an individual level, the consideration of environmental exposures might enrich suicide prevention programmes. title: Temperature-related mortality and climate change in Australia – Authors' reply

Department of Public Health, Environments and Society, London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, University of London, London WC1E 7HT, UK

ab: We thank Thomas Longden for his Correspondence, in which he offers insightful comments on some publications from our research team on temperature-related mortality projections under climate change scenarios.1Gasparrini A Guo Y Sera F et al.Projections of temperature-related excess mortality under climate change scenarios.Lancet Planet Health. 2017; 1: e360-e367Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (365) Google Scholar, 2Vicedo-Cabrera AM Guo Y Sera F et al.Temperature-related mortality impacts under and beyond Paris Agreement climate change scenarios.Clim Change. 2018; 150: 391-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar His letter provides us with the opportunity to discuss some aspects in more detail, and to clarify specific debated issues. The focus of Longden's Correspondence is on the projected temperature-related impacts for Australia under different climate change scenarios, found in our analyses, which show a different pattern when compared with those in other regions of the world, specifically a net decrease in temperature-related mortality. This difference can be explained by a projected decrease in cold-related deaths that is higher than the increase in heat-related mortality. However, providing a context for correctly interpreting such findings is important. First, some estimates are quite uncertain, and the relatively wide confidence intervals include ranges that are in fact compatible with a net increase (see for instance the right-bottom panel of figure 3 in our Article).1Gasparrini A Guo Y Sera F et al.Projections of temperature-related excess mortality under climate change scenarios.Lancet Planet Health. 2017; 1: e360-e367Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (365) Google Scholar Second, as shown in the same graph and in figures 1 and 2 in Vicedo-Cabrera and colleagues' publication,2Vicedo-Cabrera AM Guo Y Sera F et al.Temperature-related mortality impacts under and beyond Paris Agreement climate change scenarios.Clim Change. 2018; 150: 391-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar the net change is stronger for milder climate change scenarios, whereas the pattern reverses and the net change is less clear for more extreme warming. Finally, and most importantly, both publications define such scenarios as global temperature trajectories or changes, but they explicitly state that in all of these scenarios, Australia is projected to experience a milder temperature increase if compared with the other regions assessed in these investigations (see table 2 and the figure in the appendix [p 12] of our Article).1Gasparrini A Guo Y Sera F et al.Projections of temperature-related excess mortality under climate change scenarios.Lancet Planet Health. 2017; 1: e360-e367Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (365) Google Scholar Longden then reports results from an article he authored, in which an alternative method based on endogenously determined thresholds was used to estimate cold-related and heat-related deaths in five Australian cities.3Longden T Measuring temperature-related mortality using endogenously determined thresholds.Clim Change. 2018; 150: 343-375Crossref Scopus (8) Google Scholar We value the comparison with other approaches; however, we would like to point out that the analytical framework we applied is the result of an intense methodological development for environmental epidemiological studies that has occurred in the past two decades,4Schwartz J Spix C Touloumi G et al.Methodological issues in studies of air pollution and daily counts of deaths or hospital admissions.J Epidemiol Community Health. 1996; 50: S3-S11Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 5Dominici F Samet JM Zeger SL Combining evidence on air pollution and daily mortality from the 20 largest US cities: a hierarchical modelling strategy.J R Stat Soc Ser A Stat Soc. 2000; 163: 263-302Crossref Google Scholar providing study designs and statistical techniques validated in simulation studies6Peng RD Dominici F Louis TA Model choice in time series studies of air pollution and mortality.J R Stat Soc Ser A Stat Soc. 2006; 169: 179-203Crossref Scopus (415) Google Scholar, 7Gasparrini A Modelling lagged associations in environmental time series data: a simulation study.Epidemiology. 2016; 27: 835-842Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar and used in hundreds of publications.8Basu R High ambient temperature and mortality: a review of epidemiological studies from 2001 to 2008.Environ Health. 2009; 8: 40Crossref PubMed Scopus (758) Google Scholar The results cannot be easily dismissed with a comparison with a newly developed and relatively untested method. Further research and a critical review of the various approaches is needed. In the first part of his letter, Longden also discusses specific results relating to the shapes of the exposure–response curves and the minimum mortality temperature. Regarding the curves, he states how in his cited analysis the temperature–mortality association resembles a J-shaped curve,4Schwartz J Spix C Touloumi G et al.Methodological issues in studies of air pollution and daily counts of deaths or hospital admissions.J Epidemiol Community Health. 1996; 50: S3-S11Crossref PubMed Google Scholar more than a U-shaped curve as in a previous Article published in 2015 by our research team.9Gasparrini A Guo Y Hashizume M et al.Mortality risk attributable to high and low ambient temperature: a multicountry observational study.Lancet. 2015; 386: 369-375Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar This J-curve association implies a higher risk and excess mortality associated with heat compared with cold. Longden supported his statement by citing five articles. However, we would like to point out that three of these articles involve locations in tropical areas of Vietnam, Kenya, and China, which are not climatologically similar to the three main Australian cities included in our analysis (Melbourne, Sydney, and Brisbane). The other two articles are multilocation analyses reporting results for US cities, in which the estimated curves look more like an inverse J shape (see for instance figure S8 in the cited study by Lee and colleagues10Lee W Kim H Hwang S Zanobetti A Schwartz JD Chung Y Monte Carlo simulation-based estimation for the minimum mortality temperature in temperature-mortality association study.BMC Med Res Methodol. 2017; 17: 137Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). These associations, characterised by a high minimum mortality temperature and a high number of cold-related deaths, are consistent with what we previously found.9Gasparrini A Guo Y Hashizume M et al.Mortality risk attributable to high and low ambient temperature: a multicountry observational study.Lancet. 2015; 386: 369-375Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar Regarding the minimum mortality temperature, we reported the estimate of 22·4°C for Melbourne (see the table in the appendix [pp 7–15] of the 2015 Article),9Gasparrini A Guo Y Hashizume M et al.Mortality risk attributable to high and low ambient temperature: a multicountry observational study.Lancet. 2015; 386: 369-375Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar but we stress how this value is not uncommon across the other 381 cities included in the analysis, especially those in relatively warm climates. This minimum mortality temperature is higher than the average annual temperature of 18·1°C for Australia (table 1 in the 2015 Article),9Gasparrini A Guo Y Hashizume M et al.Mortality risk attributable to high and low ambient temperature: a multicountry observational study.Lancet. 2015; 386: 369-375Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar but also for all the other cities or countries, consistent with findings from other research groups; for instance, the two multicity studies cited in Longden's Correspondence. In conclusion, we welcome the assessment that Longden has provided on our Article, and we agree that further analyses and comparison with alternative approaches are warranted to complement the evidence on potential health effects of climate change in Australia and other regions of the world. Both authors report a grant from the UK Medical Research Council (MR/M022625/1) and a grant from the UK Natural Environment Research Council (NE/R009384/1). Projections of temperature-related excess mortality under climate change scenariosThis study shows the negative health impacts of climate change that, under high-emission scenarios, would disproportionately affect warmer and poorer regions of the world. Comparison with lower emission scenarios emphasises the importance of mitigation policies for limiting global warming and reducing the associated health risks. Full-Text PDF Open AccessTemperature-related mortality and climate change in AustraliaTemperature-related mortality is one of the main measures used to assess the costs and benefits associated with climate change. Some assessments have found a net benefit of climate change due to reduced cold temperature deaths offsetting increases in heat-related deaths.1–3 Antonio Gasparrini and colleagues1 and Vicedo-Cabrera and colleagues3 found a net benefit of climate change for Australia, a surprising outcome given that other regions that experience cooler weather were associated with a net cost of climate change. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: What if the earth had a fatal heart attack?
display_name: What if the earth had a fatal heart attack?

author.au_affiliation_raw: Los Angeles County Department of Health Services, Los Angeles, CA, USA
author.institution_display_name: Los Angeles County Department of Health Services

author.au_affiliation_raw: University of California, Los Angeles, CA, USA
University of California, Los Angeles, CA, USA

ab: Now in her 60s, Mrs PE hauls around a metal oxygen tank. She is the victim of a slow, debilitating process that began decades earlier with fast food consumption, physical inactivity, and cigarette smoking. Although she felt fine, over time she steadily gained weight and her cholesterol levels crept up. By the time these subtle warning signs became apparent, the damage to her vital organs was irreversible. This woman might help save our planet. That is because Mrs PE is actually a metaphor for Mrs Patient Earth—our plastic-clogged waterways are her cholesterol build-up, our global warming crisis is her silent rise in blood pressure, and our coal overdependence is her food overconsumption. These are the chronic stressors on Earth's vital organs. Metaphors like the aforementioned one are perhaps our most precious currency in this crusade for a sustainable planet, because the modern technological era now demands more than ever that effective risk communication be relatable, memorable, and succinct. Indeed, this ongoing failure in risk communication is the most serious threat to the environmental movement. Dr John Sterman, a leading scientist on climate change from Massachusetts Institute of Technology, highlights that “strong scientific consensus on the causes and risks of climate change stands in stark contrast to widespread confusion and complacency among the public”,1Sterman JD Risk communication on climate: mental models and mass balance.Science. 2008; 322: 532-533Crossref PubMed Scopus (244) Google Scholar and ineffective risk communication is now the “major bottleneck preventing science from playing an appropriate role in climate policy.”2Sterman JD Communicating climate change risks in a skeptical world.Clim Change. 2011; 108: 811Crossref Scopus (140) Google Scholar Researchers are now actively working on this pressing communication problem, including at the University of California Climate Lab, the Yale Climate Change Communication programme, and the Climate Outreach programme. Yet, more work needs to be done. So, if the science is clear yet the communication unclear, how do we save Patient Earth? As doctors, we learn how to communicate risk throughout our careers. Every day we are charged with the responsibility to explain complex and preventable conditions with distant consequences, much akin to environmental risks, such that patients can immediately understand their situation and make actionable changes themselves. First, we've learned that risk communication is a trainable skill. In fact, a major study showed that communication training for doctors improves patient adherence by more than 10% for treatments such as medications, diet improvements, increased exercise, and cancer screening—behaviours with high stakes yet distant outcomes.3Zolnierek KBH DiMatteo MR Physician communication and patient adherence to treatment: a meta-analysis.Med Care. 2009; 47: 826Crossref PubMed Scopus (1458) Google Scholar Indeed, in medical school, the practice of working with hired patient actors and then reviewing our interactions with clinical mentors is considered an essential training tool. We quickly learn which risk communication techniques motivate behaviour change and which do not. For example, in trying to connect today's sugar-loaded diet to an increased risk of diabetes, the vividness of a surgical limb amputation resonates more powerfully than the vague future risk of diabetes itself. This skill is both teachable and fundamental to the work of both doctors and environmental scientists alike. Second, we have realised the striking effect of risk communication during moments of crisis. One large longitudinal survey found that patients with a new diagnosis of stroke, cancer, lung disease, heart disease, or diabetes were three times more likely to quit smoking than the average smoker.4Keenan PS Smoking and weight change after new health diagnoses in older adults.Arch Intern Med. 2009; 169: 237-242Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar Numerous studies since then have confirmed that new diagnoses, especially of serious medical conditions, represent teachable moments for risk-factor modification. Perhaps, environmentalists too could initiate timely, highly-focused campaigns surrounding important natural disasters. For example, this strategy might have substantially magnified risk communication (and perhaps even changed human behaviour) following the destructive California wildfires that cost more than US$3·5 billion or the record-setting US mid-west freeze that killed 21 people. Third, we tap into the power of figurative language to shed light on risk and complexity and motivate crucial behaviors. One of us faced this dilemma on a medical trip to Malawi, Africa—how do you get a 7-year-old boy with HIV to take life-saving medications every day of his life? By sharing with him that taking his (antiretroviral) medications gives the soldiers in his body the vitamins they need to fight disease and keep him strong. A study substantiated our personal experience, showing that when explaining cancer treatments, patients appreciated the use of metaphors such as traffic jam and bus driver, instead of exon specificity and driver mutation.5Pinheiro AP Pocock RH Dixon MD Shaib WL Ramalingam SS Pentz RD Using metaphors to explain molecular testing to cancer patients.Oncologist. 2017; 22: 445-449Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar By creating simplified mental models (such as in the case of Patient Earth), metaphors might represent a potent cure to the problem of risk communication. We live in a time when the battle is often over tweets and truth, in which human attention span is measured in milliseconds, and in which viral and instafamous are status symbols. This reality is ours. Thus, our tactics should be tailored to the 280 character limit of our lives. In a world in which our greatest enemy is the mischaracterisation of truth by a single tweet, the metaphor further lends itself to battle in this medium. After nearly 50 years of policy advancement since the first Earth Day in 1970, our planet is now under unprecedented assault. Although US policies are not the only contributor, we are far from leading the charge in the right direction. In just the past 2 years alone, our nation has withdrawn from the Paris Agreement, proposed reversal in fuel efficiency standards, and recommended budget cuts to renewable energy research and climate change initiatives.6Greshko M Parker L Howard BC A running list of how trump is changing the environment.https://news.nationalgeographic.com/2017/03/how-trump-is-changing-science-environmentDate accessed: April 8, 2019Google Scholar Progressive causes have long struggled with their inability to overcome academic tendencies and abstract policy prescriptions, failing to galvanise widespread public action. This is especially true for issues with far-removed consequences, such as climate change and chronic disease risks. Current events remind us all of our shared purpose to protect and preserve the health of our planet. We should reflect, refine, and reclaim the techniques and tactics we use to serve this purpose. Ultimately, Earth's health might depend on a simple metaphor. We declare no competing interests.

title: Attribution of reductions in malaria prevalence in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania – Authors' reply
display_name: Attribution of reductions in malaria prevalence in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania – Authors' reply

author.au_affiliation_raw: Ifakara Health Institute, Environmental Health and Ecological Sciences Thematic Group, Dar es Salaam 78373, Tanzania
Ifakara Health Institute, Environmental Health and Ecological Sciences Thematic Group, Dar es Salaam 78373, Tanzania
Ifakara Health Institute, Environmental Health and Ecological Sciences Thematic Group, Dar es Salaam 78373, Tanzania
Ifakara Health Institute, Environmental Health and Ecological Sciences Thematic Group, Dar es Salaam 78373, Tanzania

ab: We thank Mathieu Maheu-Giroux and Marcia Castro for their Correspondence about our Article.1Killeen GF Govella NJ Mlacha YP Chaki PP Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of parasitological and entomological surveys.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e132-e143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar Regarding concerns about the stepped-wedge design of the larviciding scale-up in our study, we agree and also note that scale-up was not randomised, but rather introduced earliest to the best-prepared wards. However, such compromises are normal and healthy in pragmatic assessments of effectiveness under realistic programmatic conditions, rather than efficacy under artificially controlled experimental conditions. As acknowledged in the discussion and emphasised in the title, we also agree that evidence for window screening impact is purely observational, and that long-overdue, cluster-randomised, experimentally controlled analyses of well developed delivery practices for both these supplementary vector control measures are urgently needed.1Killeen GF Govella NJ Mlacha YP Chaki PP Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of parasitological and entomological surveys.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e132-e143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar However, we disagree with the view that our attributions of intervention effects are haphazard and that potential confounders were “arbitrarily disregarded”. In our Article,1Killeen GF Govella NJ Mlacha YP Chaki PP Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of parasitological and entomological surveys.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e132-e143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar factors such as bed nets, antimalarial drugs, and household-level screening were all considered in the analysis, with relevant effect sizes reported and discussed in detail. Although major shifts in vector population composition were observed in rural Tanzania around the time of the first mass distributions for insecticide-treated nets in 2008,2Russell TL Govella NJ Azizi S Drakeley CJ Kachur SP Killeen GF Increased proportions of outdoor feeding among residual malaria vector populations following increased use of insecticide-treated nets in rural Tanzania.Malar J. 2011; 10: 80Crossref PubMed Scopus (421) Google Scholar, 3Derua YA Alifrangis M Hosea KM et al.Change in composition of the Anopheles gambiae complex and its possible implications for the transmission of malaria and lymphatic filariasis in north-eastern Tanzania.Malar J. 2012; 11: 188Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar no equivalent changes were observed in Dar es Salaam over the same period, because the city was given lowest priority in both national campaigns so coverage remained low until 2010.4Msellemu D Namango HI Mwakalinga VM et al.The epidemiology of residual Plasmodium falciparum malaria transmission and infection burden in an African city with high coverage of multiple vector control measures.Malar J. 2016; 15: 288Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar Although a slight upward trend in net usage coincided with the downward trend in human malaria prevalence in Dar es Salaam, and artemisinin-based therapies also came into use, uptake of both measures was far too low to plausibly account for such massive reductions of malaria burden.1Killeen GF Govella NJ Mlacha YP Chaki PP Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of parasitological and entomological surveys.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e132-e143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar The only interventions for which substantive upward coverage trends were observed over the study period were larviciding and window screening. Together, these two intervention scale-ups were associated with prevalence reductions equivalent to those accounted for with a simple, unattributed empirical time trend.1Killeen GF Govella NJ Mlacha YP Chaki PP Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of parasitological and entomological surveys.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e132-e143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar As detailed in the methods, we did account for temporal autocorrelation when fitting these models.1Killeen GF Govella NJ Mlacha YP Chaki PP Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of parasitological and entomological surveys.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e132-e143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar Indeed, our models that included a simple empirical time trend as per previous studies5Lawson AB Carroll R Castro M Joint spatial Bayesian modeling for studies combining longitudinal and cross-sectional data.Stat Methods Med Res. 2014; 23: 611-624Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar, 6Maheu-Giroux M Castro MC Impact of community-based larviciding on the prevalence of malaria infection in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.PLoS One. 2013; 8: e71638Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar essentially reproduced the previous results, notably the modest effect size estimates for larviciding. The major issue therefore seems to be that fitting an unattributed empirical time trend may have spuriously assimilated the effects of both observed intervention scale-up processes.1Killeen GF Govella NJ Mlacha YP Chaki PP Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of parasitological and entomological surveys.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e132-e143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar Underestimating effect sizes may be as dangerous as overestimating them, and regression dilution bias inherently exacerbates risk of underestimation. Notably, the entomological secondary outcomes and explanatory variables clearly and independently implicated window screening as the most important, obvious, and parsimonious explanation for the remarkable decline in malaria prevalence.1Killeen GF Govella NJ Mlacha YP Chaki PP Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of parasitological and entomological surveys.Lancet Planet Health. 2019; 3: e132-e143Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar Substantial reductions of mosquito population density were associated with scale-up of both larviciding and window screens. Effect sizes for different taxonomic groups of mosquitoes were fully consistent with those attributed to the same two interventions for the epidemiological data. Crucially, the effect sizes for window screening were greatest for the most efficient malaria vectors with the greatest preference for human hosts, and therefore the greatest dependence upon accessing human blood. It is difficult to envision how changes in demography, socioeconomic status, or any intervention other than a personal protection measure like window screens could cause such behaviour-dependent effects on mosquito populations. GFK, NJG, YPM, and PPC report grants from the United States Agency for International Development, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, the Wellcome Trust (fellowship award to GFK), and Valent BioSciences LLC. Suppression of malaria vector densities and human infection prevalence associated with scale-up of mosquito-proofed housing in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania: re-analysis of an observational series of parasitological and entomological surveysCommunity-wide mosquito proofing of houses might deliver greater impacts on vector populations and malaria transmission than previously thought. The spontaneous nature of the scale-up observed here is also encouraging with regards to practicality, acceptability, and affordability in low-income settings. Full-Text PDF Open AccessAttribution of reductions in malaria prevalence in Dar es Salaam, TanzaniaDar es Salaam's Urban Malaria Control Project (UMCP) was launched in 2004 with the objective of implementing and assessing a microbial larviciding intervention. From 2004 to 2008, malaria prevalence decreased from 28% to less than 2%.1 This collapse of malaria vector populations was also observed in neighbouring regions of Tanzania.2 Part of the reduction preceded the initiation of larviciding activities and the introduction of artemisinin-based combination therapies. Yet, previous analyses suggested that larviciding was effective in reducing malaria prevalence. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Deforestation and malaria in Madagascar: a new framework to explore linkages in the absence of robust health reporting infrastructure
display_name: Deforestation and malaria in Madagascar: a new framework to explore linkages in the absence of robust health reporting infrastructure

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Global Health and Population, Harvard T H Chan School of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA
Department of Environmental Health, Harvard T H Chan School of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA
Medical Entomology Unit, Institut Pasteur de Madagascar, Antananarivo, Madagascar
Medical Entomology Unit, Institut Pasteur de Madagascar, Antananarivo, Madagascar
Madagascar Health and Environmental Research, Maroantsetra, Madagascar
Catholic Relief Services, Antananarivo, Madagascar
Department of Global Health and Population, Harvard T H Chan School of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA
Department of Environmental Health, Harvard T H Chan School of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA

ab: BackgroundLand-use changes, such as deforestation, can increase the transmission potential of a landscape by increasing the abundance of preferred microhabitats for malaria vectors. However, this relationship between malaria and deforestation is complex and depends on factors such as the type of land use, the local ecology of malaria vector species, and the health resources available to the human population. In Madagascar, despite alarmingly high rates of deforestation and concerning reports of increases in malaria, this link remains poorly studied.MethodsThe feasibility of traditional approaches to studying the link between malaria and deforestation is limited for Madagascar because (i) health systems lack capacity to collect regular and accurate malaria data, especially in many rural areas, (ii) vector habitat preferences are poorly understood, and (iii) most existing malaria infection outcome datasets lack data on important mediating factors. To circumvent inadequacies in current data streams, we discuss a new framework that integrates novel primary data collection efforts on malaria infection and vector ecology from cross-sectional studies with longitudinal land-use data from remote sensing. Incorporating these data into hierarchical models allows us to infer structural associations between macro and micro level predictors of malaria risk in different ecological contexts in Madagascar. We compare the outputs from these models to analyses that can be conducted with robust data from the Brazilian health system.FindingsWe report data on malaria burden, deforestation, its covariates, and vector larval habitat preference for four distinct, previously understudied, ecoregions of Madagascar. Risk factors of malaria infection vary in sign and magnitude of effect across ecological contexts.InterpretationWhile data such as Brazil's allow for predictive modelling and assessment of temporally dynamic systems, our proposed modelling framework demonstrates variations in risk factors regionally in the meantime. This approach can help to mitigate current data gaps and better inform existing malaria control efforts in Madagascar during health system development.FundingThe Ren Che Foundation, Henry David Thoreau Foundation, Catholic Relief Services through a grand from United States Agency for International Development, and Madagascar Health and Environmental Research (MAHERY).

title: A payment of ecosystem services programme leveraging ecological restoration, public health, and livelihood in a family farm-dominated landscape
display_name: A payment of ecosystem services programme leveraging ecological restoration, public health, and livelihood in a family farm-dominated landscape

author.au_affiliation_raw: Gund IE, Burlington, VT, USA
Gund IE, Burlington, VT, USA
University of São Paulo, São Paulo, Brazil
The University of Vermont, Burlington, VT, USA

ab: Society must increase food production and restore vital ecosystem services or suffer unacceptable consequences. Unfortunately, conventional agriculture might be the single greatest threat to ecosystem function. At the same time, reducing ecologically harmful agricultural inputs or restoring farmlands to native ecosystems threatens food production. We fell into this predicament because we designed agricultural and economic systems that failed to account for ecosystem services, and the path forward requires redesigning both systems. Agroecology—which applies ecological principles to design sustainable farming methods that can increase food production, wean us away from non-renewable and harmful agricultural inputs, and restore ecosystem services—promises to be an appropriate redesign of agricultural systems. In Santa Rosa de Lima (Santa Catarina, Brazil), we are working with small family farmers, local and state government, and non-government organisations to develop multifunction riparian forests (MultRF) and High biodiversity silvopastoral systems (SPSnuclei) that achieve these goals, as well as the policies required for the adoption and dissemination. Appropriate policies must recognise that agricultural land can be managed for multiple ecosystem services, some of which directly benefit the farmer and market production, while others flow to society as a whole at different spatial levels, and hence are public goods. Ongoing research suggests that MultRFs and SPSnuclei can generate crucial ecosystem services like controlling blackflies, but incur initial investments. Farmers cannot be expected to prioritise the needs of society over those of their family, even when the former is socially optimal. This paper describes a pilot project for payments for ecosystem services for an agroecology scheme in Santa Rosa de Lima Southern Brazil, designed as participatory action research by the Silvopastoral and Ecological Restoration Lab (Universidade Federal de Santa Catarina) to address these challenges. Funding CAPES & CNPq & Gund IE. Contributors All cited authors were fully involved on the design of the PSA program discussed. Declaration of interests We declare no competing interests.

title: Quantifying the consumption, nutrition, and greenhouse gas emission effects of dietary guidelines in China: a modelling study
display_name: Quantifying the consumption, nutrition, and greenhouse gas emission effects of dietary guidelines in China: a modelling study

author.au_affiliation_raw: SOAS University of London, London, UK

ab: BackgroundThe rapid nutrition transition China is now ongoing; the so-called westernisation of diets has been negatively affecting both human health and that of the environment. Against this backdrop, the Chinese government released new Dietary Guidelines (CDG) in 2016 and has been actively promoting them since. Our research makes use of quantitative modelling and aims to determine whether adjusting the average Chinese diet, so that it fulfils dietary requirements, could lead to nutritional and environmental co-benefits. Moreover, we want to determine the maximum reduction in greenhouse gas emissions (GHGEs) that could be achieved while simultaneously consuming a healthy diet.MethodsA diet optimisation model is used to simulate, quantify and compare the effects on the consumption of 19 food groups, and associated levels of GHGEs, resulting from two different scenarios: consumers complying with either the CDG or the WHO dietary norms. Subsequent simulations set maximum emission limits for the optimised diets and progressively reduce emissions by 5%. Four waves of consumption and price survey data from the China Health and Nutrition Survey are used in the analysis, while LCA estimates of GHGEs are compiled from the appropriate literature.FindingsPreliminary results show that outcomes under the two scenarios differ significantly, both nutritionally and in terms of GHGEs. Adopting the CDG would lead to a considerable intensification of emissions for both men and women, while adhering to the WHO norms would marginally increase emissions for women and slightly decrease emissions for men. However, we find a 10% reduction in GHGEs relative to current levels could be achieved, under both scenarios, through healthy and realistic dietary change. The maximum decrease in emissions achievable in the CDG model is 15%. The WHO models with a more drastic decrease in emissions (30% and 40%) involve major dietary change and lead to less balanced and varied diets compared with existing ones.InterpretationOur quantitative estimates show the potential for dietary guidelines to lead to environmental and health co-benefits, but only if they are specifically formulated to include environmental considerations. Achieving a major reduction in GHGEs through diets involves clear trade-offs between nutritional and environmental considerations.FundingNone.

title: Actor network theory to map planetary health interconnections: a clinical case study
display_name: Actor network theory to map planetary health interconnections: a clinical case study

author.au_affiliation_raw: Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, Porto Alegre, Brazil
author.institution_display_name: Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul

author.au_affiliation_raw: Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, Porto Alegre, Brazil

author.au_affiliation_raw: Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, Porto Alegre, Brazil
author.institution_display_name: Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul

ab: BackgroundIn 2017, the World Organization of Family Doctors (WONCA) officially stated "[it is] imperative that planetary health be included in the core curriculum of medical schools, family medicine residencies and further professional development". In 2019 WONCA urged "family doctors around the world to commit to acting on planetary health". Despite positive repercussions from major medical journals, the integration of planetary health into medical education remains a challenge. In this context it seems relevant to search for and develop tools to facilitate planetary health medical teaching. We aimed to apply actor-network theory (ANT) to describe interconnections between a patient with a clinical problem and planetary health proximal and distal issues.MethodsUsing ANT anthropological methodology, we describe the human and non-human actors involved in the interdependent network around the visit of a patient with obesity, hypertension, and diabetes to a community health clinic in southern Brazil. Perceived relevant proximal and distal planetary health issues involved in the clinical case were described, then organised into one diagram. This ANT clinical case diagram was subsequently used as a teaching tool.FindingsThis ANT clinical case diagram was presented to medical students and other health professionals in a few conferences and lectures in Brazil during the second semester of 2018 and initial months of 2019. Informal feedback from students and peers has been positive so far. The ANT diagram seemed to significantly facilitate comprehension of the planetary health framework to address clinical issues.InterpretationANT methodology could potentially be used in different clinical cases in diverse scenarios. Further formal quantitative and qualitative assessment of the utility of this teaching tool is required.FundingNone.
